questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presents with a black, foul-smelling nasal discharge and suppuration of the eye with visual impairment. On examination, there is black eschar on the nasal mucosa. On Sabouraud agar, the colonies formed are grey-white with thick cottony, fluffy surfaces. What is the finding seen on microscopic examination?

choices.text: Broad, ribbon-like hyphae with irregular branching
Spherical yeast with a thick capsule on India ink staining
Oval, budding yeast cells with germ tube formation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. Under the microscope, it is seen as broad, ribbon-like aseptate hyphae with irregular branching. 

Mucormycosis (zygomycosis) is an opportunistic infection caused by species of rhizopus, mucor, and absidia. Among them, the most prevalent species are Rhizopus oryzae and R. delemar. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. They invade the tissues of patients, enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels, particularly paranasal sinuses and orbit. The blackish discoloration is due to arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis- They can be stained with 10% potassium hydroxide and can be cultured. On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface. Under the microscope, they appear as nonseptate or sparsely septate, irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores). 

Treatment: Surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration.

The below image shows broad aseptate and irregularly branched hyphae seen in mucormycosis.

Other options:

Option A-Long conidiophores with terminal vesicles are seen with aspergillus 

Option C- Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule on India ink stain is seen with cryptococcus neoformans

Option D- Oval, budding yeast cells with germ tube formation is seen with candida.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female patient presents to your clinic with nasal obstruction. Physical examination revealed a wide, roomy nasal cavity, a pale nasal mucosa and greyish-black dry crusts that improved after modified Young's procedure. Identify the clinical feature likely to be associated with this condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis, and merciful anosmia is associated with this condition. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. The patient presents with nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers. It is associated with foul odor from their nose but the patient is unable to smell it because of merciful anosmia. Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements. On examination nasal mucosa appears pale, greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. 

Medical management is done using warm saline for nasal irrigation, removal of crusts and administering local antibiotics like kemicetine antiozaena solution(containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2).

Surgical management involves:

  • In Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule. They are opened after 6 months and during this time, the mucosa comes back to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young operation is a modified version of Young's operation where the nostrils are only partially closed. The results are the same compared to Young's operation and it is done to avoid discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. 

Other options:

Option A: Offensive cheesy discharge is seen in an uncommon condition called rhinitis caseosa. It is usually unilateral and affects males. The disease arises from chronic sinusitis with the collection of inspissated cheesy material.

Option C: Paroxysmal sneezing refers to bouts of sneezing in the morning and is associated with allergic rhinitis and vasomotor rhinitis. 

Option D: Allergic salute is the constant upward rubbing motion of the nose simulating a salute, leading to transverse nasal crease across the dorsum of the nose. Seen in allergic rhinitis. 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

questions.text: During a lice outbreak among jail inmates, a few of them developed fevers that subsided after 3-5 days. The fever relapsed after a week and subsided again. Many patients had tender splenomegaly on examination. What is the most appropriate management for the given cases?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lice-borne relapsing fever (LBRF) caused by Borrelia recurrentis. The most appropriate management is to start Doxycycline therapy.

Relapsing fever is an infectious condition due to Borrelia species and is characterised by two or more episodes of fever with periods of well-being. It can be of two types: 

  • Louse-borne or epidemic relapsing fever acquired from head or body louse and caused by Borrelia recurrentis and
  • Tick-borne relapsing fever acquired from soft ticks 

Clinical features include sudden onset of fever, rigours, pulse and blood pressure rise followed by diaphoresis, temperature fall, and hypotension. Headache, neck stiffness, arthralgia, and myalgia can also be present. There may be hepatosplenomegaly during the episodes, causing abdominal pain. Myocarditis may be present and can lead to death.

The preferred treatment for louse-borne relapsing fever in adults is a 10-day course of doxycycline (100 mg twice daily) or tetracycline (500 mg or 12.5 mg/kg orally every 6 hours). If tetracyclines are contraindicated, erythromycin (500 mg or 12.5 mg/kg orally every 6 hours) for ten days is used as an alternative.

In cases where CNS involvement is suspected or confirmed, intravenous administration of penicillin G (5 million units IV every 6 hours) or ceftriaxone (2 g IV daily) for 10–14 days is preferred. However, if resources are limited and CNS involvement is not suspected, oral penicillin V potassium (500 mg or 12.5 mg/kg every 6–8 hours) can be given for ten days.

Other options: 

Option A: Gentamicin is not used for the management of borrelia as it is relatively resistant to aminoglycosides.  

Options B: Proper personal hygiene and avoiding overcrowding are preventive strategies for this disease. Other preventive strategies include better access to hot water (≥60° C) for clothes washing and use of pesticides in the infested buildings.

Option D: Topical 5% permethrin is used for the treatment of scabies.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: In the following left ventricle (LV) pressure-volume loop diagram, the mitral valve will open at point:
questions.solution:
The mitral valve will open at point 1.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • 4 - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

During isovolumic contraction, the volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point 3.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point 4), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. The line labeled IV traces this decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of death in smothering?
questions.solution:
Slow asphyxia is the mechanism of death in smothering. 

Smothering is a type of asphyxia that is caused by closing the external respiratory openings (nose, mouth) either by the hand or by inserting a foreign substance (cloth, mud) into them. 

Smothering can be: 

  • Suicide - Commonly seen in psychiatric patients and prisoners. Self-smothering is not possible using the hand. Thus, suicide is attempted either by the burial of the face in a mattress or by tying a polythene bag over the head.
  • Homicidal - It is a simple and convenient method of homicide. It is a type of gentle homicide and is difficult to prove as it leaves no evidence. Usually, the things used to smother are - cloth, a pillow, or a hand
  • Accidental - Commonly seen in intoxicated, epileptics, and children. In intoxicated or epileptics, smothering may occur due to accidental burial of the face in the pillow. In children, smothering may occur due to accidental suffocation while playing with plastic bags

 The image below shows a picture showing smothering by a pillow and hand:

Other options:

Options A & D are mechanisms of death seen in hanging.

Option A: Death due to cerebral anemia can be seen in hanging. It occurs when the knot of the rope is placed at the nape of the neck which causes compression of the large vessels (both arteries and veins). This causes death within 10 to 15 seconds due to cerebral anemia and consequent coma.

Option D: Death due to venous congestion can be seen in hanging. It is particularly seen in cases where the knot is situated over the chin causing compression of the jugular veins. This in turn stops cerebral circulation leading to a rise in the venous pressure in the head and subsequent loss of consciousness. A tension of 2kgs is sufficient to occlude the jugular veins.

Option C: Death due to laryngeal spasm can be seen in drowning.

questions.text: The sign shown in the given ultrasound image of the lung is seen in:
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image of the lung shows the barcode sign or stratosphere sign which is seen in pneumothorax.

On M mode, classical signs for the grayscale imaging are seen:
• Seashore sign: normal lung
• Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax


The given M-mode image in the question demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a similar linear pattern deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign indicates absent lung sliding and suggests the presence of pneumothorax at this.

The M-mode image of a normal lung demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a granular or sandy appearance deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon is known as the seashore sign and it indicates normal lung sliding and excludes pneumothorax at this interspace.

Other options:

Option B: Pleural effusion on ultrasound appears anechoic with an echogenic line at the fluid-lung interface if it is transudate. Exudative and hemorrhagic effusions may appear echogenic with pleural thickening. The fluid shows movement and changes in shape with breathing, along with the presence of septa and fibrous strands.

Option C: Consolidation on ultrasound appears hypoechoic with heterogeneous echotexture. It is isoechoic with the liver and is referred to as lung hepatization. 

Option D: A collapsed lung under a large effusion will be seen as a hyperechoic wedge-shaped area.

questions.text: A child is brought with hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma. On testing, you find an isolated prolongation of prothrombin time. Which of the following clotting factors is likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma is suggestive of a bleeding disorder and that associated with an isolated prolonged prothrombin time shows that clotting factor VII is likely to be deficient in this patient.  

Prothrombin time (PT) assesses the extrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time (in seconds) needed for plasma to clot after the addition of an exogenous source of tissue thromboplastin and calcium ions. A prolonged PT can occur due to deficiencies/dysfunction of factors V, VII, X, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) assesses the intrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time needed for plasma to clot after the addition of kaolin (to activate XII), cephalin (substitutes platelet phospholipids), and calcium ions. aPTT is prolonged due to dysfunction of V, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII, prothrombin, and fibrinogen.  

Thus this shows that factor VII deficiency is associated with isolated prolongation of PT.

Clotting factor VII deficiency, otherwise known as Alexander's disease, is usually inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. It can present with recurrent episodes of bleeding into joints, muscles, and closed spaces that start spontaneously or following an injury. Diagnosis can be made by lab results of PT and aPTT and confirmed with factor VII assay. Patients are treated with recombinant factor VIIa.  

Other options:

Option B & C: Factor VIII and IX deficiency, otherwise known as hemophilia A & B respectively, are associated with isolated prolonged aPTT.

Option D: Factor II deficiency is associated with prolongation of both PT and aPTT.

questions.text: A young boy presented with a cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula.

Ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland. It produces a characteristic translucent swelling that gives the appearance of a frog’s belly. A ranula usually resolves spontaneously.  

A plunging ranula is a mucus retention cyst. It has mucus collecting below the gland and perforating through the mylohyoid muscle.

Other options:

Options A: Ectopic thyroid tissue is a developmental defect of the thyroid gland and is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct. Lingual thyroid is the most common presentation of ectopic thyroid (shown below).

Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. 

Option C: Ludwig's angina is a brawny swelling of the submandibular region that is caused by streptococcal infection. The infection tracks down to the mylohyoid muscle causing inflammation that displaces the tongue leading to dysphagia and painful airway obstruction. Management is by antibiotic therapy and decompression of the floor of the mouth by incising mylohyoid muscle.  

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

Related Pearl: Plunging ranula

It is a form of mucous retention cyst that can arise from both sublingual and submandibular salivary glands and presents as dumb-bell-shaped swelling that is soft, fluctuant and painless in the submandibular or submental region of the neck.

  • It shows cross fluctuation along the mylohyoid
  • Treatment is by removal of the sublingual gland and aspiration of the saliva out from the sac. The cervical approach which was previously used is now contraindicated.
  • Conditions with cross fluctuation are :
    • Plunging ranula
    • Bilocular hydrocele
    • Compound palmar ganglion
    • Psoas abscess

Note:

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.

questions.text: A tourist presented with fever, lymphadenopathy, and a skin lesion as shown below after a forest hike. He remembers getting an insect bite from the forest. Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of insect bite followed by fever and lymphadenopathy and the clinical image of eschar formation are suggestive of scrub typhus. Penicillin  was found to be ineffective in the treatment of scrub typhus. 

Scrub typhus is caused by O. tsutsugamushi and the vector is trombiculid mite. Clinical features include fever, lymphadenopathy, headache, and eschar where the chigger has been fed.

Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Doxycycline, Azithromycin or chloramphenicol are also used for the treatment. In the case of pregnant women where doxycycline is relatively contraindicated, azithromycin may be preferred.

questions.text: A patient with a mechanical prosthetic valve is on a long-term oral coumarin anticoagulant. Which of the following coagulation factors will functionally reduce due to this drug?
questions.solution:
The coagulation factor II will be functionally reduced due to the use of oral coumarin anticoagulant. 

Coumarin anticoagulants, such as warfarin (most commonly used), are vitamin K antagonists that act by indirectly interfering with the production of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. 

Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X is done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase which is inhibited by warfarin. Hence, there will be a reduction in the activation of coagulation factors.

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

Warfarin is chiefly used as a chronic anticoagulant (e.g., in venous thromboembolism prophylaxis or for preventing stroke in atrial fibrillation). It is also used as an anticoagulant to prevent systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve. 

However, warfarin toxicity can lead to bleeding that may even be fatal. Its dose is regulated by measuring prothrombin time and international normalized ratio (INR) levels. Treatment of toxicity involves withholding the anticoagulant, administration of vitamin K, and giving prothrombin complex concentrate or fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors.

An infant is brought with history of multiple episodes of seizures and fasting hypoglycemia. On examination, there is growth retardation, hepatomegaly, and hypotonia. Lipid profile, AST, and ALT are deranged. Liver biopsy shows hepatocytes with large glycogen stores. Biochemical analysis reveals glycogen with short outer chains. Which enzyme deficiency, as shown in the image, causes this condition?

AST: Aspartate aminotransferase

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Cori's disease - Type III glycogen storage disease (GSD), due to the deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme. This disease is also called Forbes disease or limit dextrinosis.

A deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme results in the accumulation of glycogen with short outer chains in the liver and muscles called limit dextrans. On muscle biopsy, this is seen as vacuolation of muscle fibers.

 Other options:

Option B: Andersen disease (Glycogen storage disease type IV) is due to the deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme (enzyme 3 in the image). It presents with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of polysaccharides with  a few branching points, and the child usually dies by the age of 5 years

Option C: McArdle syndrome (Type V GSD) is due to the deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (the enzyme 4 in the image). It presents with poor exercise tolerance, low lactate levels following exercise, and accumulation of glycogen in muscles.

Option D:  Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase (enzyme 7 in the image). The affected child will have cardiomegaly, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of claudication pain of the left lower limb while walking. Which of the following phosphodiesterase inhibitors is indicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The history of claudication pain suggests a likely diagnosis of peripheral vascular disease and cilostazol is the phosphodiesterase inhibitor that is indicated in this condition.

Phosphodiesterase (PDE) is an enzyme that degrades cyclic nucleotides intracellularly. Therefore, phosphodiesterase inhibitors increase the concentration of cyclic nucleotides (cAMP and cGMP).

There are different classes of phosphodiesterase inhibitors of which cilostazol is a PDE-3 inhibitor. It increases intracellular cAMP in vascular smooth muscle and platelets leading to vasodilatory and antiaggregatory effects. This allows patients with intermittent claudication to have better walking distance. 

Other options:

Option A: Sildenafil and tadalafil are selective PDE-5 inhibitor and are used for pulmonary arterial hypertension and erectile dysfunction.

Option C: Theophylline is a non-specific phosphodiesterase inhibitor that causes bronchodilatation as well as decreases the release of inflammatory cytokines. It has limited use in the management of asthma due to various side effects.

Option D: Milrinone is a selective PDE - 3 inhibitor and is used as a short-term therapy in severe or refractory congestive heart failure.

questions.text: A patient died from bronchopneumonia following an intracerebral hemorrhage caused by cerebral metastases from a squamous cell carcinoma of the left main bronchus. What should be recorded in line I (c) of the death certificate?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the left main bronchus

questions.solution:
Cerebral metastasis will be filled in the line I (c) of the death certificate, as one of the antecedent causes in the order of the events that took place.

The flow of events in this patient is as follows:

WHO death certificate contains part I and part II.

Part I contains a sequence of events that directly caused death. It further has

  • Part I (a)- Disease or condition directly leading to death. In this case, it is bronchopneumonia.
  • Part I (b)- Preceding disease or condition that lead to I (a). In this case, it is intracerebral hemorrhage.
  • Part I (c)- Preceding disease or condition that lead to I (b). In this case, it is cerebral metastasis.
  • Part I (d)- Preceding disease or condition that lead to I (c). In this case, it is squamous cell carcinoma of the left main bronchus.

Part II mentions other diseases or conditions that influenced the morbidity of the process, and thus contributed to the fatality. It is not directly related to the disease. Examples can be diabetes mellitus, hypertension, etc. Part II will only be filled up with a significant condition contributing to the death but not related to the disease or condition causing it.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding apoptosis?
questions.solution:
The plasma membrane is intact in apoptosis.

Apoptosis is a pathway of programmed cell death and can occur due to physiological requirements (such as elimination of harmful self-reactive lymphocytes) or in pathological conditions (such as DNA damage or infection-induced).

The morphological features seen in apoptosis include:

  • cell shrinkage with dense and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • chromatin condensation is the most characteristic feature of apoptosis.
  • formation of cytoplasmic blebs followed by fragmentation into apoptotic bodies.
  • phagocytosis of apoptotic cells by macrophages.

The other options are all features of necrosis (type of cell death). It is characterized by leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes, local inflammation, and enzymatic degradation of the injured cell. The nucleus undergoes pyknosis (nuclear shrinkage and increased basophilia), karyorrhexis (fragmentation of pyknotic nucleus) and followed by karyolysis (chromatin fades).

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with complaints of sudden onset dramatic swelling of the face, lips, and tongue that is associated with pain. Which of the following drugs is likely to cause such a reaction?
questions.solution:
The history of a sudden onset of dramatic swelling associated with pain is suggestive of angioedema and perindopril is likely to cause this drug-induced reaction.

It can be drug-induced or hereditary. Drug-induced (such as ACE-inhibitor use as mentioned above) occurs due to delayed degradation of bradykinin. Hereditary angioneurotic edema occurs due to the deficiency of C1 inhibitor (which leads to an increase in bradykinin levels).

Angioedema has the same pathological process as urticaria, however, angioedema occurs due to vascular dilatation and edema involving the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissue. It has a characteristic dramatic swelling that is marked by more pain than pruritus.

Other options: 

Option A: Icatibant is a bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist that is used to reduce the swelling caused by hereditary angioedema.  

Option B: Ambrisentan is an endothelin receptor antagonist and is indicated for use in pulmonary arterial hypertension. Its most common side effect is peripheral edema. 

Option D: Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine type of calcium channel blocker that is used as an anti-anginal as well as an anti-hypertensive. Frequent side effects include palpitation, headache, drowsiness, ankle edema, etc.

questions.text: A man is diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma. What is the tumour marker used in the detection and management of his condition?
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is used in the detection and management of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

It is an oncofetal glycoprotein. Levels are elevated in the fetus, fall to lower levels after birth, and are elevated during pregnancy. It is synthesised by hepatocytes and endodermal-derived gastrointestinal tissues. The upper limit of normal for a healthy, nonpregnant adult is < 25 ng/ mL. 

Use of AFP in HCC:

  • Detection- Levels > 400 ng/mL with typical radiological findings are suggestive of HCC. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not elevated in fibrolamellar HCC.
  • Screening- the combination of AFP and ultrasound improves the efficacy of screening for HCC.
  • Prognosis- degree of AFP elevation corresponds to tumor size. A high rate of increase of AFP (AFP doubling time) is associated with a poor prognosis.
  • Monitoring- after complete resection, AFP levels should drop and remain less than 10 ng/ml. A postoperative rise in AFP is the best indicator of recurrent disease.

Alpha-fetoprotein is also produced by a variety of conditions, such as:

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Non-seminomatous germ cell tumours of the ovary and testis (e.g., yolk sac and embryonal carcinoma)
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Pregnancy and benign liver disease (e.g., viral hepatitis, cirrhosis)
  • Gastrointestinal tract tumours
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia (along with CEA)

Limitations of AFP include low sensitivity and specificity. It is not specific to HCC and can occur with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma and colorectal metastases.

questions.text: An old hypertensive male patient had a recent change in his anti-hypertensive drug. He now comes with complaints of dizziness on standing for few minutes. This started soon after taking the new drug. Which of the following class of drugs would have most likely caused this effect?
questions.solution:
The patient is having drug-induced orthostatic/postural hypotension and it is caused by the effect of alpha1 - selective receptor blocker.

Alpha1 receptor blockers, such as prazosin, cause a reduction of peripheral resistance as well as venous pooling of blood. This causes a decrease in venous return and cardiac output leading to a fall in blood pressure. Postural reflex causes marked postural hypotension which leads to syncope. This dizziness and fainting are known as the first dose effect and can be minimized by starting with a minimal dose and titrating it thereafter. Other side effects include reflex tachycardia, miosis, nasal congestion, and impotence. 

They are used as an antihypertensive agent and in benign hypertrophy of the prostate to decrease prostatic tone.

Other options:

Option A: Nonselective Beta receptor blockers, such as intravenous propranolol, is used to treat life-threatening arrhythmias, etc. It produces side effects such as bradycardia, exacerbating heart failure and chronic obstructive lung diseases, etc.

Option B: Alpha2 selective receptor agonists, such as apraclonidine, are used to reduce intraocular pressure and have minimal systemic effects. Side effects include dry mouth, sleepiness, and conjunctival hyperemia. 

Option C: Beta2 selective receptor agonists, such as salbutamol, act as a bronchodilator, vasodilators, and uterine relaxants. They have side effects such as muscle tremors, palpitations, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can lead to the measurement of a falsely elevated oxygen saturation in a pulse oximeter?
questions.solution:
Carboxyhemoglobinemia leads to a falsely elevated O2 saturation measurement in a pulse oximeter.

Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive measurement of the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin. It measures SpO2 (peripheral oxygen saturation). It works on the principle of Lambert-Beer law.

 A pulse oximeter probe is composed of a light emitter(two light-emitting diodes or LEDs) and a photodetector (measures the transmission of light from each LED). 660nm and 940nm are the two wavelengths commonly used. Red light (660nm) absorbs deoxygenated Hb and infrared (940nm) absorbs oxygenated Hb. The ratio of oxygenated Hb to deoxygenated Hb is calculated and converted to SpO2 by the processor.

Potential reasons for artifacts in measurement with a pulse oximeter are given in the table below:

Falsely increased O2 saturation value

 

  • Carboxyhemoglobinemia
  • Intra aortic balloon pump.

Falsely decreased O2 saturation value

 

  • Anemia
  • Hypotension(Blood pressure- BP<80 mm Hg)
  • Application of nail paint and henna
  • Venous pulsations
  • Methylene blue

In a patient with methemoglobinemia, the SpO2 approaches 85%, irrespective of the SaO2 (oxygen saturation of hemoglobin in the arterial blood).

Other options: 

Option A and Option C: Sulfhemoglobinemia and polycythemia have no significant effects on the measurement of oxygen saturation in a pulse oximeter.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with a BMI of 42 kg/m² with central obesity is scheduled to undergo bariatric surgery. As preparation for surgery, he is advised to follow a low-carbohydrate, low-fat, and moderate-protein meal, for two weeks. On follow-up, he is found to be non-compliant with the diet. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The next best step is psychological re-evaluation to address the underlying psychological blocks in a patient who is unable to comply with the diet.

Male individuals who are morbidly obese, especially those with central obesity, have large livers that make surgery impossible since the surgeon has to lift the liver to gain access to the stomach. A liver shrinkage diet helps to reduce the size of the liver. This allows mobility for the surgeon and increases the chances of a safer procedure.  

A liver shrinkage diet is one that has a low-carbohydrate, low-fat, and moderate-protein diet. It is started at least 2 weeks prior to the surgery and must be followed strictly by patients who had consented to the surgery. 

When there is no compliance, a psychological evaluation should be done.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of congestive heart failure is brought to casualty with complaints of sudden onset dyspnea. Bilateral fine basal crackles can be heard on auscultation. A bolus dose of injection furosemide was given.  Which of the following principles apply to the use of loop diuretics in this patient?
questions.solution:
Furosemide (which was given to the patient) acts on the principle of reduction of preload.

It comes under a class of drugs known as loop diuretics (high ceiling diuretics) and they are the diuretic of choice for reducing edema in heart failure. They act by inhibiting the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

This leads to a decrease in preload by increasing sodium and water excretion and improves ventricular function by reducing the circulatory volume. Intravenous furosemide also increases systemic venous capacitance.

The history of a patient who is known to have congestive heart failure being brought with complaints of sudden onset dyspnoea and bilateral fine basal crackles is suggestive of pulmonary edema. Heart failure is the inability of the heart to pump an adequate cardiac output for meeting physiological demands and can occur due to systolic/diastolic dysfunction. There is an elevation of filling pressure to compensate for the reduced cardiac output, but such an increase in stroke volume can produce congestive features similar to the scenario mentioned above. The main goal of drug therapy would be to relieve the congestive symptoms and restore cardiac function.

Other options:

Option B: In heart failure, low cardiac output causes activation of the neurohumoral regulation (renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system and sympathetic nervous system) that leads to an increase in sodium and water reabsorption as well as elevation of blood pressure (causing an increase in afterload). Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists act by the principle of reducing neurohumoral modulation.

Option C: Hydralazine act on the principle of reducing afterload by dilating resistance vessels. Reduction of afterload is beneficial in heart failure as it allows the heart to pump out blood against a lower resistance. 

Option D: Positive inotropic agents such as cardiac glycosides (Na+/K+ATPase inhibition - digoxin) and cAMP-dependant drugs (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dobutamine) act on the principle of increasing cardiac contractility. This is beneficial as it allows to produce enough force for adequate organ perfusion.

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency room with an acute attack of asthma. Intravenous hydrocortisone had to be administered. Which of the following is true regarding the mechanism of this drug?

choices.text: They augment the effect of beta agonists on airway smooth muscles

questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone is a corticosteroid and it augments the effect of beta-agonists on airway smooth muscles.

Corticosteroids do not have any bronchodilatory properties. However, it is efficient in acute asthma exacerbation as they decrease inflammatory response (inhibit the formation of inflammatory cytokines). They also potentiate the beta-agonist effect on bronchial smooth muscles (increases the transcription of β-2 receptor genes), as well as help in decreasing mucus production.

Hydrocortisone acts primarily as a glucocorticoid but also has significant mineralocorticoid activity and is used for replacement therapy in the case of acute/chronic adrenal insufficiency.

Highest mineralocorticoid activity in a drug that is clinically used is seen with fludrocortisone (aldosterone cannot be used clinically).

Least mineralocorticoid activity is seen with betamethasone and dexamethasone.

 

Highest glucocorticoid activity is seen with dexamethasone and betamethasone.

questions.text: A young man presented with fever, nausea, and abdominal discomfort. There is no tenderness, rigidity, or guarding elicited on abdominal examination. He is diagnosed with silent appendicitis on abdominal ultrasound. In this patient, which position would the appendix most likely be at?
questions.solution:
In this patient with silent appendicitis, the position that the appendix would most likely be at is in the retrocecal position. 

Appendicitis is the inflammation of the appendix occurring due to luminal obstruction. This obstruction can be due to lymphoid hyperplasia in children and fecoliths, foreign body, and neoplasia in adults. 

It classically presents as periumbilical colic, pain shifting to the right iliac fossa (RIF), anorexia, and nausea. The clinical signs include pyrexia, localized tenderness in the RIF, muscle guarding, and rebound tenderness. 

In retrocecal appendicitis, the above-mentioned classical signs may not be seen. This is because the inflamed appendix lies behind the caecum that is distended with gas. This prevents the pressure exerted by the palpating hand. Thus it is difficult to elicit tenderness on palpation in the right iliac region. Even deep pressure in the right lower quadrant may fail to elicit tenderness. Therefore, this type of appendicitis is called silent appendicitis.

However, in retrocecal appendicitis, psoas spam may be seen. This occurs due to the inflamed appendix being in contact with the psoas muscle. The patients usually lie with their right hip flexed to relieve the pain. When the ipsilateral hip is extended, pain is elicited, this is known as the psoas sign. 

Option A: Post ileal appendicitis is also a difficult diagnosis as there are minimal symptoms. Here the inflamed appendix lies behind the terminal ileum and due to this the pain may not shift and may sometimes be localised to the right of the umbilicus. However, the term 'silent appendix' is reserved for retrocecal appendix.

questions.text: A child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain. The stool microscopy image is given below. Eggs were non-bile stained and floated in the saturated salt solution. What is the most likely organism implicated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with a diarrheal illness and stool microscopy revealing characteristic eggs that are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution implicates the most likely organism to be Hymenolepis nana.

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the smallest tapeworm and man is the definite host. It occurs more commonly in children and the patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with its eggs. The adult worm resides in the small intestine. Patients are usually asymptomatic but in heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Pruritus may also be present due to an allergic response.

Stool microscopy reveals eggs that are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution. They have a thin colorless outer membrane and thread-like polar filaments.

A single dose of praziquantel (25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice for treatment.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana:

Other options:

Option A- The fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides are bile-stained and float in a saturated solution of salt water. They are round or oval in shape. The egg is surrounded by a thick smooth translucent shell having a coarsely mamillated translucent coat. In the middle of the egg, there is a large unsegmented ovum. It covers the entire area of the egg, except for the poles.

Unfertilized eggs do not float in the salt solution. They are long, narrow, and elliptical. They have thinner shells with irregular albumin coating and small atrophied ovum

Option B- The eggs of the Ancylostoma duodenale are non-bile stained and float in a saturated salt solution. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane and a segmented ovum containing 4-8 blastomeres. The space between the hyaline shell and the ovum is clear. 

Option D- Eggs of Trichuris trichuria are brown, bile stained, and float in a saturated salt solution. They are barrel-shaped, with a mucus plug on either end.

questions.text: Acute graft rejection is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Acute graft rejection is mediated by the T cells of the host.

Graft rejection is the process by which T lymphocytes and antibodies destroy tissue grafts. It can be classified into:

  • Hyperacute rejection: mediated by preformed antibodies that are specific for the antigens on the graft. 
  • Acute rejection can be divided into:
    • Acute cellular rejection is mediated by T cells. It causes direct damage to graft cells via CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes or causes indirect damage to the graft cells by CD4+ cells which secrete cytokines and induce inflammation.
    • Acute antibody-mediated rejection is mediated by antibodies that are produced after coming in contact with graft antigens. These antibodies bind to the graft vascular endothelium and activate the complement system causing graft failure.
  • Chronic rejection: slowly occurring damage to the graft that is caused by interstitial fibrosis and narrowing of graft blood vessels - graft arteriosclerosis.

 Other options:

Option B & D: Donor CD8+ and CD4+ T cells are implicated in graft-versus-host disease. Graft-versus-host disease is usually seen in hematopoeitic stem cell transplantation and occurs due to immunologically competent cells of the graft recognizing the recipient's HLA antigens as foreign and attacking them. In most conditions, this can be prevented by irradiating or treating the recipient with high doses of chemotherapy to destroy the immune system

Option C: As mentioned above, preformed antibodies mediate hyperacute graft rejection. Preformed antibodies are antibodies that are previously produced. They can be natural IgM antibodies to blood group antigens or antibodies to allogeneic major histocompatibility molecules that were induced by prior exposure (through blood transfusion, pregnancy, etc).

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes for an evaluation of blood pressure. He had a history of occasional flank pain and a family history of stroke in his father. His BP is 160/90 mm of Hg in both arms. Further evaluation with CT was done and shown below. Which of the following is the most common extrarenal manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of hypertension, family history of stroke, along with the CT findings showing bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts and liver cysts suggests a diagnosis of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The most common extrarenal manifestation seen in ADPKD is hepatic cysts.

ADPKD is caused by mutations in PKD1 and PKD2 which code for polycystin 1 and 2 respectively. They present incidentally with hypertension, abdominal mass or flank pain. Hematuria can also be present 

The most common extrarenal manifestation is hepatic cysts which are derived from the biliary epithelium. Other extra-renal manifestations of ADPKD:

  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Berry aneurysms
  • Colonic diverticula
  • Abdominal hernias
  • Mitral valve prolapse 

Management comprises of blood pressure control, antibiotics like trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, quinolones and chloramphenicol for 4-6 weeks, and analgesics. Surgical decompression for cysts may be done.

Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Other cystic diseases:

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of sore throat and low grade fever. Examination reveals cervical lymphadenopathy and grey white discharge-covered tonsils. Gram staining showed the following appearance. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the causative bacteria.

choices.text: Albert stain is used for diagnosis
The toxin acts via ADP ribosylation of EF-2
Iron level regulate the production of toxin

questions.solution:
A child presenting with a sore throat, cervical lymphadenopathy, grey-white discharged covered tonsils and gram stain showing gram-positive rods with clubbed ends, beaded appearance, and Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheria is not chromosome encoded, it is phage-encoded (tox gene). 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli. The organism can be cultured in Loeffler's serum slope and Tellurite blood agar.

The image below demonstrates C. diphtheriae in Albert's stain as green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) by ADP ribosylation responsible for protein synthesis and the iron level regulates the toxin production.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis and a bull neck. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils is characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxaemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria may manifest as diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

The image below shows the pseudomembrane over the tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Image below shows bull neck.

Treatment of diphtheria consist of administering diphtheria anti-toxin (20,000 - 100,000 units) and supplementing with antibiotics (penicillin and erythromycin).  

Related Pearl: Toxins that are coded by phage DNA - Mnemonic

B: Botulinum toxin C & D

C: Cholera toxin

D: Diphtheria toxin

E: E.coli(EHEC): Verocytotoxin (Shiga-like toxin)

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of recurrent bilious vomiting for the past few hours. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and weighed 2.7 kg. The mother was diagnosed with polyhydramnios during pregnancy. His abdominal X-ray shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette and the radiograph showing the presence of a double bubble sign are strongly suggestive of duodenal atresia. 

Duodenal atresia occurs due to failure of recanalization of the duodenal lumen during the gestational period. 

It is associated with various conditions including prematurity, Down’s syndrome, and maternal polyhydramnios. It is also associated with malformations of the hepatobiliary system such as the annular pancreas and biliary atresia.

In most cases, this duodenal obstruction is seen distal to the ampulla of Vater. Hence, infants present with bilious vomiting and features of intestinal obstruction soon after birth. On examination, the upper abdomen is distended with a scaphoid lower abdomen. 

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. Other investigations include abdominal radiographs that show the double-bubble sign. If distal air is present, an upper GI contrast study should be done to exclude midgut volvulus, which is a surgical emergency.

Definitive management is by surgical bypass of the obstruction as a side-to-side or transverse to longitudinal (diamond-shaped) duodenoduodenostomy. 

Other options:

Option A: In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis the abdominal radiograph will show a single enlarged gastric gas bubble. 

Option C: In jejunal atresia the abdominal radiograph will show a triple bubble sign.

Option D: In colonic atresia the abdominal radiograph will show multiple dilated bowel loops and differentiation between small and large bowel is not possible in neonates. A contrast enema study can confirm the diagnosis. The contrast does not pass proximally to the sigmoid colon.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A young farmer on a hike developed sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, and cough with salty phlegm. He was rushed to the emergency and stabilized. A CT scan showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing the 'water lily sign' is suggestive of a ruptured pulmonary hydatid cyst.

Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of dogs as definitive hosts and humans as intermediate hosts.

Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver. Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice.

The 2nd most common site is the lung, specifically the lower lobe of the right lung. Symptomatic patients present with cough with salty phlegm, fever, chest pain, and, hemoptysis. Silent cysts may present as an emergency due to rupture.

Computed tomography (CT) scan is accurate for detecting hydatid cysts. If there is disruption of the inner layers of the cyst, the following signs may be noted:

  • Water lily sign/ camalote sign - air-fluid level with a floating membrane (as shown below)
  • Rising sun sign/ serpent sign - a double-wall, dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at its bottom 
  • Empty cyst sign - when all the contents are removed 

Ultrasound is the most commonly used modality to diagnose echinococcus. The ultrasound of an active hydatid cyst shows multiple septations and a rosette or honeycomb appearance (as shown below)

Serology: Detection of serum anti-echinococcal antibodies using indirect hemagglutination (IHA), indirect immunofluorescence, ELISA, and slide latex agglutination test can be used to support the clinical diagnosis.

Treatment :

Pulmonary hydatid disease the mainstay of treatment is surgery. Various surgeries that may be performed are cystotomy, segmentectomy, pneumonectomy, etc. 

Hepatic hydatid disease in the early stages can be treated with puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR). Albendazole 4 days before the procedure, continued till 4 weeks afterward. Surgery is the treatment of choice when PAIR is not possible. The preferred surgical approach is pericystectomy. Since recurrence is common, pre and postoperative albendazole for 2 years is recommended.

Other options: 

Option B: A CT scan in acute pulmonary edema would show peribronchial opacities (batwing distribution) and thickening of interlobular septae in the lung base and apex (corresponds to Kerley lines on X-ray).

Option C: A CT scan in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is likely to show bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. 

Option D: A CT scan in acute mountain sickness (AMS) is likely to reveal patchy opacities, most often in the right middle lobe. The common presenting features are cyanosis, tachypnoea, tachycardia, and elevated body temperature. AMS may also lead to the development of non-cardiogenic high-altitude pulmonary edema.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: As a part of project work in radiology postings, you were asked to measure the biological risk of an individual i.e, the risk that a person will suffer health effects from exposure to radiation. Which of the following SI unit will be used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
The biological risk of an individual is measured by using the SI unit Sievert (Sv).

Different units of measure are used depending on what aspect of radiation is being measured

  • SI unit becquerel (Bq) or conventional unit curie is used for measuring the amount of radiation being emitted by a radioactive material.
  • SI unit gray (Gy) or conventional unit rad is used for measuring radiation dose absorbed by a person (that is, the amount of energy deposited in human tissue by radiation)
  • SI unit sievert (Sv) or conventional unit rem is used for measuring the biological risk of exposure to radiation (One Sv is equal to 100 rem).

Related Pearl: Important SI units for radiation

Radioactivity Curie Becquerel 1 curie = 3.7 x 1010 becquerel  
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg 1 roentgen = 2.58 × 10-4 C/Kg Amount of radiation absorbed in air.  
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy) 100 rad = 1 gray (or, 1 rad = 0.01 gray)  Amount of radioactive energy absorbed per unit gram of tissue or material.
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv) 100 rem = 1 sievert  Indicates potential danger to health.

questions.text: In a laboratory, a bacterium is seeded into a suitable liquid medium and incubated. Bacterial counts are made at intervals after inoculation and plotted in relation to time. A growth curve is obtained as shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the bacterial growth curve is not true?

choices.text: Adaptation to new environment occurs in phase A
Exotoxins are produced in phase C
Maximum size is in phase D
Cells stain uniformly in phase B

questions.solution:
The maximum size of the cell is towards the end of phase A, not D.

Phases of bacterial growth: 

  1. Lag phase (Marked as A)
    • Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media.
    • There is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
    • This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed
  2. Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as B)
    • In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time.
    • Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  3. Stationary phase (Marked as C)
    • Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products.
    • It is a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells forms equals the number of cells that die.
    • Sporulation occurs during this phase. 
    • Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
    • Cells are gram variable and show irregular staining due to the presence of intracellular storage granules.
  4. Phase of decline (Marked as D)
    • In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and action of autolytic enzymes.
    • Involution forms are common.

questions.text: A young woman came to the gynecologist with complaints of inability to conceive even after regular intercourse. Semen analysis of her partner was unremarkable. Hysterosalpingography revealed the following finding. Which of the following is incorrect about the condition?

choices.text: Functional rudimentary horn can present with hematometra
It occurs due to the failure of normal development of one Mullerian duct
MRI shows banana-like configuration of the uterine cavity
It is a class IV uterine malformation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of unicornuate uterus and it is not a class IV uterine malformation, but a class II Mullerian malformation according to the American Fertility Society. Class IV uterine malformation refers to a bicornuate uterus.

The history of infertility and hysterosalpingography(HSG) showing a spindle-shaped or banana-shaped uterine cavity deviated to the left with a patent left fallopian tube suggests a unicornuate uterus. It results from the failure of the normal development of one müllerian duct.  It is associated with increased spontaneous abortion, obstetric complications, and renal abnormalities.

On T2-weighted MR images, the unicornuate uterus demonstrates a curved, elongated uterus with tapering of the fundal segment off the midline. This is known as the banana-like configuration. Normal uterine zonal anatomy is maintained.

If a functional rudimentary horn is present, it usually demonstrates lower signal intensity and might contain endometrial tissue. They have increased chances of endometriosis and hematometra which can be an indication for excision.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an injury to his right eye during hammering and chiselling  at work. On examination, the image as seen below is observed. Which of the following statements about the management of this condition is true?

choices.text: MRI is the investigation of choice
Topical fluorescein identifies the entry wound

questions.solution:
The given history of hammering and chiseling along with the image showing black colored small foreign body (most likely a metal/ferruginous) is suggestive of intraocular foreign body(IOFB). Topical fluorescein identifies the entry wound is the true statement about this condition.

An IOFB can cause mechanical trauma, introduce infection, or undergoes dissociation with the consequent deposition of ions in the intraocular epithelial structures causing toxic effect and cell death.

Signs of a ferruginous IOFB include:

  • Anterior capsular cataract - seen as radially distributed iron deposits on the anterior lens capsule
  • Reddish-brown staining of the iris that may give rise to heterochromia iridis 
  • Pigmentary retinopathy

Investigations include

  • Topical fluorescein to identify an entry wound.
  • Gonioscopy and fundoscopy must be considered, taking care to minimize pressure on the eye.
  • CT with axial and coronal cuts is used to localize a metallic IOFB
  • MRI is contraindicated in the context of a metallic (specifically ferrous) IOFB.

Treatment entails prompt removal of the foreign body,

  • Magnetic removal is done for the removal of ferrous foreign bodies by the creation of a sclerotomy adjacent to the foreign body followed by the application of magnet cryotherapy to treat the retinal break. Forceps removal is used for non-magnetic foreign bodies and magnetic foreign bodies that cannot be safely removed with a magnet.
  • Intravitreal antibiotic prophylaxis is generally recommended as there is a high risk of ocular infection.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with lung cancer, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is dermatomyositis.

  • Age group 50-60 yrs

  • Association with internal malignancy (lung cancer)

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Eyelid erythema and edema
  • Nail fold changes
  • Gottron’s papules
  • Shawl sign - macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Mechanic’s hands
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic crampy abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, and tenesmus. Endoscopic examination revealed multiple, continuous lesions in the rectum and rectosigmoid without normal mucosa in between. The mucosa was red and the surface was fine granular like sandpaper. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is a mucosal disease that primarily involves rectum and extends proximally to involves some parts or whole of the colon. It can cause proctitis, proctocolitis, and colitis.

The involvement of the mucosa in UC is continuous without any normal mucosa in between. The various mucosal changes in different stages of UC are as follows: 

  • Mild disease - mucosa appears erythematous with fine granular surface resembling sandpaper
  • Severe disease - mucosa is hemorrhagic, edematous, and ulcerated
  • Long-standing disease - inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) due to epithelial regeneration.

Microscopically UC shows the following findings: 

  • Inflammation that is limited to mucosa and submucosa
  • Distortion of the crypt architecture with the following changes - 
    • Bifid and reduced number of crypts
    • Gap between the crypt base and muscularis mucosae is seen
    • Cryptitis and crypt abscesses - due to crypt invasion by neutrophils
  • Basal plasma cells and multiple basal lymphoid aggregates
  • Mucosal vascular congestion with edema and focal haemorrhage 
  • Mucosal inflammatory cell infiltration by neutrophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages 
  • Backwash ileitis with:
    • Villous atrophy and crypt regeneration
    • Increased neutrophil and mononuclear inflammation in the lamina propria
    • Patchy cryptitis and crypt abscesses

The below image shows pseudopolyps in ulcerative colitis.

The below image shows the histology of ulcerative colitis.

Clinical features of UC include: Crampy abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, passing of mucus in stools and tenesmus. 

Other options: 

Option A: Crohn's disease (CD) manifests as ileocolitis with right lower quadrant pain, palpable mass, fever, leukocytosis and weight loss. Other features like elevated ESR and CRP are seen. Endoscopy shows rectal sparing, fistulas, skip lesions and transmural inflammation. 

Option B: Diverticulitis is a close differential for Crohn's disease and is characterised by features such as fever, abdominal pain, mass, elevated ESR and leukocytosis. Endoscopic features are less appreciable in this condition than in CD.

Option C: Ischaemic colitis is typically characterised by sudden onset of left lower quadrant pain and bleeding per rectum following repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm or in a patient with cardiac/peripheral vascular disease.

questions.text: On routine examination of a neonate, the left eye was smaller in size and had a white pupillary reflex. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is persistent fetal vasculature.

The points in the clinical vingette pointing to this diagnosis are: 

  • White pupillary reflex in the left eye (unilateral leukocoria)
  • Smaller size of the left eye (microphthalmos) and 
  • Fundoscopy image showing a leash of vascularized fibrous tissue extending from the back of the lens to the optic nerve head

Persistent fetal vasculature was earlier known as persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous. It is the failure of primary vitreous and hyaloid vasculature to regress. This eventually leads to contraction and opacification combined with the hypoplasia of the posterior portion of the vascular meshwork.

It is unilateral in most of the cases. It is bilateral in cases that are associated with Trisomy 13, trisomy 22, Norries disease, and Walkers Warburg syndrome. 

Clinical Findings include:

  1. Leukocoria
  2. Microphthalmia 
  3. Shallow anterior chamber 
  4. Retrolental cataract 
  5. Esotropia 
  6. Angle-closure glaucoma 
  7. Dilated iris vessels 
  8. Persistent hyaloid artery 
  9. Vitreous hemorrhage
  10. Tractional retinal detachment 

Investigations:

  • CT scan of orbit to evaluate for the presence of calcification, which is present in retinoblastoma but absent in persistent fetal vasculature. 
  • B-scan ultrasonography to evaluate for retinal detachment when a cataract limits the view to the retina.

Treatment is done by pars plana lensectomy and vitrectomy to remove the retrolental fibrovascular membrane to prevent angle-closure glaucoma, followed by aggressive amblyopia therapy

Image below shows the falciform fold of detached dysplastic retina encircling the persistent hyaloid artery that extends from the optic nerve head to the retrolental mass.

Option A:

Retinoblastoma is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally. Retinoblastoma arises from the neurosensory retina. Leukocoria and squint are the most common presentation of retinoblastoma. It may also present as painful red eye, cataract, buphthalmos, proptosis(not microphthalmos) and pseudohypopyon.

Option B:

Coats' disease is idiopathic retinal telangiectasia that is generally of onset in early childhood. It presents as unilateral visual loss, leukocoria (because of exudative retinal detachment), and strabismus. It is associated with intraretinal and subretinal exudation. 

The image below shows total retinal detachment with subretinal exudate containing cholesterol crystals and a fibrous nodule in the posterior pole seen in Coats' disease.

Option C:

Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the inner layers of the retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium.

Fundus shows smooth and convex (usually round) retinal detachment. Shifting fluid will be seen in exudative type. Shaffer's sign - Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) is a feature of fresh retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought with a history of impaired vision. On examination, she has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris. The child has a normal IQ.  You suspect a disorder due to a deficiency of an enzyme tyrosinase. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism.

The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase again acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. Mutations in the tyrosinase gene lead to a complete inability to produce melanin.

Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. This manifests as white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-gray in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

Given below is an image of a young child with albinism showing white hair, skin, and pale iris:

Other options:

Option B: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to phenylketonuria. This defect results in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Infants appear normal at birth. They gradually develop hyperactivity, agitation, low IQ, and hypopigmentation (due to tyrosine deficiency), Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the body sweat, and urine.

Option C: The metabolic defect in alkaptonuria is a defective homogentisate oxidase. Patients typically will have dark urine or urine that turns dark on standing, ochronosis(bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue), arthritis, the pigment in the sclera, and ear cartilage.

Option D: Tyrosinemia type 2 (oculocutaneous type) is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability.

questions.text: During an ongoing cholecystectomy surgery, the surgeon instructs the intern to retract the liver. Which of the following instruments should be used?
questions.solution:
A Deaver retractor is used to retract the liver during surgery.

It is commonly used during cholecystectomy. The liver can still be damaged while using this retractor, so care must be taken to avoid using excessive force. Some surgeons prefer to reduce the risk of liver injury by placing an abdominal pack between the liver and retractor. 

Other options:

Option B - Doyen retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall and bladder during surgery. It is frequently used in lower segment cesarean sections to allow visualization of the lower uterine segment. 

Option C - Morris retractor is a large retractor used to give maximum exposure during abdominal surgeries. Because of its size, it can be used to improve the field of visibility by retracting a large number of structures. 

Option D - Czerny retractor has two ends. One end is a blade with a lip and the other has two prongs and is used to retract the ends of an incision. It is used to retract wounds like in open appendicectomy.
