questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea is found to have a blind-ended vagina. Breast development is adequate and stature is normal while pubic and axillary hairs are sparse. USG reveals absent uterus and the karyotype is 46, XY. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history and the examination findings suggest a diagnosis of androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome, formerly called testicular feminization syndrome, is a condition in which the end organs are unable to respond to the androgen. There is either a mutation or lack of the androgen cytosol receptor 

They are phenotypically and psychosocially a female. 

They present with primary amenorrhea or infertility. The breast is well developed with absent or sparse axillary and pubic hair. The vagina is short and blind. The uterus is absent. It is due to the normal production of antimullerian hormone by the Sertoli cells. Testes may be in either the labia or inguinal canal or intrabdominal area. Karyotype is 46, XY.

Other options:

Options A and C: Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome, has a karyotype of 46XX. Similar to androgen insensitivity syndrome, these females present with primary amenorrhea with normal breast development and an absent uterus. However, ovaries are present. 

Option D: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. Sex chromatin is negative. Female genital organs (vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries) are present.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient underwent screening for carcinoma of cervix. A Pap smear was done with the help of the instrument given below. What instrument was used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a Cusco speculum.

Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum that is used to visualize the cervix, perform Pap smears and colposcopic exams, and collect discharge from vaginal fornices for KOH smears. 

Other options:

Option B: Sim speculum is used to look for rectocele and cystocele. The speculum is applied against the anterior vaginal wall and slowly retracted out until a bulge appears (indicates a cystocele or rectocele).  It can also be used for visualization of the vaginal walls. The below image shows Sim's speculum.

 

Option C: Auvard speculum is used during vaginal hysterectomy. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall and has a weighted handle that makes it self-retaining(shown below).

Option D: Graves speculum is used to examine a parous woman who has relaxed and collapsing vaginal walls.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
Under which of the following clinical scenarios would parenteral opioids work as suitable postoperative analgesia?

1. A 70-year-old patient with a history of MI(myocardial infarction) who underwent a cardiac surgery

2. A 7-year-old patient with no co-morbidities who underwent surgery to repair a birth defect

3. A 30-year-old patient with severe obesity and obstructive sleep apnea who underwent surgery for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy
questions.solution:
Opioids can work as suitable postoperative analgesia for clinical scenarios 1 and 2. 

Clinical scenario 1: In a 70-year-old patient with a history of MI who underwent cardiac surgery opioids can work as suitable postoperative analgesia. Opioids remain the gold standard for pain control after cardiac surgery. Postoperative pain management after cardiac surgery is important as postoperative pain can activate the stress response causing increased heart rate, myocardial work, and myocardial oxygen consumption leading to myocardial ischemia.

Clinical scenario 2: In a 7-year-old patient with no co-morbidities who underwent surgery to repair a birth defect opioids can work as suitable postoperative analgesia. Opioids are used as analgesia in paediatric patients with moderate to severe pain. They are effective in abolishing pain and are associated with decreased chances of side effects like respiratory depression than in adults.

Clinical scenario 3: In a 30-year-old patient with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) who underwent surgery for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy opioids are not preferred as postoperative analgesics. This is because opioids can frequently cause respiratory depression and OSA patients are at an increased risk for postoperative respiratory arrest.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room after she sustained a fall on the outstretched hand. Examination reveals a supracondylar fracture of the humerus with injury to the structure marked as '?' in the given image. Which of the following muscle actions is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The muscle action most likely to be affected is the abduction of the thumb.

The structure marked as '?' in the given image is the median nerve in the cubital fossa which is very commonly injured in a supracondylar fracture. Injury to the median nerve affects the abduction of the thumb as this action is carried out by the abductor pollicis brevis muscle, which is innervated by the median nerve.

Identification of the median nerve:

  • In the cubital fossa and forearm- the median nerve is found medial to the brachial artery
  • In the hand- it passes through the carpal tunnel underneath the flexor retinaculum to innervate the muscles of the thenar eminence

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes with complaints of fatigue and weight loss. An image of her thyroid scan is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the thyroid scan showing a diffusely increased uptake of radioactive iodine and an enlarged size of the gland is suggestive of Grave’s disease.

A thyroid scan helps to differentiate between a hot nodule and a cold nodule. Thyroid nodules that absorb radioiodine are called hot nodules. These nodules produce excess thyroid hormones. Whereas, the thyroid nodules that do not absorb radioiodine are called cold nodules and they indicate non-functional nodules.

Appearance of thyroid scan in other thyroid disorders:

Multinodular goiter demonstrates multiple areas of both increased and decreased uptake of radioiodine, indicating the presence of both functioning and nonfunctioning nodules.

Toxic adenoma demonstrates a focal area of increased uptake of radioiodine.

Thyroiditis shows a decreased uptake of radioiodine due to follicle damage.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

questions.text: A 46-year-old female patient complains of hot flushes, inability to concentrate, and sleep disturbances. Which among the following would help in the prediction of her approaching menopause?

choices.text: A rise in inhibin B level
A rise in anti-Mullerian hormone level

questions.solution:
A rise in FSH level helps in the prediction of approaching menopause.

Predictors of approaching menopause are:

  • A fall in the level of inhibin B. This causes a rise in the FSH level 
  • Low ovarian reserve and low antral follicular count are suggested by a fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone. 
  • A rise in FSH and a more than normal LH level 

FSH levels are studied on days 2-5 after the last menstrual period. This helps to identify the premenopausal stage.

Menopause is the permanent cessation of ovarian function, thereby, leading to permanent amenorrhea. It usually occurs between 45 - 50 years, but the average age of menopause is 47 years old and is confirmed after 12 months of amenorrhoea. Some of the features include:

  • Hot flushes which are transient heat sensations occurring in the face and neck and lasting for 2-5 minutes followed by sweating.
  • Insomnia, headache
  • Dyspareunia
  • Irritability, depression, tiredness
  • Lack of concentration and lack of memory

Note: Perimenopause is 3-4 years preceding menopause and is followed by 1 year of amenorrhoea.

questions.text: Given below are substances matched with potential consequences of chronic abuse. Identify the wrong match.
questions.solution:
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) does not produce physical dependence.

Other substances of abuse that do not produce physical dependence include cocaine, cannabis, and amphetamines. The potential consequences of chronic abuse of LSD are flashbacks or bad trips. 

Physical dependence: Frequent exposure to the drug leads to an altered neurophysiological state. This is characterized by the emergence of tolerance to the drug as well as withdrawal symptoms when the chronically abused drug is discontinued.

Other options:

Option A: Korsakoff syndrome is seen with chronic alcohol abuse. It is characterized by anterograde and retrograde amnesia, disorientation, and confabulation (describing fabricated experiences to fill gaps in memory).

Option B: Amotivational syndrome is seen with chronic cannabis abuse. It is characterized by lethargy and reduced interest in day-to-day activities. 

Option D: Tactile hallucinations seen with cocaine abuse. The affected individual percieves small insects creeping on the skin, giving rise to itching sensations. These hallucinations are termed cocaine bugs or Magnan's symptoms.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing preanesthetic evaluation. He is seated upright with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation. The image of the mouth is given below. Which class does he belong to according to the modified Mallampati score?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the faucial pillars, uvula, and the soft palate are all visible. Therefore, this patient is classified as class I according to the modified Mallampati score. 

The modified Mallampati score is used to assess the difficulty of endotracheal intubation in a patient.

The patient is seated upright with the neutral position of the head, open mouth, and protruded tongue and the patient is asked to not speak. The classification is done based on the visibility of structures through the mouth in this position. The Mallampati classification modified by Samsoon and Young is as follows:

  • Class I: Faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate are visualized.
  • Class II: The base of the uvula, fauces and soft palate are visualized.
  • Class III: Only the soft palate and base of uvula are visualized.
  • Class IV: Only the Hard palate is visualized.

Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate a more difficult laryngoscopy and subsequent intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text:
A patient presented with severe fatigue and a history of recurrent infections. Abdominal examination showed no features of organomegaly. His CBC showed pancytopenia and bone marrow aspirate gave a dry tap. Marrow biopsy shows a markedly hypocellular bone marrow. What is the likely diagnosis?

CBC - complete blood count
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with pancytopenia, dry tap on bone marrow aspiration, and marrow biopsy showing markedly hypocellular bone marrow are suggestive of aplastic anemia.

Aplastic anemia is a chronic primary hematological failure that results in pancytopenia. Causes of this condition include:

  • Idiopathic 
  • Idiosyncratic reactions to drugs such as chloramphenicol
  • Infections such as viral hepatitis
  • Inherited defects such as Fanconi anemia or inherited telomerase defects.

The pathology is thought to be due to damaged stem cells producing progeny that express neoantigens which cause an autoimmune reaction or due to the production of a clonal population with decreased proliferating capacity.

Clinically, the patients present with features of pancytopenia such as fatigue, recurrent infections, and petechiae and ecchymoses. Characteristically, splenomegaly will be absent.

A peripheral smear will show reticulocytopenia. Bone marrow aspirates often give a 'dry tap' which means that they yield little material. Thus, a marrow biopsy would show a markedly hypocellular marrow that is devoid of hematopoietic cells (some fat cells, fibrous stroma, and scattered lymphocytes or plasma cells remain).

Other options:

Option A: Megaloblastic anemia is caused by folate or vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia). Peripheral smear shows characteristic macro-ovalocytic red cells that appear hyperchromic, hypersegmented nuclei in neutrophils, and reticulocytopenia. Marrow is markedly hypercellular due to an increase in the number of hematopoietic precursors.

Option B: Iron deficiency anemia is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. Peripheral smears show microcytic hypochromic red blood cells. Bone marrow shows an increase in erythroid progenitors. A significant diagnostic finding is an absence of stainable iron in macrophages which is assessed by Prussian blue stain on aspirated marrow smears.

Option D: Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a primary marrow disorder that causes the suppression of erythroid progenitors only. One cause is acute parvovirus B19 infection which may lead to an aplastic crisis in patients who already had underlying hemolytic anemia. The hallmark of PRCA, in an otherwise normal marrow, is the absence of erythroblasts.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman is practicing intermittent fasting in order to lose weight. She fasts every day for 13 hours. During this period of fasting, which of the following is least likely?
questions.solution:
In this woman, practicing intermittent fasting for 12 hours, significant ketogenesis is least likely. Significant amount of ketone body synthesis occurs during prolonged starvation(>3 days).

A decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is seen in the fasting state, in which there is the activation of gluconeogenesis, increased glycogenolysis, thus leading to decreased glycogen storage and inhibition of glycolysis.

Metabolic process

Fasting state

Fed state

Increased

Decreased

Glycogenolysis

Increased

Decreased

Increased

Decreased

The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting i.e; 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal, following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 13 hours will be liver glycogenolysis. Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days.

In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs.

After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

questions.text: According to the sustainable development goals, by 2030, neonatal mortality and under 5 mortality should be reduced to _____ (per 1000 live births) and ______ (per 1000 live births) respectively:
questions.solution:
In sustainable development goals, target 3.2 aims to reduce neonatal mortality to 12/1000 live births and under 5 mortality to 25/1000 live births, by the year 2030.

There are 17 global goals and 169 targets set for 2030 as part of the official Sustainable Development Goals of the Agenda 2030. Goals related to health are:

  • Goal 2- Reduce hunger, improve food security and improve nutrition
  • Goal 3- Ensure healthy lives and promote well being
  • Goal 6- Availability and management of water and sanitation

Important features of Goal 3 are (by 2030):

  • Reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births
  • End preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, and reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births
  • End the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, etc.
  • Reduce mortality from non-communicable diseases and improve mental health
  • Prevent and treat substance abuse
  • Achieve universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programs
  • Reduce deaths and illnesses from environmental pollution
  • Achieve universal health coverage for healthcare services.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient complained of excessive daytime sleepiness and tiredness throughout the day. He also had episodes where he felt losing his strength in his muscles and falling to the ground, especially when he is stressed or laughing. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of narcolepsy. The finding mentioned here is called cataplexy. It is a sudden, brief loss of voluntary muscle tone, with partial or no loss of consciousness. It is triggered by strong emotions such as laughter or stress, commonly associated with narcolepsy. 

Narcolepsy is a type of hypersomnolence disorder. Symptoms commonly appear in the second decade of life. A characterized by a tetrad of symptoms is seen:

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness where there are recurrent episodes of irrepressible sleepiness occurring in a day for more than 3 months. 
  2. Cataplexy- It is associated with deficiency of the neurotransmitter hypocretin. Sudden loss of muscle tone may lead to jaw drop, head drop, weakness of the knees, paralysis of skeletal muscles, or collapse. 
  3. Sleep paralysis is where patients report being unable to move their muscles while waking up in the morning, even though they are conscious and awake. 
  4. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations where auditory or visual hallucinations are vivid, dream-like, occurring at the onset of sleep or while waking up and cause frightening for a brief period of time. 

Occurrence of REM sleep within 10 minutes of sleep onset (sleep-onset REM periods) is also seen in these patients. 

Modafinil, an a1-adrenergic receptor agonist, is used to reduce the number of sleep attacks and improve psychomotor performance. Besides this, tricyclic antidepressants or SSRIs are found effective in eliminating cataplexy. Psychosocial therapy like sched­uled naps, lifestyle adjustment, counseling, etc can also be employed. 

Other options:

Option A- Catalepsy, also known as waxy flexibility is a condition in which a person maintains abnormal body posi­tions for very long durations. This is seen in severe cases of catatonic schizophrenia.

Option C- Gegenhalten or paratonic rigidity is seen in frontal lobe lesions. It leads to an involuntary increase in resistance to passive movements.  

Option D- Negativism is when a person opposes or resists any effort to be moved or does the opposite of what is asked. They are seen in catatonic schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of erratic behaviour in school. He is unable to sit still in class for more than a few minutes at a time, pushes other children, never waits for his turn, and disturbs his classmates. His parents say that he is hyperactive at home as well. The language and milestones are appropriate for his age. Any of the following drugs can be used in his condition except:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above of a child with inattention and hyperactivity points towards a diagnosis of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Tricyclic antidepressants like desipramine are not recommended in the treatment of ADHD due to potential cardiac arrhythmia effects. There have been reports of sudden death in children with ADHD being treated with desipramine.

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists).

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuro­ psychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually rec­ognized between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may disappear in some cases, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to antisocial behavior, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

questions.text: A 49-year-old obese male patient presented with complaints of daytime tiredness, and frequent awakenings. Investigations were done and he was diagnosed with central sleep apnea. Which of the following is true regarding his condition?

choices.text: It is due to decreased sensitivity to pCO2
It is not associated with Cheyne-Stokes breathing
Opioid medication can be a risk factor
Congestive heart failure is not a risk factor

questions.solution:
The true statement about central sleep apnea is that opioids can be a risk factor for this condition.

Central sleep apnea is caused by increased sensitivity to pCO2 (option A). Thus changes in pCO2 levels during sleep lead to an unstable breathing pattern that manifests as hyperventilation alternating with apnea. A crescendo-decrescendo breathing pattern known as Cheyne-Stokes respiration (option B) is seen.

 

Risk factors for CSA:

  • Heart failure (option D)
  • Opioid medications 
  • Hypoxia (e.g., breathing at a high altitude)
  • Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) at high pressures (this condition is referred to as complex sleep apnea)

CSA itself can be an independent risk factor for heart failure and atrial fibrillation and is an early marker of subclinical myocardial dysfunction.

Treating the cause and supplemental oxygen may be useful.

questions.text: Exhumation of a body is done as per the magistrate's order for a legal case requiring age estimation. The skeletal remains found out the skull shown below. The marked suture is fused completely. What was the likely age of the person when he died?
questions.solution:
In the given image of the skull, the suture highlighted in the red colour is a completely fused sagittal suture. So the likely age of the person when he died is 50-60 years.

Age estimation using skull suture closure is an unreliable method. However among all the sutures sagital suture is considered to be the most useful in estimating the age. This is followed by lambdoid and then the coronal suture in the decreasing order of reliablility. 

Skull suture closure occus earlier in men compared to women. Also endocranial fusion occurs before ectocranial fusion.

questions.text: A concerned woman on post-natal day 2 presented with complaints of reddish vaginal discharge. Her vitals were stable and there were no associated signs of sepsis. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lochia rubra which is seen during puerperium.

During early puerperium, sloughing of the decidual tissue causes vaginal discharge that is known as lochia. For the first few days, it is associated with blood, hence red in color and is known as lochia rubra. It contains erythrocytes and shredded decidua.

After 3 or 4 days, it becomes pale and is referred to as lochia serosa (option B).

After 10 days, it becomes white or yellow in color due to a mixture of leukocytes and reduced fluid content. This is known as lochia alba (option C)

questions.text: You are an intern working in the Opthalmology department. Your professor who is examining  a male patient calls you to observe the findings as shown below. Administering which of the following drugs would have caused this?
questions.solution:
A mydriatic agent can cause the above finding of a festooned pupil that is suggestive of anterior uveitis. 

A festooned pupil is an irregularly shaped pupil that is seen when segmental posterior synechiae are formed. When mydiatrics are administered in this condition, there is dilatation of the pupillary portions that have not yet adhered to the lens, leading to festooned pupil.

Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the anterior portion of the uveal tract consisting of the iris and anterior ciliary body. It is most often associated with HLA-B27 positive conditions such as Behcet disease and sarcoidosis. Patients usually present with ocular pain, circumcorneal congestion, photophobia, etc.

Anterior uveitis is characterized by: 

  • Koeppe nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at the pupillary margin
  • Busacca nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at collarette 
  • Keratic precipitates (KP) - proteinaceous deposits on the corneal endothelium. These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. Types of KP's include - 
    • Mutton fat type - seen in granulomatous uveitis
    • Granular type - seen in non-granulomatous uveitis
  • Aqueous flare - diffuse inflammation with exudates in the anterior chamber. It is the earliest sign of non-granulomatous uveitis

The exudates can also pour out into the posterior chamber causing the iris to adhere posteriorly to the lens. When the adhesions organize to become fibrous, it becomes firm and is known as posterior synechiae.  A dilating/mydriatic agent causes the remaining pupillary portions, that have not become attached, to dilate irregularly giving the classic appearance mentioned above. 

When pupils have become adhered 360 degrees, it is known as ring synechiae. This prevents aqueous humor drainage -seclusio pupillae- and pushes the iris forward, forming an iris bombe with an increase in intraocular pressure.

Cycloplegics such as atropine and homatropine and steroids are the mainstay of treatment. Complications such as complicated cataracts, secondary glaucoma, and phthisis bulbi (soft and atrophic eye) can be seen. 

Drugs that worsen anterior uveitis and thus should be avoided are: Prostaglandin analogs, metipranolol, and brimonidine.

questions.text: A patient with chronic hepatitis C presents with skin rash and joint pains for the past 10 days. He also gives a history of hematuria. Investigations show low C4 levels and positive rheumatoid factor. Which of the following will be abnormal in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, along with chronic hepatitis C, point to a diagnosis of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Serum cryoglobulin levels will be abnormal in this condition.

Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in colder temperatures, leading to a vasculitis syndrome called cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. This syndrome is strongly associated with hepatitis C infection and occurs due to an aberrant immune response to hepatitis C antigens.

Patients present with cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, and glomerulonephritis. Laboratory findings show circulating cryoprecipitates. Rheumatoid factor is positive in most patients, and complement levels are low.  

Other options:

Option A: ANCA antibodies are positive in granulomatous vasculitis like granulomatosis with polyangiitis(Wegener's syndrome) and Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Option C: Anti-CCP antibodies are positive in cases of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are positive in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic demised from sudden cardiac death.  During the autopsy, the heart is enlarged, heavy, and flabby. A cardiac histopathologic image is shown below.  Which of the following cardiac conditions must he have developed?
questions.solution:
The history of alcoholism and sudden cardiac death with cardiac histopathology showing myocytes with ninja star-like nuclei suggests that the man must have developed dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).

Dilated cardiomyopathy is the morphological and functional progressive cardiac dilatation and systolic dysfunction. To be considered DCM, the heart should not have any primary valvular abnormalities.

Causes of DCM include:

  • Genetic factors (familial in 50% of cases)
  • Direct toxic effects of alcohol and its metabolites (acetaldehyde)
  • Previous history of viral myocarditis
  • Exposure to cardiotoxic drugs such as cobalt
  • Iron overload  (hemochromatosis)
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy
  • Catecholamine effect causing Takotsubo cardiomyopathy 

Clinical features include the slow progression to congestive heart failure and symptoms and signs related to it. Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmias or progressive cardiac failures can occur. 

Histopathologically, myocytes will show hyperchromatic and highly distorted ninja star-like nuclei (non-specific finding).

Other options: 

Option A: Pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardium and is caused by infectious or immunologically mediated agents. Histologically, there can be a mild inflammatory infiltrate in the epipericardial fat. 

Option B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic disorder causing myocardial hypertrophy. This leads to a poorly compliant ventricle which causes abnormal diastolic filling as well as intermittent ventricular outflow obstruction. Histopathologically, there is massive myocytic hypertrophy and myofiber disarray.

Option D: Myocarditis is the inflammation of the myocardium that is primary in nature or caused by an infectious organism. Histopathologically, it is characterized by interstitial inflammatory infiltrates that are associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes.

  • Missense mutation
  • Most common mutation: Beta-chain of myosin

  • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy
  • Diastolic dysfunction
  • Systolic function normal
  • On Echocardiography:
    1. Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm
    2. Systolic anterior motion of left leaflet
    3. Banana shaped left ventricle

questions.text: A farmer presented with a painless swelling over his left foot with multiple sinuses discharging pus and black granules. Pus from the sinuses was sent for investigations and the microscopic appearance of the causative agent is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario as well as the above image showing darkly stained fungal hyphae on microscopy suggests a likely diagnosis of eumycetoma.

Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia, and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It is, therefore, commonly known as maduramycosis or madura foot. It is caused by various types of fungi (eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetes). 

Eumycetoma is caused by fungi like Madurella mycetomatis. It usually enters the body through minor trauma. The disease usually begins as a small subcutaneous swelling of the foot. It enlarges and burrows into the deeper tissues and tracks to the surface as multiple sinuses discharging seropurulent fluid containing hard, black granules. 

Examination and culture of the granules and biopsy of the lesion help in ascertaining the diagnosis. Diagnosis is confirmed by isolating Madurella mycetomatis on culture on Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA).

The image below shows a eumycetoma of the foot:

Eumycetoma is treated by surgical debridement of the lesion and administering antifungals for 18-24 months(even in the absence of clinical or laboratory evidence of infection).

Other options:

Option A: Botryomycosis is a mycetoma-like lesion caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B: Sporotrichosis is a localized skin and subcutaneous tissue infection caused by Sporothrix schenkii. A papule is seen at the site of inoculation followed by the development of similar lesions along the lymphatic channels. Histopathology shows a mixed granulomatous and pyogenic reaction, and tiny oval or cigar-shaped yeasts.

The image below shows a picture of Actinomycetes on Gram staining:

Option D: Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It commonly presents as warty, cutaneous nodules resembling the florets of cauliflower. Histologically, the lesions contain the fungus, which is seen as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae, known as sclerotic bodies. The image below shows sclerotic bodies, seen on histopathology examination.

questions.text: A  farmer was presented with a suppurative wound on his arm and respiratory symptoms. Later he was diagnosed with melioidosis. The causative organism of this disease belongs to which category of bioterrorism agents as classified by CDC?
questions.solution:
Melioidosis is caused by burkholderia pseudomallei and it belongs to category B agent of bioterrorism as classified by CDC.

Melioidosis is also known as Whitmore's disease. The incubation period can be as short as 2–3 days,  months, or years. A suppurative wound infection can occur at the inoculation site which may lead to sepsis and multi-organ involvement. It is presented as fever with leukocytosis. Chest x-ray shows upper lobe consolidation. Gram staining with Wright's or methylene blue shows a gram-negative organism.

questions.text: A patient has been admitted with a history of infection with the H1N1 strain. Which of the following drugs acts as a neuraminidase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Oseltamivir is a commonly used anti-influenza drug and acts by inhibiting the neuraminidase enzyme of the influenza virus.

The neuraminidase enzyme is required for the release of progeny virions from the infected cell. Oseltamivir acts against type A and B, H5N1, and H1N1 strains of infection. Influenza virus is an RNA virus and the majority of the infections and pandemics are caused by type A, while type B often causes sporadic seasonal cases.

Other anti-influenza drugs that work under the same mechanism as neuraminidase enzyme inhibitors are zanamivir and peramivir. 

Other options:

Option A: Amantadine is a tricyclic amine drug that acts as an inhibitor of M2 protein (prevents uncoating of viral genome onto infected cell) and can only act on influenza A.

Option B: Rimantadine is a methyl derivative of amantadine and works under the same mechanism with a longer time of action. However, it shows cross-resistance with amantadine and is presently not in use. 

Option D: Entecavir is a guanosine nucleoside analog that is the first-line option for treating chronic hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the procedure shown below?

choices.text: Compression/distraction at fracture site enhances osteogenesis
The rate of compression or distraction is 2 mm per day
K wire is required for this procedure
Nerve palsy is a complication of the procedure

questions.solution:
The above radiograph depicts the lengthening of the limb using Ilizarov apparatus. The rate of compression/distraction is 1 mm per day, not 2 mm per day.

Ilizarov's technique is based on the principle of distraction osteogenesis. This is the mechanical induction of new bone which occurs between bony surfaces that are gradually pulled apart. Compression and distraction at the fracture site enhance osteogenesis.

A careful fracture of the bone is performed, followed by a short wait. The young callus formed is gradually distracted using a circular or unilateral external fixator system called a ring fixator. Transfixing thin Kirschner wires (K-wires) are the key components of the Ilizarov fixator regarding its axial stiffness. This affects the mechanobiological environment in which the bone heals.

Distraction or compression can be applied by twisting nuts on the fixation system at the fracture or corticotomy site. Distraction or compression is carried out at the rate of 1 mm per day. 

The uses of Ilizarov's apparatus are as follows:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Non-union
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis - as it offers the possibility of liberal excision of bone
  • Arthrodesis - crushing articular surfaces can stimulate union between opposing bones

Disadvantages of this technique include pin tract infection, nerve palsy, and joint stiffness.

The below images show the Ilizarov apparatus and an illustration of distraction osteogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the needle shown below and the procedure it is used for?

choices.text: It is used in obstetric anesthesia
It causes rapid onset of anesthesia within 1-2 minutes
It is used along with catheter for continuous infusions for pain management
The blunt tip needle prevents accidental dural puncture

questions.solution:
The image shown is the 18 G Tuohy needle, which is used in epidural anesthesia. It does not cause rapid onset of anesthesia, instead has a slower onset of action ranging from 10-20 minutes compared to spinal anesthesia which has a relatively faster onset of action.

Identification points:

  • It has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that helps to prevent accidental dural puncture.
  • The needle shaft is marked in 1-cm intervals so that the depth of insertion can be identified.

It is used in obstetric anesthesia, segmental blocks, and chronic pain management.

Image below shows epidural anesthesia set with Touhy's needle and epidural catheter:

 

Other epidural needles: Crawford needle (straight needles without a curved tip): has a greater incidence of dural puncture.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy sustained a wound in the forearm while playing on the ground. The wound was bleeding for some time and stopped after the formation of a blood clot. The type of homeostasis mechanism acting in this scenario is also seen in all the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the process of blood clotting which is an example of positive feedback. This is also seen in all the other conditions except pulmonary hyperventilation which is an example of negative feedback.

Pulmonary hyperventilation is a negative feedback mechanism where a stimulus (like increased CO2 in blood) leads to a response- pulmonary hyperventilation which reduces the original stimulus (blood CO2 level decreases) and brings back the system to its original state.

Positive feedback is the type of feedback in which the initial stimulus triggers a response that deviates further from the original state. Negative feedback is a system where the initial stimulus triggers a response that restores the original state. 

Most mechanisms in our body follow the negative feedback mechanism which helps to maintain homeostasis. For example, an increase in gastric acids leads to a decrease in gastric secretion.

Positive feedback is seen in a few conditions where a physiological process has to propagate itself. These include:

  • Childbirth
  • Blood clotting
  • LH surge
  • Action potential

Positive feedback may sometimes lead to vicious cycles, eg. shock.

questions.text: A  primigravida patient was admitted with complaints of epigastric pain, headache, and visual symptoms. Her blood pressure was 170/100mm Hg, and proteinuria 3+ was present. Her gestational age is 36 weeks. It was decided to start Pritchard's regimen, What is the maintenance dose of magnesium sulfate?
questions.solution:
The woman has developed preeclampsia which is evident by the given clinical scenario and findings and according to Pritchard's regimen, the maintenance dose of magnesium sulfate is 5g intramuscularly, 4 hourly in alternate buttocks.

Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder with unknown aetiology and characterised by blood pressure of >140/90 mm hg or proteinuria in a woman who was previous normotensive and non-proteinuric. 

Magnesium sulfate regimens in the management of pre-eclampsia:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4-6 g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2g/h IV infusion

It is continued for 24 hours after the last seizure or delivery whichever is later.

Repeat injections of magnesium sulfate are given only if:

  • Knee jerks are present
  • Urine output > 30 mL/h
  • Respiratory rate > 12/minute
The therapeutic level of serum magnesium is 4–7 mEq/L.

 Magnesium toxicity can be suspected if there is 

  1. Loss of deep tendon reflexes at serum Mg > 7 mEq/L
  2. Respiratory depression at serum Mg > 10 mEq/L and 
  3. Cardiac arrest at serum Mg > 25 mEq/L.

Magnesium toxicity is managed by stopping magnesium therapy after which serum magnesium and creatinine levels are estimated. Then, intravenous calcium gluconate 10 ml is injected.

Magnesium sulfate is also used for the management of torsades de pointes in pregnancy.

questions.text: A small for gestational age newborn was brought to the OPD. On examination, small palpebral fissures, smooth philtrum and microcephaly were noted. His echocardiogram revealed a ventricular septal defect. These features are caused due to consumption of which of the following substances by the mother during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
These features are caused due to consumption of alcohol by the mother during pregnancy. The given clinical scenario is fetal alcohol syndrome. 

Fetal alcohol syndrome is caused by ethanol which is a potent teratogen. The features of fetal alcohol syndrome are:

  • Growth restriction before and/or after birth
  • CNS dysfunction - microcephaly, mental retardation, abnormal neurobehavioral development like attention deficit with hyperactivity
  • Facial anomalies - small palpebral fissures, thin vermilion border of the upper lip, smooth philtrum
  • Cardiac anomalies - Ventricular septal defect, Atrial septal defect .

Other options:

Option A: Maternal use of phenytoin causes fetal hydantoin syndrome, characterized by an upturned nose, mild facial hypoplasia, long upper lip with a thin vermilion border and distal digital hypoplasia. 

Option B: Maternal use of opioids causes neonatal abstinence syndrome which presents with hypertonia, irritability, poor sucking reflex and seizures. 
 
Option C: Maternal use of lithium leads to Ebstein's anomaly. It causes the apical displacement of the tricuspid valve resulting in tricuspid regurgitation and right atrial enlagrment. Chest X-ray showing a box-shaped heart is shown below:

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with a painless swelling in front of the ear as given below. On examination, his left earlobe was lifted and the curtain sign was positive. What is the mainstay treatment of this condition where only the superficial lobe is involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of parotid pleomorphic adenoma and the mainstay treatment in this condition is superficial parotidectomy. 

Pleomorphic adenomas are benign mixed neoplasms presenting as a painless and slow-growing swelling that lifts the ear lobe. This swelling cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone and is known as the curtain sign. 

Sometimes it may undergo malignant transformation. The malignant form is known as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma. Signs of malignant transformation include:

  • A rapid increase in size
  • Pain and ulceration
  • Facial nerve involvement (LMN)
  • Lymph node involvement
  • Restricted jaw movements

Surgical intervention is done via parotidectomy. If only the superficial lobe is involved superficial parotidectomy (removal of the superficial lobe) is done. 

If both lobes are involved, total conservative parotidectomy (both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved) or total radical parotidectomy (both lobes and facial nerve are removed - malignant cases) can be done. 

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland

questions.text: Name the surgery for which the following set of instruments is used.
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments is used in tonsillectomy.

Instrument 1: Boyle-Davis mouth gag is used for opening the mouth and depressing tongue for doing surgery. Various sized tongue blades are used along with it according to the age of the patient.

Uses of Boyle Davis mouth gag are:

  • Pharyngoplasty
  • Tonsillectomy 
  • Surgery of soft palate
  • Adenoidectomy
  • Excision of angiofibroma

Instrument 2: Draffin’s bipod

Each pod has four rings. They can be assembled to vary the height at which the tongue blade of the Boyle-Davis mouth gag can be suspended. The lower end of each pod can be placed in one of the several depressions in Magauran’s plate (vide infra).

Instrument 3: Denis Browne’s tonsil holding forceps is used for holding the tonsil during tonsillectomy by dissection method.

Instrument 4: Tonsil dissector and anterior pillar retractor:

One end is used to dissect the tonsil and the other end to retract the anterior pillar to inspect the tonsillar fossa for any bleeding point.

Instrument 5: Eves’ tonsil snare is used for tonsillectomy. After the tonsil has been dissected till its lower pole, snare is passed round the tonsil to engage the pedicle and then firmly closed. It crushes and cuts the pedicle thereby minimizing bleeding. Wire used in snare is number 25 SWG.

Instrument 6: Waugh’s tonsil dissection forceps is used for incision in mucous membrane and dissection of the tonsil.

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased visual acuity 3 months after cataract surgery. On examination, the finding seen in the image below was observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history mentions decreased visual acuity 3 months post-cataract surgery and the image shows Elschnig pearls pattern. So the likely diagnosis is posterior capsular opacification. 

Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 


Posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It becomes indicated when the patient is symptomatic. 

Other options: 

Option A: Retinal detachment is an uncommon complication of cataract surgery. It may occur in people with pre-operative risk factors such as retinal breaks, high myopia, or due to vitreous loss during surgery. Retinal detachment is treated by pars plana vitrectomy.

Option C: Postoperative endophthalmitis is a complication of cataract surgery causing acute and severe intraocular inflammation. Patients complain of pain and visual loss. Clinically, there is eyelid swelling with conjunctival injection, Marcus-Gunn pupil, hypopyon, and vitiritis. Intravitreal antibiotics are the key to management. Other treatment modalities include oral antibiotics and steroids, and pars plana vitrectomy. 

Option D: Sunset syndrome is the inferior subluxation of the implanted intraocular lens (IOL). Malpositioning such as this is an uncommon complication of cataract surgery. 

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A young rice farmer presented with a high-grade fever, diarrhea, seizures, and vomiting. He is also found to have nuchal rigidity and signs of raised intracranial pressure. The physician suspects an illness transmitted by the mosquito shown below.  Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Pond herons can act as hosts

questions.solution:
The rice farmer presenting with features of acute encephalitis is likely to have Japanese encephalitis. Man is the incidental dead-end host.

The image shows the Culex mosquito. It can be identified by the presence of unspotted wings, hunched back, and the absence of stripes.  The Culex mosquitoes are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis. 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most prevalent cause of viral encephalitis in Asia. It is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease caused by Flavivirus. It is transmitted mainly by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically C. tritaeniorhynchus and C. vishnui (common in India) species.

JE is a zoonotic disease primarily affecting animals like pigs and ardeid birds (pond herons, cattle egret). Pigs are considered the major vertebrate hosts and amplifiers for the JE virus. Humans are the dead-end hosts for this virus. When a mosquito bites an infected pig, the virus is transmitted to the mosquito. The virus, in turn, is transferred to other pigs or humans due to mosquito bites and this cycle continues. Horses are the only known domestic animals that present with signs of JE infection.

The control measures include mosquito control by areal or ground fogging with ultra-low-volume insecticides such as malathion and fenitrothion, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs.

JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunisation Schedule.

questions.text:
A middle-aged male patient who has been diagnosed with short bowel syndrome is to be given parenteral nutrition. All of the following are true about parenteral nutrition except:

PICC - peripherally inserted central venous catheter

choices.text: Central venous access can be achieved through subclavian vein
PICC line can produce irreversible thrombophlebitis
Peripheral feeding can be used for more than 2 weeks
Catheter-related sepsis is a common complication

questions.solution:
All of the above are true about parenteral nutrition except that peripheral feeding can be used for more than 2 weeks. 

Parenteral nutrition is defined as the continuous infusion of all the required nutrition through the intravenous route to completely avoid the use of the gastrointestinal tract. It is usually indicated when protein and energy demands cannot be met by enteral nutrition administration. They include causes such as short bowel syndrome, enterocutaneous fistula, etc.

It can be provided by obtaining either peripheral venous access or central venous access. Peripheral venous access is achieved either by inserting a catheter into a peripheral vein and then maneuvering it into the central vein (peripherally inserted central venous catheter-PICC) or by a short wrist vein cannula. PICC lines have a mean survival duration of 7 days and can cause irreversible thrombophlebitis. 

Central venous access is achieved by the subclavian, internal jugular, or external jugular vein. The infraclavicular subclavian approach is preferred as it is easier to provide nursing care. For long-term parenteral nutrition, Hickman lines are more appropriate.

The image below shows (A) a typical PICC line (B) the insertion of a PICC line (C) a patient with a PICC line inserted through the upper arm.

Parenteral nutrition can cause metabolic complications such as fluid overload, hyperglycemia (due to insulin resistance in critically ill patients), vitamin deficiencies, and impaired liver function. Catheter-related sepsis is common and can be diagnosed by culturing organisms from the blood or catheter tip. Refeeding syndrome is caused by severe fluid and electrolyte shifts in patients undergoing refeeding and results in hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia/hypoglycemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: Mr. X is a 24-year-old muscular male athlete with a BMI of 21 kg/m2 and Ms. Y is a 36-year-old female with a BMI of 28 kg/m2. Both of them are started on the same drug 'D' which is highly lipid-soluble. Which of the following statement is false about the expected pharmacokinetics of the drug administered to them?

choices.text: Ms. Y requires a higher loading dose of the drug compared to Mr. X
Mr X requires a higher loading dose of the drug compared to Ms. Y
The drug 'D' will have a higher volume of distribution in case of Ms. Y
The drug 'D' will have a lower volume of distribution  in case of Mr. X

questions.solution:
The false statement is "Mr. X requires a higher loading dose of the drug compared to Ms. Y."

Lipophilic drugs are more likely to distribute to areas with high-fat content. The volume of distribution is governed by factors such as fat content in the body, body water composition, etc. Hence, the drug will have a higher volume of distribution in Ms. Y. Since the volume of distribution is directly proportional to the loading dose, Ms. Y would require a higher loading dose of the drug compared to Mr. X. 

Loading Dose = (Vol. of Distribution x Desired Steady-state plasma Concentration)/ Bioavailability

When the time to reach a steady state is long, as it is for drugs with long half-lives, it is desirable to administer a loading dose that quickly raises the concentration of drug in plasma to the targeted level of concentration.

 The volume of distribution is the proportionality factor that relates the total amount of drug in the body to the concentration. The following formula calculates it: 

Volume of distribution = Amount of drug in the body/Concentration of the drug in blood or plasma

questions.text: A newborn assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to have a  heart rate of 122 beats/min. The baby coughs on inserting a nasal catheter and has a strong cry. His limbs have some degree of flexion and his body was pink with blue extremities. What is the Apgar score in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The Apgar score in this newborn is 8.

In the given newborn the following features bring the total Apgar score to 8: 

  • Heart rate >100 - score 2
  • Strong cry is present in terms of respiratory effort - score 2
  • Body appears pink but the extremities are blue - score 1
  • Some degree of flexion - score 1
  • Coughs on stimulation - score 2

Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It measures appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration.  It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Causes for low Apgar score are:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Haemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a wound with the linear splitting of the tissue, sharp margins, and crushed hair follicles, which is suggestive of an incised-looking lacerated wound. 

Incised-looking lacerated wounds are seen at sites where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue. A blunt force causes linear splitting of the tissue which results in the laceration resembling an incised wound. 

Common areas: Scalp, forehead, eyebrows, zygoma, lower jaw, perineum, shin, and iliac crest.

A laceration is a tear or a split in the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ produced by blunt force. The full thickness of the skin is penetrated.

Classification of a laceration:

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration) occurs when the skin is crushed between two hard objects
  • Stretch laceration occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.
  • Avulsion is a lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues. It may overhang the wound.
  • Tears occur due to tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue can occur from localized impact.
  • Cut lacerations occur due to an injury that leads to a deep and wide injury. 

Features of laceration:

  • Margins are irregular with pieces of tissue attached in between called tissue tags or bridges. Tears that are seen at the ends, diverging away from the main laceration are called swallow tails.
  • Bruising is seen around the margins.
  • Deeper tissues are unevenly divided with tissue tags.
  • Hair bulbs are crushed.
  • Depth of the wound contains abundant foreign material such as dust particles, paint material of the vehicle involved, etc
  • In skin lacerations, one of the margins overhangs the other helping in assessing the direction of the force.
  • A laceration, on healing, produces a permanent scar.

Other options -  

Option A:- Strech laceration - A flap of skin is peeled off from the underlying bone or deep fascia due to overstretching of the fixed skin, seen in running over by a motor vehicle. 

Option B:- Incised wound - produced by a sharp weapon. Wound margins are clear and regular with no tissue bridges, associated with profuse bleeding.

Option D:- Chop wound - produced by a heavy sharp weapon. A deep gaping wound with regular margins associated with bruising of the adjacent skin and crushing of the floor of the wound.

questions.text: During surgery, a patient is given an inhalational anesthetic through a red color vaporizer. All of the following can be a side effect of this anesthetic except?
questions.solution:
Halothane is the inhaled anesthetic, delivered through red-colored vaporizer, and status asthmaticus is not a side effect of halothane. Halothane is one of the preferred anesthetics for asthmatics as it causes bronchodilation and suppresses cough.

Halothane has a sweet odor, is non-irritant, and is non-inflammable. Therefore, it can be used both for induction and maintenance of general anesthesia.

Side effects of halothane include the following:

  • Halothane hepatitis is a fulminant form of hepatotoxicity which is characterized by elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase levels, and massive hepatic necrosis. Hepatic toxicity is less frequent in children.
  • Malignant hyperthermia occurs due to halothane triggering calcium-channel receptors at the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles. This releases massive amounts of intracellular calcium ions. This causes persistent muscle contraction and increased heat production. It is more commonly seen in susceptible subjects who have an abnormal RyR1 (Ryanodine receptor) calcium channel and is accentuated by the presence of succinylcholine.
  • Respiratory depression
  • Myocardial depression
  • Sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic action of adrenaline.
  • A fall in blood pressure leads to decreased cardiac output, decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and urine output.

RTS is a scoring system that assesses the overall condition of the injured patient by using a combination of the Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate. questions.text: Secondary membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Secondary membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is seen in hepatitis B. 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis/mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis is a pattern of immune-mediated injury and can be classified, histologically, into three types:

  • MPGN type I is immune-complex mediated 
  • MPGN type II (otherwise called dense-deposit disease) and type III are immunoglobulin mediated and occur due to excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway. 

Secondary MPGN is, invariably, type I MPGN and is caused by:

  • System lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Infections: Hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoatrial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses
  • α1-Antitrypsin deficiency
  • Malignant diseases, particularly chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)

Type I MPGN manifests as a combined nephritic-nephrotic picture with hematuria and mild proteinuria. Histopathological findings of type I MPGN are: 

  • On light microscopy - 
    • Hypercellular, and large glomeruli with a lobular appearance
    • Proliferating mesangial cells and increased mesangial matrix
    • Double contour or tram-track appearance of the glomerular basement membrane due to new basement membrane synthesis. It is evident in silver or PAS stains
  • On electron microscopy - subendothelial electron-dense deposits
  • On immunofluorescence - IgG and C3 can be seen deposited in a granular pattern

The image below shows the histology of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis with lobular appearing glomeruli, mesangial cell proliferation, and capillary membrane thickening.

Other options:

Option A: Reflux nephropathy is associated with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). There is characteristic epithelial damage (the hallmark of FSGS) and effacement of foot processes. It is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome.

Option C: Alport syndrome is usually an inherited X-linked disease that causes mutations affecting type IV collagen production that is crucial for the lens, cochlea, and GBM function.  On electron microscopy, GBM gives a basket-weave appearance (thickening alternating with thining) and with progression will lead to focal segmental and global glomerulosclerosis. Other manifestations include cataracts, lens dislocation, and sensorineural deafness.     

Option D: Goodpasture syndrome is an anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease that causes crescentic glomerulonephritis as well as necrotizing hemorrhagic interstitial pneumonitis.

questions.text: A female patient with 5 weeks of amenorrhea, comes with complaints of profuse vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal pain. She is hypotensive. Abdominal ultrasound reveals an empty gestational sac. Her urine pregnancy test was found to be positive. What would be the absolute contraindication for medical management?

choices.text: A sac size  less than 3.5 cm

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy and it is an absolute contraindication for medical management. 

Methotrexate is used in the medical management of ectopic pregnancy. The classic predictors of its success are:

  • Initial beta-HCG level (single best prognostic indicator)
  • Size of ectopic pregnancy - size <3.5 is associated with better success
  • Fetal cardiac activity - the presence of cardiac activity is more likely to fail

Single-dose methotrexate therapy of  50 mg/m2  of body surface area protocol is more commonly used.      

According to ACOG (2013), absolute contraindications for medical management include:  

  • Ruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy
  • Intrauterine pregnancy
  • Evidence of immunodeficiency
  • Hematologic dysfunction
  • Active pulmonary disease
  • Active peptic ulcer disease
  • Clinically significant hepatic/renal impairment

Note: Expectant management is indicated if the serum hCG levels are less than 1000 IU/L, gestation sac size less than 4 cm with transvaginal ultrasound showing no fetal heartbeat and no evidence of rupture or bleeding.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient complains of fatigue and weight loss for the past 1 year. Examination revealed massive splenomegaly. Chromosomal analysis was done and the defect is shown below. Which is the most sensitive test to detect this type of defect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows t(9:22) and BCR-ABL fusion, along with features of fatigue, weight loss, and massive splenomegaly suggesting a diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The most sensitive investigation to detect this translocation defect is spectral karyotyping (SKY) or multicolor FISH. 

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm that presents as fatigue, anemia, splenomegaly, weight loss, and anorexia. The image demonstrates the Philadelphia chromosome, a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. BCR-ABL gene created by this reciprocal (9;22) (q34;q11) translocation is characteristic of CML. It is detected using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or PCR.

Fluorescent in Situ Hybridisation (FISH) is a technique for the detection of specific genetic information on morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes. It uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. Multicolor FISH uses 23 distinct fluorescent colors, thus each chromosome is identified by a unique color, and translocations are detected easily.

G banding (Option A) is a method used for karyotyping and chromosomal identification using Geimsa stain. It cannot detect small translocations but is used for detecting aneuploidies.

Southern blotting(Option C) is used to detect specific  DNA sequences using complementary DNA probes and is not used for the diagnosis of CML.

DNA sequencing(Option D) is used to detect Mendelian disorders, cancers, acute myeloid leukemia, etc. It is the sequencing of the whole genome and is done using Sangers sequencing or Next Generation Sequencing. It is not employed for the diagnosis of CML in patients.

Image of a multicolor FISH/Spectral Karyotyping:

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement about cadaveric rigidity:

choices.text: It is a sign of death
Helps to estimate time since death
Indicates body position at time of death

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about cadaveric rigidity is that it suggests the manner of death. 

Cadaveric spasm suggests the manner of death i.e. if the death occurred due to a homicide, suicide, or accident. 

Cadaveric rigidity refers to the state of stiffening of muscles after death. Individual cell death occurs during this stage. It is also known as postmortem stiffening, rigor mortis, or cadaveric stiffening. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours.

Rigor mortis in all the muscles of the body does not begin simultaneously. The sequential order in which rigor mortis appears is given by Nysten's rule. Muscles are affected in the given order:

  • Involuntary muscles - heart
  • Eyelids
  • Neck and lower jaw
  • Face
  • Chest
  • Upper extremities
  • Abdomen
  • Legs
  • Fingers and toes

Medicolegal importance of rigor mortis:

  • It is a sign of death
  • Its extent helps in the estimation of the time of death. However, it may not be reliable.
  • It depicts the position of the body at the time of death

Related Pearl: Difference between Cadaveric Rigidity (Rigor mortis) and Cadaveric Spasm (Instantaneous rigor)

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with a painful vulvar lesion. On examination, there is an exophytic and ulcerative vulvar mass. It is about 4 cm in diameter and there are no palpable inguinal lymph nodes. Incisional biopsy reveals a poorly differentiated invasive vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Which among the following is false?

choices.text: Labia minora is the most common site
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
Groin node status is the best prognostic predictor
Spread through vascular route is rare

questions.solution:
Labia minora is the most common site is a false statement. The most common site of vulvar cancer is labia majora.

Vulval cancer is most common in elderly females in the 6th or 7th decade. In young women, human papillomavirus (HPV) infection and smoking can increase the risk of vulval cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulvar cancer.

Clinically, patients present with pruritus, vulval swelling, lump, or ulcer. Lesions are seen commonly in labia majora. The clitoris and perineal region can also be involved. Ulcers can bleed and cause offensive discharge. Inguinal lymph nodes may or may not be palpable.

First lymph node involved: Superficial inguinal lymph node > Deep inguinal lymph node > Femoral group of lymph nodes. The vascular route of spread is rare in vulvar cancer. Groin node status is the best prognostic predictor.

Sentinel lymph node mapping is useful in vulval cancer. It is the lymph node that receives the drainage directly from the primary tumor. Removal of the sentinel lymph node helps to avoid unnecessary dissection of other nodes. This can be achieved by lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy before or during surgery.

IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes

questions.text:
You see an elderly man collapse in a shopping mall. He has no pulse. What is the correct sequence to be followed to provide cardio-pulmonary resuscitation to him?
  1. Call for the emergency response team
  2. Check scene safety
  3. Recheck pulse
  4. Chest compressions
questions.solution:
The correct sequence to be followed to provide cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) to the elderly man is 2-1-4-3.

For a patient in respiratory and cardiac distress, CAB-D (Circulation, Airway, Breathing, Defibrillate) must be assessed:

  1. Assess to make sure the scene is safe for you to attend to the patient.
  2. Assess responsiveness: Speak to the adult and ask if they are ok. Simultaneously look at the chest and abdomen for movement and normal breathing. 
  3. If the patient is unresponsive, call the emergency response team and bring an automatic external defibrillator (AED) to the patient or ask someone nearby to do so.
  4. Place the patient supine on a hard flat surface.
  5. Check for a carotid pulse for 5-10 sec.
  6. If the patient does not have a pulse, proceed with 5 cycles of CPR (lasting approximately 2 minutes).
    • Start with chest compressions:
      • Provide 100-120 compressions per min.
      • Place palms midline, one over the other, on the lower 1/3rd of the patient’s sternum between the nipples.
      • Press to a depth of 2-2.4 inches (5-6 cm) on the patient’s chest.
      • Press hard and fast.
      • Ensure full chest recoil with each compression.
    • Provide 2 rescue breaths for every 30 chest compressions (1 cycle of adult CPR is 30 chest compressions to 2 rescue breaths).
    • Recheck pulse every 2 min.
  7. If the patient has a pulse:
    • Provide 10 rescue breaths per min (1 breath every 6 sec).
    • Recheck pulse every 2 min.
  8. Once the AED arrives, analyze the rhythm for defibrillation:
    • If the rhythm is shockable, assure no one is near the patient, press the shock button, and resume 5 cycles of CPR.
    • If the rhythm is not shockable, initiate 5 cycles of CPR and recheck the rhythm.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below. 

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text:
The image below shows the metabolic pathways of levodopa in the periphery and brain. Identify the drug that corresponds to the action of A in the following

COMT - Catechol-O-methyl transferase

DDC - Dopa decarboxylase

3-OMD - 3-O-methyldopa

BBB - Blood-brain barrier

MAO - Monoamine oxidase

3-MT - 3-methoxytyramine

DOPAC - Dihydroxy phenylacetic acid

HVA - Homovanillic acid
questions.solution:
The drug that corresponds to the action of A is tolcapone.

Tolcapone is an anti-parkinsonism drug that acts by inhibiting COMT enzyme and is an adjuvant to levodopa-carbidopa in advanced parkinsonism with motor fluctuations. It acts as an adjuvant by prolonging the half-life of levodopa. COMT inhibitors are used to smoothen the 'wearing off' as well as increase the 'on' time and decrease the 'off' time and thus allowing to reduce the dose of levodopa. Another drug in the same class is entacapone.

Parkinsonism is an extrapyramidal disorder and is characterized by rigidity, tremor, and hypokinesia. It occurs due to degeneration of substantia nigra and the nigrostriatal tract causing a deficiency of dopamine.  

Other options:

Options A and B: Benserazide and carbidopa are peripheral (extracerebral) dopa decarboxylase inhibitors and do not penetrate the blood-brain barrier or inhibit the conversion of levodopa into dopamine. 

Option C: Selegiline is an MAO-B inhibitor and at low doses retards the intracerebral degradation of dopamine.
