questions.text: A surgeon performing a modified radical mastectomy decides to remove the pectoralis minor and level III lymph nodes but preserve the pectoralis major. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The given procedure where pectoralis minor and level III lymph nodes are removed but pectoralis major was preserved is Patey's modified radical mastectomy. 

Patey's modified radical mastectomy is a total mastectomy. It includes removal of the breast tissue and axillary lymph nodes up to level III along with the removal of pectoralis minor muscle, but pectoralis major is preserved.

Other options:

Option A: Scanlon’s modified radical mastectomy is a modification of Patey's procedure in which pectoralis minor is incised and not removed following which the level III nodes are approached. 

Option C: Halsted radical mastectomy involves excision of the breast tissue, skin, and nipple-areolar complex, dissection of level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes, and pectoralis major and minor muscles. 

Option D: In, Auchincloss modified radical mastectomy, pectoralis minor is left intact and level III nodes are not removed. 

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: A young woman delivered a baby with limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions. Which of the following infections did the mother most likely have during her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. It is seen in babies born to mothers who had chickenpox infections during their pregnancy.

Features of congenital varicella syndrome include:

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis

The image below shows limb hypoplasia in fetal varicella syndrome:

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A young girl was rushed to the emergency room in a delirious state. Her parents reported her to have consumed a wild fruit as shown below while on a camping trip. On examination, photophobia, staggering gait, flushing, and dry mucous membranes are noticed. The pupils are bilaterally dilated. Which of the following plant poisons she may have consumed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing cherry-like fruit is suggestive that the plant poison the patient may have consumed is Atropa belladonna. 

Atropa belladonna is a deliriant poison that acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

Clinical manifestations of Atropa belladonna poisoning include: 

  • Fever, flushing, rash
  • Neurological symptoms - delirium, slurred speech, headache, choreoathetosis, myoclonus, visual and auditory hallucinations, convulsions and coma
  • Eye symptoms - photophobia, blurred vision, dilated pupils poorly reactive to light
  • Cardiovascular symptoms - arrhythmia, tachycardia, hypertension
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms - severely dry mouth and throat, decreased bowel sounds, constipation, ileus
  • Renal symptoms - urinary retention

Anticholinergic symptoms include tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis and urinary retention. 

Treatment - Conservative management with gastric lavage with activated charcoal. Benzodiazepines are used to control agitation and delirium. Physostigmine is a specific antidote, that should be given in cases of tachycardia, coma and respiratory arrest.

 

Other options - 

Option A - Datura poisoning also presents with similar symptoms, but the image given is not of datura stramonium.

Option B - Nicotiana tabacum is a cardiac poison, all parts of the plant are poisonous except the ripe seeds. Acute poisoning results in burning sensation, abdominal pain, hypersalivation, tachycardia, hypotension, and respiratory depression.

Option C - Ricinus poisoning leads to symptoms such as the burning of oral mucosa, salivation, nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhoea. It may also cause drowsiness, convulsions, delirium, and death. The entire plant is poisonous, but seeds are the most toxic and toxic principle is toxalbumin ricin which acts by blocking protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient comes with complaints of a palpable swelling on her breast. On histopathology examination, dyscohesive infiltrating tumor cells and signet ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets are seen. Immunohistochemistry shows the tumor to be under the luminal group. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of palpable breast mass, with histopathology showing dyscohesive infiltrating tumor cells and signet ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, is suggestive of invasive lobular carcinoma.

They also show a single file pattern or Indian file pattern on histopathology. Immunohistochemically, lobular carcinoma is a special histologic type that comes under the luminal group, which means that they are ER-positive/HER2-negative. 

The most common genetic abnormality observed in the above lesion is loss of function of the CDH1 gene. The function of the CDH1 gene is to make E-Cadherin protein which makes the cell cohesive. Loss of function makes the cell dyscohesive. 

A histopathology image of invasive lobular carcinoma showing a single file pattern is given below.

 

 

Other options:

Option B- Phyllodes tumor arises from the intralobular stroma and on histology, it appears as increased stromal cellularity with typical leaf-like architecture as shown below.

 

Option C- Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor that appears as a delicate and often myxoid stroma that resembles normal intralobular stroma as shown below.

 

Option D- Medullary carcinoma of the breast appears as sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders as shown below.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with back pain radiating to the leg after lifting a heavy suitcase. There is sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, and great toe. The medial hamstring reflex is diminished. The knee and ankle jerks are normal. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this case scenario is L4-L5 disc prolapse.

The points given in the question in favor of this diagnosis are back pain radiating to the leg, sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, great toe, diminished medial hamstring reflex, and normal ankle jerk. 

The prolapsed intervertebral disc (PIVD) usually presents in adults between 20 to 40 years. The most common symptom is low back pain. It can be associated with or without pain radiating down the back of the leg (sciatica). 

Neurological features of L4-L5 PIVD are: 

  • Weakness of extensor hallucis longus and dorsiflexor muscles of the foot
  • Sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of knee and leg, dorsum of the foot, and the great toe. One or more adjacent toes may also be involved (i.e., 1st web space) but never the little toe
  • Diminished medial hamstring reflex
  • Knee jerk and ankle jerk are normal.

Tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT): 

This test is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area. The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in a neutral position. Affected leg passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. SLRT test negative if the leg can be raised 80–90 degrees without pain. SLRT test positive if pain elicited between 30-60 or 70 degrees from horizontal. Lasègue's test is a modified SLRT where the knee is bent to 90 degrees. 

2. Crossed straight-leg test: 

SLRT on the unaffected side. Pain felt on the affected side and is termed as contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is often highly specific for a large central prolapse. 

3. Bowstring sign or popliteal compression test: 

This test is more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. It is performed by eliciting SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Now without reducing the amount of lift, the knee is bent to relax the sciatic nerve. The pain in the buttocks is immediately relieved. Following this, the popliteal fossa is pressed to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. Tightening of the nerve like a bowstring re-induces the pain. 

MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment:

  • Bed rest, heat, ice, NSAIDs, muscle relaxants and/or spinal traction are commonly advised
  • Operative removal of the prolapsed disc: 
    • Absolute indication - cauda equina compression syndrome 
    • Relative indications - neurological deterioration, persistent pain and/or failed conservative treatment

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with frequent headaches. Following workup, he is diagnosed with migraine headaches. However, he firmly believes that he has a brain tumor. He visits several doctors and undergoes repeated brain imaging, but is still not reassured. His wife mentions that he had previously been visiting multiple doctors for months, after believing he had colon cancer following a few episodes of diarrhea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts a patient misinterpreting his headache and being worried about having a serious illness like brain tumor. This is characteristic of hypochondriasis.

Hypochondriasis, now somatic symptom disorder, is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. It equally affects men and women and is commonly seen in the third decade of life. Patients believe that they have a serious disease despite negative laboratory results, the benign course of the disease, and reassurances from doctors.

They are preoccupied with excessive thinking about their symptoms, leading to high levels of anxiety about their health. They spend excessive time and energy in an attempt to address their health concerns.

The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months. The disorder follows an episodic course separated by long qui­escent periods. Exacerbations of somatic symptoms are associated with psychosocial stressors.

Patients with somatic symptom disorder usually resist psychi­atric treatment. Management involves psychotherapy, regular health checks providing objective evidence of their health, and treatment of any underlying psychiatric conditions like depression.

Other options:

Option A: Conversion disorder now termed functional neurological symptom disorder is a mental disorder in which the patient experiences an involuntary limitation or alteration of physical function that is an expression of a psychological conflict or need, not of a physical disorder.

Option B: Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by persistent preoccupations about perceived flaws in one’s appearance. This causes significant emotional distress and impairment in the patient's functioning. The patient firmly believes that there is some abnormality in their appearance, like a crooked nose, unequal limb length, malformed ears, etc. They may frequently look into the mirror, try various methods to cover up their imaginary flaws, or even avoid stepping out of the house.

Option C: Factitious disorder (Munchausen syndrome) is the intentional production of physical symptoms to seek medical attention. There is no intention to obtain a practical gain. They want to make hospitalization a way of their life.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, pain, and swelling over the right thigh. On examination, a mass was noted over the diaphysis of the femur. Cytogenetic analysis showed translocation (11:22). The histopathology image is given below. Identify the most likely X-ray feature of this condition:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the histopathology image showing sheaths of small round cells that are PAS-positive are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma. Onion peel appearance is the most likely X-ray feature of this condition.

Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant tumor that occurs mainly in the age group between 10-20 years. The most common site is the diaphysis of long bones. Karyotyping shows a translocation (11:22). 

The gross specimen shows a tumor involving the whole medullary cavity. The bone gets expanded, the periosteum gets elevated and subperiosteal new bone formation occurs in layers.

Microscopically, solid sheaths of small round cells with PAS-positive magenta pink colored cytoplasm are seen. The cells show PAS positivity due to the presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen. This is an important feature for the differential diagnosis of Ewing's with other small round cell tumors. 

The clinical features include persistent pain, swelling over the area and fever. On X-ray, a lytic lesion in the medullary area on the diaphysis of long bones will be seen. It also shows cortical destruction along with new bone formation. This is called onion peel appearance. 

It is a highly radiosensitive tumor. Radiotherapy for control of local tumor and chemotherapy with vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and adriamycin is considered.

Other options: 

Option A: Sunray appearance is seen in osteosarcoma. It occurs predominantly in the age group of 15- 25 years. The common sites are the metaphysis of the lower end of the femur and the upper end of the tibia.

Option C: Soap bubble appearance is seen in osteoclastoma. It occurs predominantly in the age group of 20-40 years. The common sites are epiphysis of the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, lower end of the radius.

Option D: Mottled calcification is seen in chondrosarcoma.it occurs predominantly in the age group of 30 - 60 years. The common sites are anywhere in the flat bones and upper end of the femur.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with sudden onset palpitations over the last 3 days. ECG is shown below. There was evidence of a thrombus in the left atria on transesophageal electrocardiography (TEE). How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of palpitations for 3 days (>48 hours) along with the ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm with absent 'p' waves suggests atrial fibrillation. The TEE shows evidence of thrombus. Thus, the patient is managed with anticoagulation for 3 weeks. 

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia characterized by disorganized, rapid, and irregular atrial activation. 

It is common in men and risk factors are underlying cardiac disease, hypertension, diabetes, family history of AF, obesity, and sleeping disorders.

Features include heart rate typically ranges from 110-160 beats/minute. It is irregular and rapid. Presyncope and syncope can be seen. Thrombus formation can occur and thromboembolic events can take place.

Typically, ECG shows an absent P wave.

Management is mainly by control of rate and rhythm, avoiding the thromboembolism risk and modifiable risk factors.

Immediate cardioversion (option B) should be done when the patient presents within 48 hours and are at low risk for developing stroke whereas in patients presenting after 48 hours or if the duration is not known, there is an increased risk of thromboembolism. Therefore, anticoagulation should be done for 3 weeks followed by cardioversion and 4 weeks post cardioversion. 

The other approach is to start anticoagulation followed by transesophageal echo and only if the thrombus is absent cardioversion can be done.

The rate control strategy (option D) is adopted to reduce the patient's symptoms. It is achieved with calcium channel blockers/ beta blockers and digoxin.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the demographic process and cycle of various countries. Which of the following statements would likely be true for India?

choices.text: Birth rate lower than death rate

questions.solution:
India is currently in the third (late-expanding) stage of the demographic cycle, which is characterized by a decreasing demographic gap.

A demographic gap is a difference between the birth rate and the death rate. The demographic gap is maximum in the early-expanding phase, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate. As the demography of the country transitions to the late-expanding phase, both the birth rate and death rate fall, causing a decreasing demographic gap. Although the birth rate is falling in the late-expanding phase, it is still higher than the death rate, which causes the population to increase.

Other options:

Option A: A birth rate lower than the death rate is seen in the fifth (declining) stage of the demographic cycle.

Option B: The maximum demographic gap is seen in the second (early-expanding) stage, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate.

Option D: The stationary population is seen in the first (high stationary) stage and fourth (low stationary) stage of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A COVID-positive patient was rushed to the emergency on the 3rd day of illness due to difficulty in breathing. His Spo2 was 84%, and ABG values showed normal PaCO2 with low PaO2. He was mechanically ventilated in view of his deteriorating condition. Despite best efforts, the patient couldn't be saved and succumbed to death. What type of respiratory failure would have caused this?
questions.solution:
The patient had died because of COVID pneumonia. The respiratory failure seen in pneumonia is Type I respiratory failure (acute hypoxemic type).

Type I respiratory failure occurs due to alveolar flooding (caused by alveolar haemorrhage, pulmonary oedema, lung injury, pneumonia) and subsequent ventilation-perfusion mismatch and intrapulmonary shunt physiology.

Causes include

  • Sepsis
  • COVID-19
  • Gastric aspiration
  • Pneumonia
  • Near-drowning
  • Multiple blood transfusions
  • Pancreatitis.

Management includes prone positioning, fluid conservation, masks, and high-flow oxygen delivery systems.

Other options:

Option A: Type IV respiratory failure occurs due to hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles during shock. Intubation and mechanical ventilation can cause a redistribution of cardiac output to vital organs.

Option B: Type III respiratory failure results from lung atelectasis. It is more common in the postoperative period. Treatment includes frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and/or abdominal pain. Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

Option C: Type II or hypercapnic respiratory failure is characterized by alveolar hypoventilation and the inability to effectively eliminate carbon dioxide. Therefore the levels of PaCO2 are high. Management is aimed at treating the underlying cause(s) of ventilatory failure. Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation with a tight-fitting facial or nasal mask can be used.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe left loin pain and burning micturition. His erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the best management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given abdominal X-ray shows left staghorn renal calculi. The best treatment option for staghorn renal calculi is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Staghorn calculi is also known as triple phosphate stone. It occupies the renal pelvis and calyces.

PCNL: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney by percutaneous technique and stones are fragmented and removed. It is mainly used in treating large stones and stones in the proximal ureter.

Indications of PCNL:

  • Obstructions caused by anatomical abnormalities like pulviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula or ureteric obstruction
  • Staghorn calculi
  • Stones >2.5 cm in size
  • Stone composition - struvite, calcium oxalate monohydrate and cystine stones
  • Multiple stones
  • Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated
  • Stones not responding for ESWL

Other options:

Option A: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. 

Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Contraindications for ESWL include obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Option C: Percutaneous nephrostomy, or nephropyelostomy, is an interventional procedure that is used in the decompression of the renal collecting system.

It is done in grossly unwell patients due to sepsis secondary to an obstructive urinary tract calculi. They drain pus from the kidneys adequately with less manipulation and a lower risk of septicemia than a ureteric stent.

Option D: Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. Ureteric calculi are directly visualized through semi-rigid ureteroscopes. Stones are then fragmented and extracted using a dormia basket.

Ureteroscopic stone removal using dormia basket is depicted in the image below.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who had witnessed a terrorist attack has been experiencing frequent intrusive flashbacks and nightmares about the incident. He avoids the places that remind him of it.  He is significantly distressed, has difficulty falling asleep and frequently feels anxious for the last 6 months. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with re-experiences (flashbacks and nightmares), avoidance of the stimuli associated with the attacks, and hyperarousal (impaired sleep and anxiety) for more than one month are suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder(PTSD).

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event, (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks- The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state- fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

The duration of these symptoms should be > 1 month to label it as PTSD.

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. SSRIs may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to stressful situations like financial issues, medical illnesses, or relation­ship problems that develop within 3 months of the stressor. The stressor in adjustment disorder can be of any severity. In adjustment disorder, the individual does not experience intrusive symptoms like flashbacks and nightmares, hyperarousal symptoms, and avoidance symptoms.

Option B: Acute stress disorder presents with the same symptoms as PTSD, but the symptoms usually occur immediately after the trauma and persist for a period of 3 days to upto 1 month after the trauma.

Option C: Persistent complex bereavement disorder occurs after the death of a loved one. Since the death, for 12 months or more, the individual may experience persistent yearning/longing for the deceased, intense sorrow, and emotional pain, preoccupation with the deceased, and the circumstances of the death.

questions.text: The CT abdomen of a patient presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting, with CT showing a Mercedes-Benz sign, is characteristic of cholelithiasis.

Mercedes–Benz sign (triradiate sign), is seen when a gallstone contains central radiolucent gas. The fissures may be tri-radiate or bi-radiate (seagull sign). These fissures appear dark on CT or radiographs, giving the sign its characteristic appearance. 

Gallbladder stones or cholelithiasis are the most common condition affecting the gallbladder. They are often discovered incidentally and typically remain asymptomatic. However, they become symptomatic when the stones obstruct the cystic duct. In such cases, patients may experience dull or colicky right upper quadrant or epigastric pain radiating to the back, along with symptoms like nausea and vomiting. 

Only about 10% of gallstones are radiopaque. Ultrasonography (USG) is the most accurate initial imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of gallbladder stones. These stones appear as echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows. The sensitivity of USG for gallstones is >95%.

questions.text: What is the most common gene mutation associated with pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Bone morphogenetic protein receptor 2 (BMPR2)  is the most common gene mutation in pulmonary hypertension. Inactivating mutations in this gene are found in 75% of the familial cases of pulmonary hypertension, and 25% of sporadic cases.

The BMPR2 receptor is a cell surface protein belonging to the TGF-β receptor superfamily. It is involved in the regulation of growth, differentiation, and apoptosis of pulmonary artery endothelial and smooth muscle cells.

Due to the mutation, there is enhanced proliferation and reduced apoptosis of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells leading to pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A young woman presents with the following lesion on the right inguinal lymph node region. Direct microscopy of a smear from the lesion shows a school of fish appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with the image showing bubo formed from ruptured and necrosed right inguinal lymph node suggest the most likely diagnosis to be chancroid. 

Soft chancre or chancroid is caused by the gram-negative bacterium, Haemophilus ducreyi. 

It begins as inflammatory papules that undergoes central necrosis and forms multiple painful nonindurated ulcers with undermined edges. It is often associated with inguinal lymphad­enitis, which may suppurate and lead to bubo formation. They are usually unilateral, fluctuant and may rupture spontaneously to form inguinal ulcers and sinuses.

Autoinoculation from the primary ulcer may lead to multiple or kissing ulcers on opposing skin surfaces, as well as extragenital lesions.

Diagnosis:

  • Direct microscopy of smears from chancroid  - school of fish appearance of organisms
  • Culture of H. ducreyi from the lesion or from an aspirate of suppurative lymph nodes

The image below shows school of fish appearance of H. ducreyi on microscopy.

Treatment as per the NACO guideline:

  • Doxycycline 100mg orally twice daily for 21 days (to cover LGV) + azithromycin 1g orally single dose, OR 
  • Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally, twice a day for 3 days to cover chancroid
  • Partner notification and treatment
  • Fluctuant buboes should be aspirated through healthy skin

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolytes level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette in a patient with no signs of dehydration and body temperature of 106oF is highly suggestive of heatstroke. Sweating is absent in heatstroke.

Heatstroke/ thermic fever/ heat hyperpyrexia is due to the failure of the heat regulation center of the hypothalamus. It is caused by failure of cutaneous circulation and sweating. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, alcoholism.

Heatstroke can be:

  • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures, usually without adequate training.
  • Sedentary heatstroke is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body temperature rises.

All the signs of shock are present. Patients usually present with a sudden collapse accompanied by loss of consciousness. Typical vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure. Other specific signs include rapid Kussmaul type of breathing, the absence of sweating with dry, hot skin, delirium, coma, convulsions, rhabdomyolysis, multiorgan failure.

Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, clinical features of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature >104.9-degree Fahrenheit (> 40.5 degrees Celsius) help establish the preliminary diagnosis. The body temperature must be measured rectally.

Treatment includes rapidly cooling the body with ice water till the rectal temperature falls below 1020F.

Autopsy findings include the presence of edema and reduction of Purkinje's cells in the cerebellum.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the clinic with easy fatiguability and weight loss. His peripheral smear is shown below. Cytogenetic studies showed the presence of t (9;22) (q34.1; q11.2) translocations. He was started on two tyrosine kinase inhibitors but has shown no improvement. What is the next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with peripheral smear showing marked leukocytosis, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms with t(9;22)(q34.1; q11.2) chromosomal translocation is suggestive of chronic myeloid leukaemia. Since there was no improvement with 2 tyrosine kinase inhibitors, the next step in treatment is omacetaxine. 

Omacetaxine is a protein synthesis inhibitor. It selectively inhibits BCR-ABL 1 oncoprotein synthesis. It is indicated when there is no response with 2 or more tyrosine kinase inhibitors or in chronic and accelerated CML. The main side effect of this drug is myelosuppression. 

Chronic myeloid leukaemia is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder that is common in males 55-65 years of age. It occurs due to the balanced reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the Philadelphia chromosome t(9,22) (q34.1; q11.2).

There is no familial association in CML, nor is there a specific etiological factor. Exposure to ionising radiation and radiation therapy post ankylosing spondylitis can increase the risk. Common presenting features are fatigue, malaise, weight loss, anaemia and splenomegaly. 

The peripheral blood findings in CML are:

  • Leukocytosis with a predominance of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Blasts are usually less than 5% of the circulating cells.
  • Thrombocytosis is seen.

The bone marrow in CML shows:

  • Markedly hypercellular marrow with myeloid hyperplasia is present. 
  • Blasts are less than 5% and reticulin fibrosis is seen. 

The initial treatment of choice in patients with chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) is tyrosine kinase inhibitors. These include imatinib, nilotinib, dasatinib, bosutinib, and ponatinib. 

Other options: 

Option A: Hydroxyurea is a safe and effective chemotherapeutic agent. It is used as a temporary measure to reduce the initial CML burden. It is used in between definitive therapies to sustain the hematologic or cytologic response. 

Option B: Busulfan is a rarely used chemotherapeutic agent now. It was used in preparative regimen of patients with CML, planned for allogeneic stem cell transplants. It has side effects like delayed myelosuppression, Addison-like disease, myelofibrosis, and cardiac and pulmonary fibrosis. 

Option A: Ponatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. Since the question mentions there is no improvement with 2 tyrosine kinase inhibitors, it is not the right option.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is unlikely to cause onychomycosis in a patient?
questions.solution:
Microsporum gypseum does not cause onychomycosis.

Dermatophytes includes 3 genera: Trichophyton, Microsporum and Epidermophyton.

  • Epidermophyton includes species E.floccosum. It infects only skin and nails and not hair.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a foot drop. The nerve marked in the below image is affected. Identify the nerve.
questions.solution:
The nerve affected in this patient is the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve). It descends obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa and medial to biceps femoris.

 

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. Patients with common peroneal nerve injury present with foot drop. On examination, there will be weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion of the foot. The sensation on the dorsum of the foot will be diminished.

Other options:

Option B- Sural nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation of the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third in the leg. In the foot, there is diminished sensation over the lateral malleolus and the lateral side of the fifth toe.

Option C- Saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation in the skin over the patella, medial side of the leg, and medial side of the foot.

Option D- Tibial nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. It is derived from the anterior divisions of L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3. In the popliteal fossa, this nerve is overlapped by two heads of gastrocnemius. Damage to this nerve paralyzes gastrocnemius, plantaris, soleus, and popliteus muscles.

questions.text: A patient in the ICU requires fresh frozen plasma (FFP). The FFP that arrives from the blood bank is labeled as Solvent/Detergent plasma, which destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. Which of the following viral infections is the patient still susceptible to?
questions.solution:
The patient is still susceptible to hepatitis A infection. It is a non-enveloped virus, and hence it’s not affected by SD plasma.

Solvent/Detergent plasma (SD plasma) is a form of blood plasma made from plasma collected from many people which is then processed with solvents in an attempt to remove viruses. questions.text: Which of the following is a topical androgen receptor inhibitor that you can prescribe in a 16-year-old with the following condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of papules and pustules with an erythematous base with few comedones, suggestive of moderate acne vulgaris.  Clascoterone is the topical androgen receptor inhibitor that can be prescribed to this patient.

Clascoterone is approved by the FDA in 2020 in the treatment of acne vulgaris in individuals aged ≥ 12 years. It is one of the alternative topical therapies. 

The mechanism of action of clascosterone is that it competes with the androgens, specifically dihydrotestosterone, for binding to the androgen receptor. This leads to inhibition of the sebum production and the inflammatory pathways. 

The adverse effects are skin irritation and in some cases hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression. 

Acne is a polymorphic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit, frequently affecting the face, back and chest. Precipitating factors include:

  • Lifestyle and environmental factors, diet, BMI, smoking and alcohol use, menstrual cycle, stress and sleep deprivation
  • Drugs like corticosteroids, anticonvulsants, etc

questions.text: Your friend is planning a trip to the mountains but is concerned because of her history of severe nausea and vomiting while traveling anywhere. Which of the following drugs would be the least effective in managing her condition?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ondansetron is the least effective in managing motion sickness.

Ondansetron is a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT and does not suppress vomiting caused by motion sickness. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. 

Drugs used in the treatment of motion sickness are:

  • Anticholinergic agents (muscarinic receptor antagonists) such as scopolamine (hyoscine) and dicyclomine.
  • Antihistamines (H1 antagonists) are primarily used for treating motion sickness and postoperative emesis.  

Scopolamine transdermal patches should be given prophylactically as it is less effective once symptoms start. It is applied behind the ear at least 4-12 hours before an anticipated exposure to motion. Dry mouth and sedation are common side effects.

First-generation antihistamines such as promethazine, dimenhydrinate, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, cyclizine, and meclizine are effective in controlling nausea and vomiting in motion sickness. Sedation is a common side effect of these drugs. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine and fexofenadine are ineffective in the treatment of motion sickness.

questions.text:
A woman presents with a lower abdominal mass. A pelvic examination showed an irregular and enlarged uterus. Beta HCG was done and it turned out to be negative. Among the given options, which is the most common symptom that can be seen in the above condition?

Beta HCG: Beta human chorionic gonadotropin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and examination findings are consistent with fibroid uterus/leiomyomas and the most common symptom in this condition is menorrhagia.

Leiomyomas commonly referred to as fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumours mainly arising from the myometrium. Grossly, they are round rubbery masses with a whorled pattern.

Most women with leiomyomas are asymptomatic. When symptomatic, patients complain of bleeding, pain, urinary frequency, incontinence, constipation and infertility.

An increase in size and number of myoma increases the risk of bleeding. Dysregulation of local vasoactive growth factors causes dilatation of endometrial venules. During menstrual sloughing, there is a rupture of these engorged venules, which overwhelms the normal homeostatic mechanism and leads to menorrhagia.  Thus, subserosal, intramural, and submucous tumours have a tendency to cause heavy menstrual bleeding.

Other options:

Option B: Fibroids are usually painless and therefore acute pelvic pain occurs due to a degenerating or prolapsing leiomyoma. However, this is less frequent.

Option C: Pressure symptoms such as constipation, dysuria, or urinary retention can occur but it is rare.

Option D: There has been no conclusive evidence showing an association between abortion and leiomyomas.

questions.text: A young man presented with symmetric weakness in both the lower limbs for 3 months. On examination, external ophthalmoplegia and reduced power in the proximal muscles of the lower limbs are noted. His CSF examination revealed elevated protein levels with no cells.  He underwent a nerve conduction study. Which findings can be certainly seen during the nerve conduction study?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP). Conduction block can certainly be seen during the nerve conduction study.

CIDP is an autoimmune condition. It has a chronic course with an onset of >9 weeks when compared with Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS) which has an acute onset. But both CIDP and GBS have similar presenting features.

The clinical features include symmetric proximal weakness. If there is involvement of the cranial nerves, external ophthalmoplegia may be seen. Some patients may also present with isolated motor or sensory involvement. If sensory involvement is present it can be seen as chronic inflammatory sensory polyradiculopathy (CISP)  or distal acquired demyelinating symmetric (DADS) variants. 

CSF is usually acellular and shows elevated protein levels. Presence of conduction blocks is a certain sign of an acquired demyelinating process. Other features that may or may not be seen in nerve conduction studies are:

  • conduction slowing (option B)
  • prolonged distal latencies (option C),
  • distal and temporal dispersion of compound muscle action potential (CMAP).
  • axonal loss (option D) can be seen secondary to demyelination.

In mild cases, expectant management is suitable. Treatment is initially started with IV immunoglobulins. Other options include glucocorticoids, plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressants.

questions.text: A male neonate of a diabetic mother presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. On auscultation, an ejection systolic murmur was heard at the left mid-sternal border. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray showing an egg-on-string appearance is suggestive of transposition of great arteries (TGA). 

TGA is cyanotic congenital heart disease and is commonly seen in infants of diabetic mothers and in male babies. It is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery originating from the left ventricle. 

Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood. This occurs via the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus in the newborn period, and also via ventricular septal defect (VSD) that is present in about 50% of infants with TGA.

 

It is a medical emergency and most infants present with cyanosis and tachypnea shortly after birth. The level of hypoxia varies depending on the degree of atrial shunt and if the ductus is partially closed or open. Loud single or split S2 and a soft systolic ejection murmur may be heard at the mid-left sternal border. 

Chest X-ray shows a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, therefore appearing like an egg. The superior mediastinum appears narrow which gives the characteristic finding of an egg-on-a-string appearance as shown below.

 

ECG may show right axis deviation. Echocardiography with doppler is confirmatory and shows the transposed ventricular-arterial connections and their size, ductus arteriosus, and the degree of mixing of blood. 

Since the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood is essential for these patients, early management includes an immediate infusion of prostaglandin E1 which keeps the ductus arteriosus patent for improving oxygenation. Rashkind balloon atrial septostomy can be done to improve the hypoxic state.
 
Other options: 

Option A: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins that results in total pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium instead of normally joining the left atrium. In supracardiac type of TAPVC, the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resemble a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign as shown below. 

 

Option B: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by the tetrad of:

  • Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  • Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Aorta overriding VSD
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

In the TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. This appears as a boot-shaped heart or Coeur en sabot on the X-ray as shown below.

 

Option C: Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease with diminished pulmonary blood flow due to abnormality of the tricuspid valve. It can occur due to the teratogenic effect of lithium. There is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium leading to an elevated apex giving a box-shaped heart as shown below.

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported in a town between June and September of 2021. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. This exemplifies:
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral Hepatitis A is an example of a point source, multiple exposures type of epidemic.

In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A occurred over a period which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a point source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is single exposure from a point source.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposures epidemics are:

  Point source, single exposure Point source, multiple exposures 
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous, or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning from an event Sex worker infected with gonorrhea, contaminated well water

Option C- Cyclic trend refers to the appearance of diseases after regular intervals. For example, influenza pandemics occur every 7-10 years, automobile accidents increase during weekends, etc.

Option D- Secular trend refers to the progressive increase or decrease of the occurrence of a disease over a very long period of time. Even though there are short-term fluctuations, it moves in a particular direction over a long period of time. Examples are coronary heart disease, lung cancer and diabetes have an upward trend, while diseases such as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, diphtheria, and polio have a declining trend.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

Related Pearl: Investigation of an Epidemic

A) Steps

  • Verification of diagnosis
  • Confirmation of existence of epidemic
  • Defining the population at risk
    • Obtaining a map of the area
    • Counting the population
  • Rapid search for all the cases
    • Medical survey
    • Epidemiological case sheets
    • Searching for more cases
  • Data analysis on the basis of time, place and person
  • Formulation of hypothesis
  • Testing of hypothesis
  • Evaluation of ecological factors
  • Further investigation of population at risk
  • Writing the report

B) Final Epidemic Report

  • Background including geography, climate, demography, socio-economic groups, health service organization, surveillance data and normal disease prevalence
  • Historical data including previous occurrences of the epidemic, occurrence of any related diseases and discovery of the primary case in present outbreak
  • Methodology of investigations including case definition, epidemiological questionnaires, collection and laboratory techniques
  • Analysis of data including clinical and epidemiological data, modes of transmission, laboratory data and all their interpretations
  • Control measures including strategy definitions, methodology of implementation, evaluation methods and preventive measures

questions.text: Droplet precautions and isolation is to be done for all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis (JE) does not require droplet precaution and isolation as it is an arboviral disease. 

Arboviral diseases are caused by arthropod-borne viruses. JE is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected mosquito. The most common vectors for JE are culicine mosquitoes, C.tritaeniorhynchus, C.vishnui, and C.gelidus. Man is a dead-end host and not known to transmit the infection to other humans. The incubation period in man is around 5 - 15 days. 

Diphtheria, pertussis, and poliomyelitis can be transmitted by droplets and hence require droplet precaution and isolation.

Other options:

Option B: Diphtheria is an acute bacterial infection that is caused by Corneybacterium diphtheriae. It is transmitted by droplet infection. The incubation period is 2 to 6 days. Affected patients are asked to isolate for 14 days. 

Option C: Pertussis is caused by Bordetella pertussis. It only affects man and is transmitted through droplet infection and direct contact. It has an incubation period of 7 to 14 days. It is most infectious during the catarrhal stage and patients are kept isolated until considered non-infectious. Prevention is only achieved through immunization. 

Option D: Poliomyelitis is caused by poliovirus which has three serotypes of which most outbreaks are caused by type-1 virus. It is transmitted via both the fecal-oral route as well by droplet infection (during the acute phase). Droplet infection can transmit the infection by close contact and is an important mechanism of transmission in developed countries where fecal transmission is remote.  It has an incubation period of 7 to 14 days.

questions.text: Following a mitral valve replacement procedure involving cardiopulmonary bypass, a patient developed acute kidney injury due to cholesterol emboli. Which of the following findings on urine microscopy is suggestive of the cause of renal failure?
questions.solution:
Eosinophiluria is likely to be seen in patients with acute kidney injury due to cholesterol emboli.

Laboratory findings of eosinophiluria is suggestive of atheroembolic etiology of renal failure.

Cholesterol emboli may be released from atherosclerotic plaques either spontaneously or commonly due to manipulation of the aorta during surgical procedures. This can result in:

  • Cerebral transient ischemic attack
  • Livedo reticularis (skin mottling) in the lower limbs
  • Hollen horst plaques in the retina
  • Acute kidney injury leading to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
  • Necrosis of the toes

Acute kidney injury may sometimes be associated with hematuria, mild proteinuria, and loss of renal function, which progresses over a few years.

Other options:

Option A: RBC casts are seen in glomerulonephritis, vasculitis, malignant hypertension, and thrombotic microangiopathy.

Option B: Granular casts may be seen in:

  • Acute kidney injury due to sepsis or ischemia
  • Vasculitis
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Tubulo interstitial nephritis

Option C: Calcium oxalate crystals are seen in cases of ethylene glycol intoxication, acute uric acid nephropathy and drugs like acyclovir, indinavir.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: In the 1980s, David Philip Vetter was a prominent case of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), who later died at the age of 12.  In such children, the defective DNA repair mechanism is:
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ).

Non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) is a mechanism by which a group of proteins mediates the recognition, processing, and direct ligation of the ends of two DNA fragments where a double-strand break in DNA has occurred. This is in contrast to homologous repair (HR), another mechanism, where an undamaged homologous DNA template is required to replace an adjacent damaged one.

The type of repair depends on the phase of cell cycles:

The phase of the cell cycle     Repair mechanism
 G0 /G1 Phase   Nonhomologous End Joining Repair
S, G2, M Phase   Homologous Repair

NHEJ deficiency confers combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) occurs due to defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Patients with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, etc. The most common form is X-linked SCID, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors and the most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.

questions.text: A researcher was conducting a study on the relationship between the bladder volume and perception of bladder fullness.  What quantity of urine is required to cause this marked sense of fullness?
questions.solution:
400 mL of urine in the bladder is required to cause this marked sense of fullness.

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL (option D).

The relationship between the intravesical pressure and volume of fluid in the bladder can be plotted in a graph and is studied by the cystometrogram.

The curve shows

  • An initial increase in pressure when there is a first increase in volume (Ia)
  • A long and flat portion which is produced with a further increase in volume (Ib);
  • A sudden, sharp increase in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered(II).
  • The law of Laplace explains the flatness of segment Ib. It states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by the radius, P= 2T/R
  • In case of the blad­der, the filling of the bladder and the radius increases with increase in the tension. Therefore, there is slight increase in pressure increase until the organ is relatively full.

questions.text: Which of the following protocols set the standard to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases internationally?
questions.solution:
The Kyoto Protocol was an internal agreement to set internationally binding emission reduction targets.

It is linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The parties committed to reduce GHGs by 18% in the period between 2013-2020.

Related Pearl: Greenhouse Effect

Greenhouse gases (GHGs) or radiatively active gases (RAGs) are gases in the atmosphere that absorb some of the upward-going, long-wave radiation after they have left the Earth’s surface. They then emit the radiation in all directions, some of it back towards the Earth’s surface. This raises the earth's temperature.

In this entire process, the earth acts as an effective insulator and the overall process is known as the greenhouse effect. The greenhouse effect has a role in global warming which is the average rise in global temperature leading to change in climate patterns.

The most important natural GHGs are:

  • Water vapor
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Methane
  • Tropospheric ozone (Stratospheric ozone is not harmful)
  • Nitrous oxide

Non-natural GHGs include chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

International protocols on climate change:

  • Kyoto Protocol:
    • Linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
    • Set internationally binding emission reduction targets for the concerned parties
    • Parties aimed to reduce GHGs by 18% from 2013-2020.
  • Paris Agreement:
    • Aims to strengthen the global response to climate change
    • Aims to maintain the global temperature rise in this century < 2°C above pre-industrial levels
    • Aims to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5°C.
    • It deals with greenhouse gas emissions mitigation, adaptation, and finance starting in the year 2020.
  • Montreal Protocol:
    • Related to the depletion of the atmospheric ozone layer, which is protective.

questions.text: An obese male patient has been recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease and hypertension. He is started on atorvastatin. Which of the following additional medication can be safely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Atenolol is a beta-blocker and an anti-hypertensive medication that can be safely prescribed along with statins like atorvastatin because atenolol does not have much interaction with statin metabolism.

Statins are hypolipidemic drugs that act by competitively inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase. This allows for a compensatory increase in LDL receptors in the liver and thereby increases LDL catabolism. 

They are well tolerated. However, they can cause notable side effects such as myopathy and liver injury. They occur commonly when statins are concurrently given with nicotinic acid, gemfibrozil, or CYP3A4 inhibitors such as:

  • Macrolide antibiotics (erythromycin/clarithromycin)
  • Ketoconazole
  • Cyclosporine
  • HIV protease inhibitors
  • Warfarin
  • Digoxin
  • Azole antifungals
  • Amiodarone

Other options: 

Option A: Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that inhibits the hepatic uptake of statins by the organic anion transporter OATP1B1 and prevents its metabolism, thereby increasing its bioavailability. Thus, the risk of toxicity of statins increases. Concurrent use of gemfibrozil with statins most commonly causes myopathy (rhabdomyolysis). 

Option C: Digoxin used concurrently with a statin can increase the risk of myopathy.

Option D: Nicotinic acid (Niacin) used concurrently with statins can cause myopathy due to inhibition of skeletal muscle cholesterol synthesis. 

Related Pearl: Metabolism of drugs

Drugs metabolized by cyp3A4 enzymes:

  • Protease inhibitors
  • Statins
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Amiodarone
  • Estrogen
  • Erythromycin

questions.text: A teenage girl comes to your clinic complaining of easy bruising. She gives a history of prolonged intake of antibiotics to treat her acne. Which among the following vitamin deficiencies might have led to her present condition?
questions.solution:
History of easy bruising after prolonged use of antibiotics is suggestive of menaquinone/vitamin K deficiency. Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency. This is due to the loss of normal bowel flora that synthesizes menaquinones (vitamin K2). Menaquinones type of vitamin K is produced by gut bacteria.

Vitamin K is required for the functioning are the blood-clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S. Vitamin K deficiency causes easy bruising, bleeding, elevated prothrombin time, and hemorrhagic disease in newborns.

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin. The following are the vitamers of vitamin K:

  • Phylloquinone (Vitamin K1) is the normal dietary source of Vitamin K that is found in green vegetables.
  • Menaquinone (Vitamin K2) is synthesized by intestinal bacteria.
  • Menadione (Vitamin K3) is a synthetic compound that is metabolized to phylloquinone.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old lady who recently went in for an IUCD contraception has increasing pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before her menses begin. The pain is relieved once the menses starts. What is the clinical diagnosis in this case?

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
Pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before menses are suggestive of congestive dysmenorrhea.

Dysmenorrhea is defined as cramping pain that occurs during menstruation.

It can be classified as:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhea is a type of dysmenorrhoea that is not associated with any pelvic pathology. It affects women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles.
  • Secondary (Acquired) dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and endometriosis. 

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most common and is characterized by cramping pain on the first and second days of menstruation. 
  • Congestive dysmenorrhea presents as worsening pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain, a few days before the onset of menses followed by relief of the symptoms. This is seen in PID, IUCD users, varicosities of pelvic veins, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea is rare and is characterized by crampy pain that occurs with the passage of the endometrium as a cast at the time of menstruation.

Primary dysmenorrhea can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), combined oral contraceptive pills, and progestin-only pills. GnRH agonists and androgens are also useful. Surgical management includes hysterectomy and is indicated if not responding to medical management. In secondary dysmenorrhea, treating the cause is needed.

Fibromyalgia is a disorder with diffuse musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It is associated with irritable bowel syndrome, anxiety, and depression. There is no cure for fibromyalgia as of now, although the symptoms can be controlled by medications. Researchers believe that fibromyalgia amplifies painful sensations by affecting the way your brain processes pain signals.

questions.text: A patient under alcohol rehabilitation comes with complaints of green-colored vaginal discharge and pruritus. She was prescribed metronidazole. Which of the following reactions should be kept in mind while prescribing this drug?
questions.solution:
The history of greenish vaginal discharge along with pruritus is suggestive of trichomoniasis. This is effectively treated by metronidazole, but disulfiram-like reactions should be kept in mind while prescribing the drug. 

Disulfiram is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor and is used in disulfiram aversion therapy to reduce alcohol dependence. If alcohol is ingested after taking disulfiram, there is an increase in blood acetaldehyde concentration that causes symptoms such as flushing, burning sensation,vomiting, perspiration, tightness of chest, dizziness, throbbing headache, visual disturbance, etc. Knowledge of this may help the patient to resist drinking.

Disulfiram-like reaction is the same reaction mentioned above that has been noted in patients who take the following drugs with alcohol:

  • Metronidazole
  • Sulfonylureas
  • Cefoperazone
  • Procarbazine
  • Griseofulvin

 Other options: 

Option A: Cheese reaction occurs due to ingestion of products with large quantities of tyramine by patients who are on monoamine oxidase inhibitors. It causes the release of large amounts of noradrenaline causing a hypertensive crisis or cerebrovascular accidents. 

Option C: Acute adrenal insufficiency is a withdrawal syndrome that is precipitated by an abrupt cessation of corticosteroid therapy. There is malaise, fever, pain in muscle and joints, as well as reactivation of the disease that the steroid was used for.  

Option D: Reversal reaction is seen in leprosy and is caused due to delayed hypersensitivity to M.leprae antigens. There is cutaneous ulceration and multiple nerve involvement with swollen and painful nerves.

questions.text: The photostress test is used to differentiate between diseases involving?
questions.solution:
The photostress test is used to differentiate between the disease involving the macula and optic nerve.

Photo receptor test is an ophthalmic test used to check for the photoreceptors functioning. It is mainly useful in the detection of macular diseases and central serous retinopathy. 

Procedure of the test: 

In this test, one eye of the patient is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A brief stimulation with bright light for 15 seconds is given to the uncovered eye. Following this the patient is asked to read the line again and the recovery time is noted. The test is repeated in the other eye as well. 

The interpretation of the results are as follows:

  • Macular disease - the recovery time is prolonged usually by >1/3rd of the normal recovery time. This is because, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process
  • Optic nerve disease - the recovery time is not affected
  • No ocular disease - recovery time is not affected

questions.text:
A child is brought by his mother with complaints of cough, dyspnea, and dysphagia. On examination, stridor is present and the child keeps his head extended during the entire period. Given below is the X-ray of the child. Which of the following forms the treatment option for this child?
  1. Incision and drainage
  2. Topical antibiotics
  3. Tracheostomy
  4. Systemic antibiotics
  5. Interval tonsillectomy
questions.solution:
The given image and clinical scenario of cough, dyspnea, and dysphagia are suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess, with respiratory obstruction. The treatment options for retropharyngeal abscess include incision and drainage of the abscess, systemic antibiotics, and tracheostomy to relieve the obstruction.

The features that are seen in the x-ray include :

  • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow
  • In an acute abscess, the gas formation can be seen.

Etiology:

Commonly seen in children below 3 years. It is the result of suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to infection in the adenoids, nasopharynx, etc., In adults, it may result from penetrating injury of the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus. 

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing
  • Stridor
  • Croupy cough
  • Torticollis
  • A bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall

Diagnosis can be diagnosed on a lateral x-ray of the soft tissues of the neck.

Other options:

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess(Prevertebral abscess):

This is commonly seen in adults who have caries of the cervical spine or tuberculosis of retropharyngeal lymph nodes. The clinical features include discomfort in the throat and dysphagia. On examination, a fluctuant swelling on either side or in the midline is noted. 

The treatment options include incision and drainage of abscess with or without antitubercular therapy.

Interval tonsillectomy is done for peritonsillar abscess.

questions.text: A mother brings her infant after noticing the child is dyspnoeic. An echocardiogram showed multiple masses in the ventricles causing obstruction to blood flow. Following surgical resection, the histopathologic reports of the mass showed spider cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An infant's echocardiogram showing multiple cardiac masses in the ventricle which on histopathology shows spider cells suggests a likely diagnosis of rhabdomyoma.

Rhabdomyomas are the most common pediatric primary cardiac tumor and are seen during the first years of life. They are commonly noted during evaluation for valvular or other flow obstructive causes. Around one-half of the cardiac rhabdomyomas are due to sporadic mutations while the other half are associated with tuberous sclerosis

They are gray-white myocardial masses that are usually multiple in number and are mostly seen involving the ventricles and protruding into the lumen. Microscopically, they consist of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Routine histologic processing removes the glycogen and artifactually reduces the cytoplasm to thin strands stretching from nucleus to surface membrane. These appear to look like spider cells. 

They are considered hamartomatous as they often undergo spontaneous regression. Surgical resection is only indicated if the tumors cause obstruction.

The image below shows histopathological findings of cardiac rhabdomyoma with spider cells.

Other options:

Option A: Papillary fibroelastomas are sea-anemone-shaped endocardial tumors and are mainly present on valves. They are usually incidental but become clinically important if they embolize.

Option B: Myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults. They are benign Unlike rhabdomyomas and single and the common site of origin is the region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an abundant acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. There are characteristic vessel-like or glandlike structures.

Option D: Paragangliomas are rare chromaffin cell tumors and are a form of extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma. They are highly vascular and can be hormonally active causing uncontrolled hypertension.

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady presents with symmetric and proximal muscle weakness for the past few weeks. She has no history of dysphagia or dysarthria and no cutaneous lesions were seen on examination. On evaluating her further, creatinine kinase levels were elevated and muscle biopsy shows the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with elevated levels of creatinine kinase (CK) and muscle biopsy showing non-specific inflammatory cells in endomysial locations is suggest the most likely diagnosis to be polymyositis.

Polymyositis is one of the inflammatory myopathies characterized by symmetric and proximal muscle weakness. This weakness usually worsens over several weeks to months. 

It is more common in women. Most patients improve with immunotherapies, but they require lifelong treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Inclusion body myositis is characterized by asymmetric weakness of wrist and finger flexors in arms and quadriceps in legs. Dysphagia is also commonly seen. It is common in adults >50 years of age. CK levels are normal or slightly elevated. Antibodies against 5' nucleotidase are seen in the blood. 

Option C: Dermatomyositis (DM) characterized by symmetrical and proximal muscle weakness. The dermatological manifestations of DM include: 

  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discoloration of the eyelid with periorbital edema
  • Gottron sign - erythematous rash over joints
  • Gottron papules - raised erythematous rash over knuckles
  • V rash - over sun-exposed areas 

It can present in adults as well as children. It has a high risk for malignancies. CK levels can be normal or elevated. Histology shows perifascicular atrophy and perivascular inflammatory infiltrates. 

The images below show: Heliotrope rash, Gottron papules and V rash respectively. 

Option D: Necrotising autoimmune myopathy is characterized by acute onset of symmetric and proximal muscle weakness, dysphagia, dysarthria, and myalgia. It is associated with an underlying connective tissue disorder or cancer. CK levels are markedly elevated. Histology shows multifocal necrotic and regenerating muscle fibers with a paucity of inflammatory cells.
