questions.text: A female patient comes to the casualty ward after noticing the passage of blood instead of urine at night. Laboratory investigations show pancytopenia and elevated LDH levels. The findings of flow cytometry of blood are shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history and flow cytogram showing a population of red blood cells deficient in both CD55 and CD59 suggest a likely diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

PNH is a chronic acquired hemolytic anemia that occurs due to mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A (PIGA) gene. PIGA is an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.

Thus, PNH blood cells are deficient in three glycosylphosphatidylinositols (GPI) linked proteins that regulate complement activity:

  • Decay accelerating factors or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

The most important of these is CD59, which is the potent inhibitor of C3 convertase. It prevents the spontaneous activation of the alternative complement pathway. Red cells deficient in these GPI-linked factors are susceptible to lysis or injury by the C5b - C9 membrane attack complex.

Clinically, the patient would have hemolysis, pancytopenia, and a tendency for venous thrombosis. Intravascular hemolysis may be nocturnal and paroxysmal or chronic hemolysis without the dramatic hemoglobinuria. Some patients may complain of recurrent attacks of abdominal pain that may be related to thrombosis in abdominal veins. 

Investigations show iron deficiency anemia (due to chronic hemoglobinuria), and elevated LDH levels. The gold standard for diagnosis is flow cytometry which would be CD59 and CD55 negative. 

Flow cytometry: It shows a population of red cells that is deficient in both CD55 and CD59 (left-lower quadrant in the image below). Also, a second population of red cells, which are derived from residual normal hematopoietic stem cells may be seen, which are positive for CD55 and CD59 (right-upper quadrant in the image below).

 

Eculizumab is used in treatment. It is a monoclonal antibody that prevents the conversion of the complement C5 to C5a.  

Other options: 

Option A: Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant disorder that causes the loss of red cell membrane leading to its conversion to a spherocyte. The spherocytes are phagocytosed by the spleen causing red cell destruction. Clinically, patients present with anemia and splenomegaly. 

Option C: Warm antibody immune hemolytic anemia is caused by antibodies that bind to red blood cells at 37 degrees Celsius. It may be idiopathic, or secondarily caused by drugs such as alpha-methyldopa, other autoimmune diseases such as SLE, or lymphoid neoplasms. Autoimmune hemolytic anemias can also be caused by other antibodies such as cold agglutinin type (binds to RBCs at 0 to 4 degrees Celsius) or cold hemolysin type (causing paroxysmal cold hemoglobin type). 

Option D: Disseminated intravascular coagulation is a thrombohemorragic disorder caused by excessive coagulation. This causes the consumption of platelets and coagulation factors leading to bleeding, vascular occlusion, and tissue hypoxemia. Here, red blood cells undergo traumatic damage while passing through lumens filled with thrombi. This causes intravascular hemolysis known as microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. The most common triggers are major trauma, sepsis, and obstetric complications.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with regurgitation of food and exacerbated nocturnal cough for a week. He also notices gurgling sounds while swallowing. On barium fluoroscopic examination, the given finding is seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis​?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and barium swallow showing a fraction of the ingested barium sulfate being trapped in a pharyngeal pouch in the cervical esophagus suggests a diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum. 

Zenker diverticulum, otherwise known as cricopharyngeal achalasia/pharyngeal pouch, is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum (false diverticula occurring due to motor disorder causing increased intraluminal pressure). It results from the herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle (dehiscence of Killian).

Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus (shown below).

 

It is usually seen in the seventh decade of life and is thought to occur due to loss of muscle tone and elasticity causing incomplete relaxation. The impaired relaxation and spasms of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing results in increased pressure within the distal pharynx and the development of Zenker's diverticulum.

Patients complain of dysphagia, halitosis, recurrent regurgitation, and respiratory infections. The most serious complications are aspiration pneumonia and lung abscess.

Diagnosis is by barium swallow studies and video laryngoscopy. The gold standard of treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The transoral endoscopic approach is known as the Dohlman procedure in which the common wall between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus is ablated using laser, electrocautery, or stapler devices. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size. Lesions less than 2 cm are managed with myotomy. A sac more than 5 cm is usually excised.

Other options:

Option A: Epiphrenic diverticula is a pulsion pseudodiverticula that arises from the terminal third of the thoracic esophagus (next to the diaphragm). They are often associated with diffuse spasm, achalasia, and other esophageal motor abnormalities. 

Option B: Achalasia is a type of esophageal motility disorder and a premalignant condition that occurs due to hypertension of the lower esophageal sphincter and thereby failure to relax. The classic triad of presentation is dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. Esophagogram shows the classic bird beak appearance (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing). 

Option D: Lateral pharyngeal diverticulum, otherwise known as a pharyngocele, is the herniation of the lateral pharyngeal wall in the piriform recess or vallecula. Patients are often asymptomatic or may complain of dysphagia, neck mass, cervical pain, etc. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 3-year-old unimmunized child is brought to the emergency room with high-grade fever, drooling of saliva, and dysphagia. Auscultation revealed inspiratory stridor. His lateral X-ray of neck is given below. The next best step in his management is?

choices.text: Secure airway and start empirical IV ceftriaxone
Give antipyretics and reassure the patient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever, drooling, dysphagia, and inspiratory stridor along with the lateral X-ray neck showing the thumb sign suggests acute epiglottitis. The next best step in his management is to secure airway and start empirical IV ceftriaxone.

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammatory condition of supra-glottic structures, i.e. epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and arytenoid. It is also known as supraglottic laryngitis and is a medical emergency. 

It commonly affects children aged 2–7 years. The most common organism responsible for this is Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib). 

Clinical features include high-grade fever, dysphagia, drooling of saliva, sore throat, dyspnea, and inspiratory stridor.The patient usually adopts a tripod position by leaning forward on his arms and has his neck extended with his chin up and breathing through the mouth. Airway obstruction occurs due to inflammation and edema of the surrounding structures. 

The direct laryngoscopic shows an inflamed and swollen epiglottis that has a characteristic cherry-red-colored appearance. A lateral X-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis giving an appearance called the thumb sign (shown below). 

Treatment includes: 

  • Immediate hospitalization 
  • Securing airway by endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or by tracheostomy, irrespective of the degree of respiratory obstruction
  • Empirical management by third-generation cephalosporins (cefotaxime, ceftriaxone) or ampicillin
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema
  • Humidified oxygen can also be given

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

questions.text: Calculate hepatic clearance of a drug with hepatic blood flow of 2000 mL/min and hepatic extraction ratio of 0.5.
questions.solution:
The hepatic clearance of the given drug is 1000 mL/min.

Clearance of a drug by an organ is the difference between the rate of presentation of the drug to the organ and the rate of exit of the drug from the organ. It is calculated by the equation:

CLorgan = Q x E

Where, 

  • Q - Organ blood flow 
  • E - Extraction ratio (organ-specific)

The question shows that the hepatic blood flow (Q) is 2000 mL/min and the hepatic extraction ratio (E) is 0.5.

Substituting the values in the above equation, 

CLorgan = 2000 X 0.5 = 1000 mL/min

Note: The extraction ratio (E) is the fraction of the drug that is removed from the blood by the eliminating organ.

Extraction ratio (E) = CA-CV/CA

Where,

  • CA is the concentration of drug presented to the organ
  • CA-CV is the drug removed by the organ

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought with complaints of diarrhea and blood loss to the outpatient department. A stool examination showed  Ancylostoma dudoenale.  All of the given statements regarding Ancylostoma dudoenale are true except:

choices.text: Eggs are shed in faeces of an infected individual
Man and soil are known reservoirs
It can enter the human body through penetration of skin
Immediate source of infection is soil

questions.solution:
The given scenario of diarrhea, blood loss, and stool examination showing the presence of Ancylostoma dudoenale is suggestive of hookworm infection. Man is the only known reservoir of this condition. 

A reservoir is any person, animal, arthropod, plant, soil, or substance in which an infectious agent can live, multiply, and is transmissible to the susceptible host. 

The two main nematodes causing hookworm infection in humans are  Ancylostoma dudoenale and Necator americanus. The affected individuals can present with blood loss, diarrhea, and iron deficiency anemia. The adult hookworms reside in the small intestine (mainly jejunum) and are attached to the villi. The female worm can lay thousands of eggs which are passed in feces.

Larvae rapidly develop when these eggs land on warm, moist soil, and the egg hatches after 1 to 2 days. This soil contaminated with the infective larvae of this organism is the immediate source of infection. The feces containing the ova of the organisms are considered the infective material. The filariform larvae can enter the human body through penetration of skin or ingestion by mouth.

questions.text: An unimmunized boy developed conjunctivitis and bluish-white spots on his buccal mucosa. Four days later, he developed a rash, as shown below. What is the incubation period for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of conjunctivitis, bluish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Koplik's spots), and the image showing widespread maculopapular rash are suggestive of measles. The approximate period between the exposure to the infection and the appearance of symptoms (incubation period) is 10 to 14 days. 

Measles is an infection caused by Paramyxovirus which is a single-stranded lipid enveloped RNA virus. It is spread 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash through body secretions. The patient should be isolated for a week from the onset of the rash to prevent spreading. Infected cells are found fused together to form multinucleated giant cells called Warthin - Finkeldey cells. 

The image below shows a slide of a lymph node biopsy showing a Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell: 

The clinical features are mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. The Koplik spots are red lesions with bluish-white spots seen in the inner cheeks at the level of premolars. 

The image below shows Koplik spots: 

The red maculopapular rashes begin on the forehead, behind the ears, and on the upper neck on the 4th day. It then spreads towards the torso, and extremities and reaches the palms and soles. 

The image of the maculopapular rash is shown below: 

The diagnosis is mainly made clinically but serological demonstration of IgM antibodies and IgG antibodies are also used. Complications are pneumonia, croup, tracheitis etc. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a nearly fatal complication of chronic measles diagnosed by elevated IgG levels in cerebrospinal fluid. 

Measles can be prevented by active immunisation. Live attenuated vaccine is given subcutaneously except for immunocompromised and pregnant women. According to WHO it requires at least 96% immunisation coverage under one year of age for eradication.

Chickenpox 14 - 21 days

Erythema infectiosum 4 - 14 days

Related Pearl: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine:

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.

questions.text:
A middle-aged patient comes to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of hearing loss. On tuning fork examination of the patient, inferences were recorded, as shown below. What will be the likely inference of Schwabach's test in this patient?
Tuning fork test Right ear Left ear
Rinne's test AC>BC  BC>AC
Weber's test Lateralisation to the left
Absolute bone conduction (ABC) test  Normal

AC- Air conduction

BC- Bone conduction

choices.text: Lengthier than that of the examiner
Shorter than that of the examiner
Same as that of the examiner
Difficult to interpret with the given data

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of conductive deafness in the left ear, and Schwabach’s test shows bone conduction duration lengthier than that of the examiner.

The patient here complains of hearing loss. Rinne's test showing BC>AC in the left ear, Weber's test lateralizing to the left ear, and a normal ABC test are suggestive of conductive deafness in his left ear.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration, while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus(EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive(normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15 - 20 dB.

 Weber test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex, and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • Normal result is achieved when the sound is heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worse ear.
  • In sensorineural deafness it is lateralized to the better ear.

In the absolute bone conduction(ABC) test, the patient’s bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner after occluding( by pressing the tragus inwards) EAC of both the patient and the examiner to prevent the ambient noise from entering through the AC route. It is used to assess cochlear deafness.

  • Normal result: The test result is the same as the examiner.
  • Conductive deafness: The test result is the same as the examiner.
  • Sensorineural deafness: test result reduced than that of the examiner.

In Schwabach's test, the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the examiner, but unlike the absolute bone conduction test, the EAC is not occluded. Inferences are as follows:

  • Normal: The test result is the same as that of the examiner
  • Conductive deafness: Test result is lengthier than that of the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness: Test result is shorter than that of the examiner

Note: The ABC test and Schwabach's test are done assuming the hearing of the examiner is normal.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, red-colored urine, and frequent sinusitis. Her blood reports revealed anemia, leucocytosis, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Serology is positive for antiproteinase-3 ANCA. Her chest x-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (frequent sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (hemoptysis), and kidneys (hematuria), and an x-ray shows the presence of a cavity in the right lung. These, along with laboratory features and positivity for antiproteinase-3 ANCA (cANCA) suggest that the most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).

GPA is a type of vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas in the upper and lower respiratory tract, and small and medium vessels. Also, necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis is present in the condition.

Clinically, they present with fever, purulent rhinorrhea, nasal ulcers, sinus pain, saddle nose, polyarthralgia, cough, hemoptysis, breathlessness, hematuria, and proteinuria. Occasionally, cutaneous purpura and mononeuritis complex may be present.

Antiproteinase 3-ANCA or antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (cANCA) is seen in 95% of patients and is a useful marker of disease activity.

Management is as follows:

  • Induction with cyclophosphamide and glucocorticoids for severe disease. This is stopped after 3-6 months and can be switched to rituximab, azathioprine, methotrexate, and mycophenolate mofetil for the remission.
  • Induction with rituximab and glucocorticoids is also effective in severe disease.
  • For a non-severe disease, methotrexate or mycophenolate mofetil along with glucocorticoids is effective for induction as well as remission.

Other options:

Options A - In Goodpasture's syndrome (pulmonary-renal syndrome), anti-GBM autoantibodies are formed against the glomerular basement membrane. Younger patients present with hemoptysis, fever, dyspnea, and hematuria while older people present with isolated glomerulonephritis.

Option B - Microscopic polyangiitis mainly involves the small arterioles and venules. The presentation is similar to GPA. However, they do not have upper airway disease or pulmonary nodules. They have mainly MPO antibodies or P-ANCA positivity. The distinction can be made on a biopsy where microscopic polyangiitis would have vasculitis without granulomas. 

Option C - Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a small vessel vasculitis that has palpable purpura over the buttocks and lower extremities, arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms, and glomerulonephritis. It is commonly seen in children and the mechanism is immune complex deposition with IgA antibody.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with left flank pain, varicocele, hematuria, and headache. On examination, BP was 170/100 mm Hg. CT abdomen was done and a diagnosis of Nutcracker syndrome was made. What is the cause?

choices.text: Compression of left renal vein between abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery
Compression of  left renal vein between inferior vena cava and superior mesenteric vein
Compression of right renal vein between abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery
Compression of right renal vein between inferior vena cava and superior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
The most likely cause is compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery. This manifests as nutcracker syndrome.

Nutcracker syndrome is characterized by left renal vein hypertension, which occurs due to the compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. This is because the left renal vein is posterior and inferior to the superior mesenteric artery.

The left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein. It runs anterior to the aorta just below the origin of the superior mesenteric artery and drains into the inferior vena cava after crossing the midline.

Note: The left kidney is preferred in donor nephrectomy than the right because of the long course of the left renal vein.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the bony labyrinth?
questions.solution:
The Endolymphatic duct is not a part of the bony labyrinth. It is a part of membranous labyrinth.

The bony labyrinth consists of three parts, namely the semicircular canals, cochlea, and the vestibule.

The semicircular canals (SCC) are part of the bony labyrinth. They house the semicircular ducts which are the end organs for angular momentum. They are 3 in number:

  • Superior SCC also called anterior SCC, on X-axis.
  • Posterior SCC on Y-axis.
  • Lateral SCC is also called horizontal SCC, on Z-axis.

The bony cochlea is a coiled tube with 2.5 to 2.75 turns. The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are part of the bony labyrinth and are filled with perilymph. They communicate with each other at the apex called helicotrema. The tube coils around a central pyramid of bone called modiolus. From the modiolus laterally into the tube winding like the thread of a screw is the osseous spiral lamina.

The vestibule is the central chamber of the labyrinth and the oval window lies in its lateral wall. It has two recesses which lodge the saccule and the utricle. It has 5 openings of semicircular canal and an opening of aqueduct of vestibule. 

The membranous labyrinth consists of the cochlear duct (membranous cochlea or the scala media), utricle and saccule, three semicircular ducts, and the endolymphatic duct and sac. Scala media contains the sensory component, the organ of corti with hair cells.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with abdominal distension and gross hematuria. On examination, a palpable mass in the right flank and moderate hypertension are noted. A provisional diagnosis of Wilm's tumor is made. All the given features correspond to the respective syndromes involving Wilm's tumor except:
questions.solution:
In Wilm's tumor, the given finding of gonadal dysgenesis is associated with Denys-Drash syndrome and not with Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome. 

Wilms tumour, also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. It is the 2nd most common malignant abdominal tumor in childhood after neuroblastoma. Loss of function mutation of the WT1 gene on chromosome 11p13 is commonly seen in Wilms tumours.

The clinical presentation of Wilms tumor are:

  • Incidental discovery of asymptomatic abdominal mass
  • Hypertension
  • Abdominal pain 
  • Gross painless hematuria. 

The syndromes associated with Wilms tumor are: 

  • WAGR syndrome - aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, mental retardation
  • Denys-Drash syndrome - early-onset renal failure, gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudohermaphroditism)
  • Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome - hemihypertrophy, organomegaly, macroglossia
  • Fraiser syndrome
  • Fanconi anaemia
  • Trisomy 18
  • Perlman syndrome

The diagnosis can be confirmed by radiological investigations like CT, abdominal ultrasound, and biopsy. Histologically, Wilm's tumour is made of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cells.

Treatment depends on the stage of the disease and includes: Surgery, and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy.

questions.text: In a primary health center, a nurse asks you about using a polio vaccine vial which has not crossed its expiry date. You look at the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) and tell her that it can be used. What did the VVM most likely show?

choices.text: Inner square white, outer circle blue
Inner square blue, outer circle white
Outer square white, inner circle blue
Outer square blue, inner circle white

questions.solution:
The vaccine vial monitor has most likely showed inner square white and outer circle blue.

The standard polio vaccine vial monitor has a colour monitor or labels on the vaccine bottles. The label has an inner white square and an outer blue circle.

It can be used if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle. When the colour of the inner square becomes that of the circle, it means that the vaccine has been exposed to a higher temperature and it cannot be used. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: An intern noticed the following findings while removing the catheter in a 30-year-old patient.  A manual reduction was attempted but was unsuccessful and hence a dorsal slit was made. Surgery was planned 3 weeks later.  Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition and the definitive procedure, done for this patient?

choices.text: It is precipitated after sexual intercourse
It is associated with dorsal chordee

questions.solution:
The clinical history and the image showing swollen glans are suggestive of paraphimosis and circumcision is the definitive procedure done after 3 weeks. It is not associated with dorsal chordee but can lead to ventral chordee. 

Paraphimosis is a condition in which the retracted prepuceal skin over the glans cannot be placed back as a result of which a ring-like constriction is seen proximal to the corona and prepuceal skin. 

This leads to pain and swelling of the glans. Sexual intercourse and urethral catheterization can precipitate the condition. 

Treatment includes manual reduction of the skin. When it is not possible, a dorsal slit has to be made to relieve the pain and compression along with analgesics and antibiotics. This is followed by circumcision after 3 weeks. Alternatively, Sedation and multiple hyaluronidase injection in 10 ml saline are injected to reduce edema followed by circumcision. 

Circumcision is a surgical procedure which involves cutting the dorsal skin up to the corona later extending it circumferentially and ventrally. 

Indications for circumcision include

  • Religious
  • Phimosis - In this condition, the prepuce cannot be retracted over the glans.
  • Paraphimosis after doing initial dorsal slit
  • Balanitis and balanoposthitis - Balanitis is the inflammation of the glans, whereas balanoposthitis involves both glans and prepuce
  • Early carcinoma of the glans penis or prepuce—Here it is both diagnostic as well as therapeutic
  • Certain sexually transmitted diseases, e.g. herpes infection

Complications:

  • Infection
  • Reactionary hemorrhage - It can be due to slippage of ligature from the frenular artery and dorsal vein
  • Urethral stricture near the external meatus in children
  • Chordee due to removal of excess skin on the ventral aspect-Ventral chordee
  • Priapism can occur rarely

questions.text: A researcher during a study notices that, when a person consumes food, the stomach was able to accommodate the food with no or minor increase in pressure. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The mechanism responsible for the given process is receptive relaxation.

Receptive relaxation is a process in which the gastric fundus is dilated with the passage of food into the pharynx and esophagus. The reflex is vagally mediated.

It is a wave of relaxation transmitted through myenteric inhibitory neurons to the entire stomach and duodenum. This helps in accommodating the food reaching the stomach from the esophagus. 

Other options:

Option A: Gastroileal reflex is a vasovagal reflex wherein relaxation of the caecum occurs when the food leaves the stomach and there is increased passage of chyme through the ileocecal valve. 

Option C: Segmentation contraction is a pattern in the contraction of the small intestines that promotes the mixing of the food with intestinal secretions. In this phenomenon, the small intestine contracts at irregularly spaced intervals resulting in a chain of sausages-like appearance. When one set of contractions subsides, a new set of contractions begins at different sites.

Option D: Hunger contractions are rhythmic peristaltic contractions that occur in the body of the stomach when the stomach has been empty for a long time.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following finding. Which of the following conditions is the patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
The given finding in the image is clubbing, hence the patient is unlikely to have COPD. Clubbing is not a sign of COPD. 

In case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD then a possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterized by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window gets obliterated. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

questions.text: A young woman was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. She opens her eyes to painful stimuli, but her speech is confused. She can localize pain on the right side, but withdraws from pain on the left side. What is her Glasgow Coma Scale score?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of the patient is 11 and her component score is E2V4M5.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury. It has three components: eye-opening, verbal, and motor abilities. Each component is assigned a score, and the total score is presented as a sum of three.

  • Eye-opening: To painful stimulus = 2 
  • Verbal response: Confused = 4
  • Motor response: Localize the pain on the right side = 5

In GCS, the best motor response elicited is considered for scoring. As seen in this patient, if she can localize the pain on the right side but withdraws from pain on the left side, then the motor component of the right side would be considered, and the score would be 5. Therefore, her component score would be E2V4M5 and adding 2+4+5 gives a score of 11.

A GCS score of <8 denotes severe brain injury.

  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: You are an intern examining a 68-year-old male patient who is a known case of rheumatic heart disease. You are able to feel a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. What is the type of pulse?
questions.solution:
A 68-year-old male patient who is a known case of rheumatic heart disease with a bifid pulse is suggestive of aortic regurgitation and the type of pulse which can be felt is pulsus bisferiens.

Pulsus bisferens is a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. It can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Advanced aortic regurgitation (AR)
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Other types of peripheral pulses seen in aortic regurgitation are: 

  • Water hummer /Corrigan's pulse (option A) is one that collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls during late systole and diastole.
  • Quincke's pulse (option B) is seen when pressure is applied at the tip of the nail. It causes alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail.

Pulsus paradoxus (option D) is characterized by a fall in systolic blood pressure (SBP)> 10 mm Hg during inspiration. It is seen in patients with: 

  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Hemorrhagic shock
  • Obstructive lung disease and
  • Tension pneumothorax. 

The below image shows different arterial pressure waves.

questions.text: A child is brought to the clinic with the following pigmented lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image suggests the most likely diagnosis to be compound naevus. It is characterized by a hyperpigmented papule surrounded by a symmetrical, lighter brown, macular area.

A compound naevus is a slightly raised, oval, or round papule with a symmetrical shape. This naevus is also pigmented, with shades of brown according to the patient’s skin color.

Based on the position of melanocyte aggregates, the acquired melanocytic naevi can be classified into:

  1. Junctional - melanocytes in the dermo-epidermal junction
  2. Compound - melanocytes in the dermo-epidermal junction and dermis
  3. Dermal - melanocytes in the dermis

questions.text:
A 3-day-old neonate has a fever, drowsiness, and signs of raised intracranial pressure. Blood culture revealed gram-positive cocci in chains, that were CAMP test positive and caused β-hemolysis on blood sheep agar. What is the causative organism of the baby's condition?

CAMP- Christie, Atkins, and Munch-Peterson
ICT - Intracranial tension
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of meningitis caused by Streptococcus agalactiae (aka group B beta-hemolytic streptococcus). 

S. agalactiae is a capsulated Gram-positive coccus occurring in chains. It causes meningitis in the neonatal period. Infection is commonly acquired from the maternal vagina during birth. There are two clinical types seen in neonates:
  • Early-onset type(more common) presents within a week of birth as meningitis or septicemia and is often fatal.
  • Late-onset type presents between the second to twelfth week of life commonly as septicemia.

The CAMP test is used to identify group B,  β-streptococci (based on their ability to form CAMP factor). CAMP factor causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed from staphylococcus aureus when streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to a staphylococcus aureus grown on blood agar. This gives the characteristic arrow-head zone of hemolysis as shown below.

The disease can be prevented by screening mothers at 35-37 weeks of gestation. Administering intravenous ampicillin to mothers with Streptococcus agalactiae colonizing their genital tract prevents subsequent Streptococcus agalactiae infection in the infant.

Treatment of the affected baby can be done using beta-lactam antibiotics such as ampicillin or penicillin.

Other options : 

Option A: Neisseria meningitidis is a gram-negative bacteria that can cause meningitis. 

Option B: Hemophilius influenza is a gram-negative bacteria that requires special growth factors X and V for their culture. 
 
Option C: Streptococcus pneumoniae is gram-positive but exhibits alpha hemolysis on blood agar.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with a history of nasal stuffiness, blood-stained nasal discharge, swelling of the cheek, loosening of teeth, and weight loss. On examination, there is an expansion of the alveolus and palate. Investigations confirmed maxillary sinus carcinoma. Which among the following is true about the condition?

choices.text: Growths situated posterosuperior to Ohngren’s line have a good prognosis
The most common variety is squamous cell carcinoma
Submandibular and upper jugular nodes are not enlarged
It is more commonly seen in young females

questions.solution:
The most common variety of maxillary sinus carcinoma is squamous cell carcinoma.

Maxillary sinus carcinoma arises from the sinus lining and is more commonly seen in males and in people aged 40-60 years. Those engaged in nickel refining show a higher incidence of this cancer. The most common variety is squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

Early features of maxillary sinus carcinoma may present with vague symptoms of sinusitis. Other early features of SCC of the maxillary sinus are nasal stuffiness, blood-stained nasal discharge, facial paraesthesias or pain, and epiphora. Maxillary sinus carcinoma may remain silent for a long time and then spreads to destroy the maxillary sinus and invades the surrounding structures.

The late features of SCC of the maxillary sinus depend on the direction and extent of spread. Some examples are as follows:

  • Medial spread causes nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis.
  • Inferior spread causes expansion of alveolus with dental pain, loosening of teeth, poor fitting of dentures, ulceration of gingiva, and swelling in the hard palate.
  • Anterior spread causes swelling of the cheek and later invasion of the facial skin.
  • Superior spread causes proptosis, diplopia, ocular pain, and epiphora.
  • Enlargement of submandibular and upper jugular nodes is seen in maxillary sinus SCC.

Ohngren’s line extends from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. According to Ohngren’s classification, growths situated anteroinferior to this line have a better prognosis than growths posterosuperior to it.

The image given below shows Ohngren’s line:


A CT scan (coronal as well as axial planes) helps in staging the disease and is the best non-invasive method to find the extent of the disease.

Treatment of early cases (Stages I and II) is done with surgery and removal of the tumor. Late stages(stage III and IV) are treated with combined modalities of surgery and radiation. The five-year survival rate is (40-50%).

questions.text: You are encountering a case at the forensics department where the victim's body had an entry wound from a shotgun as shown below. What is the most likely distance range of the shot?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a central rat-hole with peripheral satellite pellet holes appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun. So it was most likely shot at a distance range of 1-5 meters.

Contact shot

    • The diameter of the wound is approximately the same as that of the muzzle.

  • Soot soiling

questions.text: A patient who has been under treatment for chronic lymphocytic leukemia is noted to have a rapidly progressing mass involving the spleen. Histopathology of the mass shows large cell lymphocytes with a diffuse pattern of growth. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a rapidly progressing tumor involving the spleen in a patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and showing large cell lymphocytes on histopathology suggests a likely diagnosis of Richter syndrome.

Richter syndrome refers to the transformation of CLL into a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). There is a development of rapidly enlarging mass that involves a lymph node or spleen. It is an aggressive tumor and most patients with the syndrome survive less than a year.

DLBCL is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is characteristically of large cell type and shows a diffuse pattern of growth. The most frequent pathological abnormality seen is dysregulation of BCL6.

Mature B-cell tumors express CD19 and CD20 markers. Special subtypes of DLBCL include immunodeficiency-assosciated large B-cell lymphoma and primary effusion lymphoma.

 

Other options:

Option A: Kostmann syndrome is a form of congenital neutropenia caused by genetic mutation that leads to impaired granulocytic differentiation. 

Option B: Mantle cell lymphoma is a non-hodgkin lymphoma that presents at fifth or sixth decade and has male predominance. Clinically, there is painless lymphadenopathy and can involve spleen and gut. Morphologically, there is proliferation of small lymphocytes with irregular nuclear contours.

Option D: Burkitt lymphoma can include endemic, sporadic, and lymphoma asssociated with HIV. Almost all endemic Burkitt lymphomas are latently infected with EBV. Clinically, it presents as a mass involving the mandible or abdominal viscera. Histopathologically, the tumor has high mitotic index and contains multiple apoptotic cells. The nucelar remnants are phagocytosed by benign macrophages which give a characteristic starry sky appearance.

questions.text: A man presented with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and tender hepatomegaly. The causative agent of his condition is shown below. What is the definitive host of this organism?

The clinical features are fever, tender hepatomegaly, right upper quadrant pain, and eosinophilia. Diagnosis is made by the detection of eggs in stool and aspirated bile. Treatment is done using oral triclabendazole.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman was started on heparin postoperatively for thromboprophylaxis. A few days later, she presented with deep vein thrombosis. Her platelet count was found to be 60,000/microliter. Which of the following anticoagulants should be avoided in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in the above scenario has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Warfarin can decrease protein C levels and may precipitate venous limb gangrene or skin necrosis in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Therefore, it should not be used until the platelet count returns to normal.

HIT is caused due to the development of IgG antibodies against complexes of heparin with platelet factor 4 (or other chemokines).

HIT usually starts 5-10 days after starting heparin. The patients will have platelet count <1,50,000/mL or reduced by 50% or more from the pre-treatment value. These are more common with unfractionated heparin than with low molecular weight (LMWH) and also more common in women.

Venous thrombosis (in the form of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism) is more common than arterial thrombosis. Arterial thrombosis can cause limb ischemia, myocardial infarction, or stroke. Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage and skin lesions at the site of subcutaneous heparin injection can also be seen.

The diagnosis of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia can be confirmed by enzyme-linked immunoassays to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes, platelet activation assays, and serotonin release assay.

Management of HIT includes:

  • Stop heparin/LMWH.
  • Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban. LMWH should be avoided because it cross-reacts with heparin antibodies.
  • Do not give warfarin until the platelet count returns to its baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal.

questions.text: Gene and cellular therapy is being used to treat all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Gene and cellular therapy is being used to treat all the above-mentioned conditions except Down’s syndrome.

Gene therapy, a revolutionary breakthrough in modern medicine, aims to introduce a missing gene or replace a defective gene in an affected individual. 

The first curative effect of gene therapy was noticed with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Other conditions where it can be applied include spinal muscular atrophy, transfusion-dependent beta-thalassemia, and chronic granulomatous disease.

Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy, a type of cellular therapy is practiced in refractory or relapsing cancers such as B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and B cell lymphoma. It cannot be used in chromosomal disorders like Down’s syndrome (Trisomy 21).

This is generally carried out with the help of a gene delivery vehicle such as a virus or lipid nanoparticle.

questions.text: A woman with a history of schizoaffective disorder was recently started on an antipsychotic. She presents to the outpatient department a month later, complaining of breast engorgement, galactorrhea, and amenorrhea. Her labs revealed prolactin levels of 220 ng/mL. The drug most likely prescribed was?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is most likely to be caused by risperidone, an atypical antipsychotic that can be used in schizoaffective disorder.

The clinical symptoms are indicative of hyperprolactinemia, most likely caused by the dopamine antagonist action of risperidone. Normally, prolactin secretion is inhibited by dopamine. Therefore, drugs that act as dopamine antagonists lead to loss of this inhibitory action and cause hyperprolactinemia. This results in symptoms like breast engorgement, galactorrhea, amenorrhea in women, and infertility in men. 

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic indicated in the management of schizophrenia, acute mania or mixed with bipolar disorder, aggressive episodes in autism spectrum disorder, etc. It is an antagonist of the serotonin 5-HT2A, dopamine D2, a1-adrenergic, a2-adrenergic, and histamine H1 receptors.

In schizoaffective disorder, symptoms of mania or depression develop concurrently with the major symptoms of schizophrenia. Thus, they are treated with mood stabilizers for manic episodes (like carbamazepine) or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (like sertraline) for depressive episodes. Antipsychotics are prescribed for psychotic symptoms. 

This hyperprolactinemia can be rapidly reversed by discontinuing the drug or switching to other atypical antipsychotics like iloperidone, olanzapine, and quetiapine which have no effect on prolactin secretion. In case, risperidone needs to be continued, then administering bromocriptine can alleviate the symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is a substrate for gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, propionyl CoA acts as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. Though it is an energy-consuming process, it is necessary to maintain blood glucose levels. It is needed as a fuel for erythrocytes and brain.

Other substrates for gluconeogenesis include:

  • Oxaloacetate is a direct precursor of phosphoenolpyruvate.
  • Pyruvate, an α-keto acid that can be converted to glucose.
  • Glucogenic amino acids like alanine, cysteine, glycine, etc, by the actions of transaminases, yield pyruvate.  
  • Lactate, obtained from anaerobic glycolysis, is released from skeletal muscles and RBCs into the blood. It is taken up by the liver via Cori cycle to be oxidized to pyruvate, to eventually synthesize glucose.
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue is converted to dihydroxyacetone phosphate in the liver, which itself is an intermediate of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

Acetyl CoA and compounds that give rise to acetyl CoA alone like acetoacetate, lysine, and leucine cannot give rise to a net synthesis of glucose. This is because of the irreversible nature of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which converts pyruvate to acetyl CoA. These compounds give rise to ketone bodies instead.

questions.text:
An obese and diabetic man presented with the lesions as shown below over his abdomen. On examination, he had diastolic hypertension. 24-hour urinary-free cortisol was increased. ACTH levels were high. What is the likely diagnosis?

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an obese, diabetic man with the image showing purple striae, diastolic hypertension, increased 24-hour urinary cortisol levels, and high levels of ACTH. So the likely diagnosis is Cushing's syndrome. 

Cushing's syndrome is a group of clinical features that occur due to chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids of any etiology. Cushing's disease is specifically Cushing's syndrome that occurs due to pituitary corticotrope adenoma. 

Typical features include

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Low libido
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic hypertension 
  • Edema 
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression, anxiety
  • Psychosis 
  • Irritability

 

Management of Cushing's syndrome includes

  • Surgical removal of the tumor followed by hydrocortisone replacement with gradual tapering is preferred.
  • Medical management includes metyrapone and ketoconazole. 

Other options:

Option A: Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), and aldosterone (mineralocorticoid). The features are fatigue, weight loss, anorexia, low blood pressure, postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, salt craving, hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.

Option B: Adrenal crisis or acute adrenal insufficiency is an emergency usually occurring in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency. It is triggered by conditions like intercurrent illness and stress. The features include hypovolemic shock, acute abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, decreased responsiveness, stupor and coma.

Option C: Conn's syndrome or primary aldosteronism occurs due to aldosterone secreting adrenal adenoma leading to mineralocorticoid excess. It is characterized by hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, muscle weakness, proximal myopathy and muscle cramps.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A woman with 23 weeks of gestation and prior history of pre-term labor undergoes a cervical length assessment. It is found to be 23mm. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
The next step in the management of a woman with 23 weeks of gestation and a cervical length of 23mm is cervical cerclage. 

Cervical incompetence is the impairment of the retentive power of the cervix. It can be due to anatomical causes or functional causes. It leads to painless dilation of the cervix and painless expulsion of the products of conception in the mid-trimester. 

Management of cervical incompetency

Patients with previous history of:

  • Spontaneous preterm birth
  • Stillbirth 
  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • Injuries to cervix
  • Amputation of the cervix
  • Cone biopsy 

should undergo serial transvaginal ultrasound for cervical length monitoring. Ultrasonography features suggestive of cervical incompetence are cervical length less than 25mm and funneling of the internal os.

The monitoring is repeated every 1 or 2 weeks if the length is less than 30mm. If cervical length is less than 25 mm before 24 weeks gestation, then cervical cerclage is done. Cerclage is the procedure done to strengthen the cervix. A nonabsorbable tape is placed around the cervix at the level of internal os. Shirodkar and McDonald's methods of cervical cerclage are the commonly performed cerclage procedures.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient has completed a family and wanted a sterilization technique which can be surgically reversible. The following method of sterilization was done as shown below.
questions.solution:
The sterilization technique which can be surgically reversible and shown in the image is the Pomeroy technique.

The Pomeroy method is the most popular technique of tubal ligation in which the fallopian tube is identified on each side and brought out through the incision. The middle portion is then formed into a loop, tied at the base and excised. 

It is surgically reversible and has a short hospitalization. 

Other options:

Option A: In Uchida's method, the serosa in the midsegment of the tube is stripped off from the mucosa and then excised. The proximal segment is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimum tubal excision preserves the potential for tuboplasty. 

Option B: The technique of fimbriectomy is irreversible. In this method, fimbria is excised. Thus, it is a permanent method of sterilisation. 

Option D: In Irving's procedure, the mid-portion of the tube is ligated with excision of the intervening portion. The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible method and may require a laparotomy incision.

The below image shows Pomeroy technique

questions.text: A patient visited the OPD with multiple, painless masses on his hand as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows verruca vulgaris or common warts and the most common causative organism of it is HPV-2 (human papilloma virus -2). These common warts are also closely related to HPV 1, 4, 27, and 57.

Viral warts show acanthosis and hyperkeratosis, usually with the characteristic koilocytosis of upper keratinocytes. Most of them also show papillomatosis.

Appearance: Common warts present as firm papules with a rough horny surface.

Site: They can occur anywhere on the skin but most commonly situated on the backs of the hands and fingers. In children they can be seen on the knees. New lesions can also occur along the sites of trauma known as pseudo-Koebner phenomenon.

Usually asymptomatic. 

Management:

  • Salicylic acid with or without lactic acid - first line treatment
  • Cryotherapy - second line treatment

Other options: 

Options A and C: HPV-6 and HPV-11 are associated with anogenital warts and laryngeal papillomas.

Option B: HPV-16 is associated with anogenital warts and cervical carcinoma.

questions.text: A forensic expert was asked to conduct an autopsy of an HIV-positive deceased man with a suspected homicidal death. He decides to do an in-situ in-part dissection followed by en block removal of the organs. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he following?
questions.solution:
The autopsy technique the forensic expert is following is the Rokitansky technique. 

In the Rokitansky technique, a local dissection (in-situ) is started from the neck and is trailed down followed by removing the organs as a block (en bloc). It is preferred in patients with highly transmissible diseases such as HIV or hepatitis B. 

A medicolegal autopsy is a postmortem examination of a body to ascertain evidence contributory to the cause of death. It is important to complete the autopsy in each and every case. This is done by examining all the organs and opening all the body cavities. 

Universal work precautions taken during the autopsy of an HIV-positive deceased are - 

  • All infected bodies should be wrapped and tied in double-layer plastic bags and tagged as biologically hazardous.
  • Workers having external injury or dermatitis should not handle the body.
  • Personal protective equipment should be worn.
  • Avoid accidental pricks and cuts from needles. 
  • Specimen should be properly labelled, filled with 10% formalin solution and handled with gloved hands.
  • Gauze and cotton should be collected in double plastic bags for incineration.
  • Instruments used for an autopsy should be dipped in 20% glutaraldehyde for 1/2 an hour, washed with soap or detergent and water dried and then rinsed with methylated spirit.
  • Freshly prepared sodium hypochlorite / 1:10 dilution bleach is used for disinfecting the autopsy room.
  • Electrical oscillating saw is used to open the cranial cavity to minimise aerosol splatter.
  • After the autopsy, all body orifices should be packed and body is wrapped in double plastic bags.
  • Body should be incinerated or burnt.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch . It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: A Ph.D scholar wants to study the etiological factors leading to the development of Moebius syndrome. Which study design should she use?
questions.solution:
Moebius syndrome is a rare disease, so a case-control study should be used by the researcher to study the etiology of this disease.

The case-control study is a comparison or cross-reference study with individuals as the unit of study. It is also called a retrospective study and is a good analytical design to study rare diseases. This study is the first approach to test causal hypotheses.

The case-control method has three distinct features:

  1. Both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of the study
  2. The study proceeds backward from effect to cause
  3. It uses a control/comparison group to support/reject an inference 

Other options:

Option A - Cohort study is a follow-up study with individuals as the unit of study. It is used for the study of multiple outcomes related to exposure of study. It can not be used when the exposure under investigation is rare.

Option B - Cross-sectional study is a prevalence study with individuals as the unit of study. It is also known as a prevalence study and is more useful for the study of chronic diseases. It is more appropriate for the study of the distribution of a disease in a population than studying its etiology.

Option D - Ecological study is a correlational study with the population as the unit of study.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: A young male sprint runner sustained a large wound over the right thigh while practicing.  The doctor decided to cover the wound with a graft obtained from the left thigh by using the instrument shown below. What type of graft is being placed on the wound?
questions.solution:
The image above shows  Humby's knife with an Eschmann blade that is used to obtain the Thiersch graft. The graft is a type of partial-thickness/split-thickness skin graft. 

Grafts are tissues that are transferred without their blood supply and will revascularize after being engrafted to a new site.

The different types of grafts are:

  • Thiersch grafts/split-thickness skin grafts consist of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. The donor area is commonly the thigh, and Humby's knife is used to take the graft. The process is shown below:
  • Full-thickness skin grafts, otherwise known as Wolfe grafts include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. Wolfe grafts have high durability and the least amount of secondary contraction. It is used in reconstructing superficial hand and facial wounds. 
  • Composite grafts are grafts that contain tissues besides skin. It can include subcutaneous fat, cartilage, small amounts of muscle, etc. It is indicated in small areas requiring specialized tissues such as nasal reconstruction.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: An obese female patient had a prolonged second stage of labor. A maneuver that involves sharply flexing the maternal thigh towards the abdomen was done. What condition is this maneuver done for?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and McRobert's manoeuvre is done for this condition.

The manoeuvre allows straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotation of the symphysis pubis toward the maternal head, and decreases the angle of pelvic inclination. Even though this does not increase pelvic dimensions, pelvic rotation towards the head usually frees the impacted shoulder.

The below image shows Mc Robert's manoeuvre 

Shoulder dystocia is the impaction of the anterior shoulder behind the pubic symphysis, which fails to deliver with maternal pushing or external traction. It is an emergency since the umbilical cord gets compressed within the birth canal.

Risk factors of shoulder dystocia are fetal macrosomia, maternal obesity, the prolonged second stage of labor, previous history of shoulder dystocia.

Shoulder dystocia is managed according to the following steps:

  1. Call for help, gentle traction with maternal efforts, adequate analgesia
  2. Episiotomy if needed
  3. Suprapubic pressure with simultaneous downward traction of the fetal head
  4. McRobert's maneuver
  5. Woods corkscrew rotational maneuver wherein the posterior shoulder is rotated to 180 degrees.
  6. Rubin maneuver  - here, the fetal shoulder is rocked from side to side by applying pressure onto maternal abdomen. If this is unsuccessful, the doctor inserts hands in pelvis to reach the accessible shoulder and pushes it towards the anterior surface of chest. This leads to a small bisacromial diameter that allows the anterior shoulder to displace from behind the symphysis.

questions.text:
A patient came to the emergency department with dyspnea. He was confused, anxious and hallucinating. Inital management was started and ABG analysis was sent. ABG shows the following. What is acid-base disorder shown?

pH: 7.25

pCO2: 70 mmHg

HCO3‾: 26 mEq/L

pO2: 45 mmHg
questions.solution:
The given ABG indicates respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: pH is decreased. This signifies acidosis. 

Step 2: In this case, pCO2 has increased by 30 mmHg. This signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 3: Plasma HCO3- has increased by 26 - 24 = 2 mEq/L. This signifies compensation is taking place.

In acute conditions, for every 10 mmHg rise in pCO2 expected rise in plasma HCO3- is 1mEq/L. In this case, pCO2 has risen by 30 mmHg, so the expected rise in HCO3- is 3 mEq/L. However, plasma HCO3- has risen only by 2 mEq/L, which implies that currently, the compensation is only partial.

The given scenario is suggestive of acute hypercapnia. The patients with acute hypercapnia present with anxiety, dyspnea, confusion, psychosis, and hallucinations, and may progress to coma. The management includes treating the underlying condition, and trying to bring back the PCO2 levels back to physiological range. Patients are started on oxygen, but endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation might be required in patients with severe acidosis.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of abnormal skin pigmentation over his forearms and face. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. Which stain has been used to identify his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features suggest a diagnosis of hemochromatosis. Prussian blue stain is used to identify this condition. On this stain, the hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes appear blue in color. 

Hemochromatosis occurs due to excessive iron absorption that leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs. The involvement of organs occurs in the following order:

  • Liver
  • Pancreas 
  • Myocardium
  • Endocrine organs (pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid, and parathyroid glands)
  • Joints
  • Skin

It can be primary hemochromatosis (inherited disorder) or secondary hemochromatosis (accumulation of iron due to other causes). The adult form of primary hemochromatosis usually occurs due to mutations of the HFE gene.

Clinical features include:

  • Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly
  • Diabetes mellitus due to destruction of pancreatic islets
  • Slate-gray color skin pigmentation due to increased melanin production
  • Cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy)
  • Acute synovitis due to excessive deposition of calcium pyrophosphate that produces disabling polyarthritis known as pseudogout
  • Atrophic testes secondary to pituitary involvement

The image below shows a slide of liver microscopy that has been stained with Perls Prussian blue stain. The hepatocellular iron appears blue due to the stain.

Other options:

Option A: Masson trichrome stain can be used to demonstrate collagen. 

Option B: Congo red stain can be used for demonstrating the accumulation of amyloid.

Option C: Sudan black stain is a fat-soluble dye that is used to demonstrate lipid inclusions.
