questions.text: The fracture seen in the X-ray given below is?
questions.solution:
The image shows an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint. So the fracture seen in the X-ray is Galeazzi's fracture.

Galeazzi's fracture is the fracture of the lower third of the radius and the subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This injury usually happens when one falls on an outstretched hand. The most common clinical feature is tenderness over the distal end of the forearm. 

The aim of treatment for this fracture is to preserve supination and pronation of the forearm. In children, closed reduction is usually enough to achieve perfect reduction. However, in adults, open reduction using a k-wire fixation or compression plating is usually required. It is also important to look for ulnar nerve damage.

Galeazzi's fracture can cause complications such as malunion due to displacement of the fragment. This often results in deformity and limitation in supination and pronation.

Other options: 

Option B: Monteggia fracture is the fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of the proximal radio-ulnar joint and the subluxation of the radiocapitellar joint.

Option C: Smith's fracture is the fracture of the distal radius with palmar angulation of the distal bone fragment. It also known as reverse Colle's fracture.

Option D: Colle's fracture is the fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought with complaints of abdominal pain and gross hematuria. On examination, a large palpable abdominal mass is present. He is noted to have hypertension. Biopsy of the mass shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of abdominal pain, gross hematuria, large palpable abdominal mass, and hypertension with histopathological image showing triphasic cell types suggest a likely diagnosis of Wilms tumor.

Wilms tumor is one of the most common causes of childhood renal tumors and has a peak incidence at ages 2 and 5 years. It can occur in association with several syndromes such as:

  • WAGR syndrome: Wilms tumor, Aniridia, Genitourinary abnormalities, and Mental retardation
  • Denys–Drash syndrome: Gonadal dysgenesis and early onset nephropathy
  • Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome: Organomegaly, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, and adrenal cytomegaly

Grossly, Wilms tumor occurs as a large, solitary, and well-circumscribed renal mass. Microscopically, you can see the classic triphasic cell types composed of blastemal, epithelial, and stromal cell types. The blastemal component consists of sheets of small round blue cells. The epithelial cell type consists of abortive tubules and the stromal cell type consists of fibroblasts. The histopathological slide is shown below:


Because of their primitive histologic appearance, the following childhood tumors are known as small round blue cell tumors:

  • Wilms tumor
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Lymphoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma
  • Medulloblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma

Other options:

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant mesenchymal tumor that has skeletal muscle differentiation. It has four subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, pleomorphic, and spindle cell type

Option C: Neuroblastoma includes tumors that arise from primordial neural crest cells occurring in sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla. They can also present with hypertension and a palpable mass. However, histopathologically, they contain tumor cells arranged concentrically about a central space filled with eosinophilic fibrillary material (neurophil). This arrangement is known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (shown below).


Option D: Medulloblastoma is a brain tumor that is one of the most common embryonal neoplasms. Histologically, they contain Homer-Wright pseudorosettes similar to neuroblastomas.

  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. An X-ray of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of falling on an outstretched hand along with the X-ray above showing a fracture in the distal part of the humerus with posterior dislocation of fracture fragment are suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. 

Supracondylar fractures are the commonest fractures in children younger than the age of 7 years. It typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched arm. They can be of various types as listed below:

  • Posterior displacement of distal fracture fragment occurs commonly and is an extension type of fracture.
  • Anterior displacement of distal fracture fragment is less common and occurs due to a direct blow on a flexed elbow and is often unstable
  • Lateral condylar fractures are due to a varus force on an extended elbow and may extend through the unossified portion of the capitellum into the joint space.

Other options:

Option A: Cubitus varus deformity or gun stock deformity is a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture that occurs due to malunion. When the distal fragment unites with an excessive backward tilt, there is hyperextension at the elbow.

Option C: Dislocated radial head would present with a discontinuity in the line drawn along the shaft of the proximal radius (the line should normally pass through the capitellum). 

The image below shows an anterior dislocated radial head with calcification of the annular ligament:

Option D: Proximal humerus fractures are uncommon in children and will be pathological fractures (due to reasons such as the presence of a bone cyst)

The image below shows a radiograph showing proximal humerus fracture with the involvement of greater trochanter:

questions.text: Physiological gynecomastia is not seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Physiological gynecomastia is not seen in obese males. In obese men, increased fat deposition over the breasts is referred to as pseudo-gynecomastia. 

Gynecomastia is defined as ≥ 2 cm subareolar breast tissue. It can be physiological or pathological.

Physiologic gynecomastia occurs during three phases of life:

  • Neonatal period
  • Adolescence
  • Senescence

Common to each of these phases is an excess of circulating estrogens in relation to circulating testosterone. Neonatal gynecomastia is caused by the action of placental estrogens on neonatal breast tissues. In adolescence, there is an excess of estradiol relative to testosterone. In senescence, the circulating testosterone level falls, resulting in relative hyperestrogenism.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with chronic pain and stiffness in his hands, knees, and hips. On examination of the hands, Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes are visible. His knee x-ray is given below. Which of the following joints is likely to be spared in this condition?

choices.text: Intervertebral joints in the lumbar region

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes on examination and reduced joint space on x-ray is suggestive of osteoarthritis. The wrist joint is likely to be spared in this condition.

Other joints that are usually spared in osteoarthritis are the elbow and ankle joints. 

Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals of age >45 years. In the early phases, there is episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, there is continuous pain and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes.

The joints involved in osteoarthritis are: 

  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • Hip and knee joints
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

Clinical signs: 

  • Tenderness and inflammation of the joint
  • Crepitus when the joint is moved
  • Bony swelling
  • Decreased and painful range of movement 
  • Deformity and instability in severe cases
  • Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes - palpable nodules in the DIP and PIP joints, respectively (as shown in the image below).

Characteristic features of OA seen on plain radiographs:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts

The image below is an x-ray of osteoarthritis showing the presence of osteophytes, narrowing of the joint space (arrow), and subchondral bone sclerosis.

questions.text: An elderly male patient, who is known to have heart failure and is on a cardiac glycoside, presents to the casualty with complaints of severe vomiting, abdominal pain, visual disturbance, and restlessness. ECG shows ventricular bigeminy. Which of the drugs used in heart failure would have likely caused this acute presentation?
questions.solution:
In this given clinical scenario, with ECG findings showing ventricular bigeminy, digoxin is the drug that would have likely caused this acute presentation suggestive of digitalis toxicity.  

Digoxin has a very low therapeutic index. Digitalis toxicity can manifests as any type of arrhythmias (atrial tachycardia with AV block is classic) as well as produce severe nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It also causes visual disturbances such as blurring or yellowing of vision.  

Treatment includes cessation of digoxin administration followed by intravenous potassium in the case of tachyarrhythmia, intravenous lidocaine for ventricular arrhythmia, and intravenous propranolol for supraventricular arrhythmias. Digoxin antibody (Fab fragment) is used in severe cases of digitalis toxicity.

Digoxin is the only cardiac glycoside that is in clinical use. It has a positive inotropic action and helps the failing heart to regain back some of its contractile power and reduces heart rate as well. Digoxin acts by inhibiting the NA+K+ATPase enzyme which causes an increase in intracellular calcium leading to increased contractility and a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance and heart rate. 

The major route of digoxin elimination is by P-glycoprotein (efflux transporter). Drug interactions with amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, etc can decrease digoxin clearance and possibly cause digitalis toxicity. 

Other options: 

Option A: Lidocaine is commonly used as a local anesthetic. It has anti-arrhythmic properties and is used to suppress ventricular tachycardia that is caused by digitalis toxicity.

Option C: Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker and is used in heart failure. It acts by arteriolar and venodilatation causing reduction of afterload and preload. It has adverse effects such as headache, dizziness, weakness, and fetopathic potential.

Option D: Levosimendan is an inotropic drug as well as a phosphodiesterase inhibitor. It is primarily used in acute on chronic decompensated heart failure as a short-term therapy. The most common side effect is hypotension.

questions.text: A multiparous woman presents in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterus appears asymmetrical and fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. On fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and on the pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. All of them are true in this condition except

choices.text: Prematurity is the most common cause
Dorsoposterior is the most common position

questions.solution:
The given examination findings are suggestive of a transverse lie and the false statement is dorsoposterior is the most common position. In transverse lie, dorsoanterior is the most common position.

The position is determined by the position of the back. There are 4 positions - dorsoanterior, dorsposterior, dorsosuperior and dorsoinferior. The position of the fetal head determines right or left. Left is more common. The likely fetal position that can cause arm prolapse is the dorsoposterior position.

The most common cause of transverse lie is prematurity.

Other etiological factors are 

  • Multiparity
  • Twins especially in the second baby
  • Hydramnios
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Placenta previa
  • Pelvic tumors
  • Malformations of the uterus
  • Intrauterine death

Clinically, fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. The fundal grip demonstrates an impalpable fetal pole. The lower pole of the uterus is empty in the pelvic grip.

Management is an external cephalic version and if it fails or is contraindicated, a cesarean section should be done.

questions.text: A boy came to the hospital with complaints of diplopia and progressive headache. Examination of extraocular movements revealed the findings as shown in the image when the patient attempted to look right. At what level of the brainstem does the affected cranial nerve nucleus arise?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding shown in the image is suggestive of lateral rectus palsy of the right eye. This occurs due to the lesion involving the abducens nerve. The abducens nerve nucleus arises at the level of facial colliculus in the pons. 

Facial colliculus is present at the floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum. This colliculus contains the abducens nerve nucleus and the fibers of the internal genu of the facial nerve which travels around the abducens nerve nucleus as shown in the image above. The abducens nerve then emerges out of the brainstem between the pons and the medulla and runs through the Dorello's canal. The abducens nerve then enters the superior orbital fissure via the cavernous sinus and innervates the lateral rectus muscle.

Determining the palsy:

The abduction and adduction of the eye are caused by the action of the lateral rectus and medial rectus muscles respectively. The lateral rectus is innervated by the abducens nerve (VI) while the medial rectus is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (III).

Horizontal conjugate movements occur when both eyes move horizontally to look right or left.

  • In right gaze: The right eye abducts and the left eye adducts.
  • In left gaze: The right eye adducts and the left eye abducts.

In the image, when the patient attempted to look right, the left eye adducted normally, while the right eye failed to abduct. This is suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy due to the lesion involving the right abducens nerve.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is looking straight (neutral gaze), then the affected eye is the left eye. In such a case, due to left lateral rectus palsy, the action of the left medial rectus is unopposed causing adduction of the left eye.

Other options:

Option A: The superior colliculus lies in the upper midbrain. At this level, the oculomotor nerve nucleus is present and the nerve emerges out of the midbrain.

Option B: Inferior colliculus lies in the lower midbrain. At this level, the trochlear nerve nucleus is present.

Option D: The inferior olivary nucleus is present in the superior half of the medulla. At this level, the hypoglossal nerve is present.

  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: A lady sustained head trauma and was evaluated for intracranial hemorrhage. Her speech was fluent but comprehension was affected. Which area of the brain is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
A lady who had sustained head trauma and has fluent speech but affected comprehension is most likely to have Wernicke's aphasia. The area affected is the posterior superior temporal gyrus, referred to as the sensory speech area or Wernicke's area. 

Intracerebral hemorrhage and neoplasm are some of the causes that can lead to Wernicke's aphasia. Language output is fluent but the comprehension is affected. There is a jumbling of words. The ability to understand spoken and written word is retained but the interpretation is affected.

Other options:

Options B and C: Damage to the premotor and prefrontal areas of the cerebral cortex results in Broca's aphasia. In this condition, the speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. The speech is telegraphic but informative. This is also called motor aphasia.

Option D: Damage to the arcuate fasciculus has been implicated in conduction aphasia which results in impaired repetition.

questions.text: Which of the following is a circumventricular organ that has tanycytes and lacks a blood-brain barrier?
questions.solution:
Organum vasculosum is a circumventricular organ that has tanycytes and lacks a blood-brain barrier.

Blood-brain barriers are the barriers present in the capillary endothelium of the brain. Structures forming the blood-brain barrier are the tight junctions between the endothelial cells and the feet end of astrocytes.

Circumventricular organs are midline structures in the ventricular wall that lack a normal blood-brain barrier (BBB). These are lined by specialized ependymal cells called tanycytes.

Other options:

Options B and C: Suprafornical and supracommissural organs are false options, the other circumventricular organs are subfornical and subcommissural organs.

Option D: Anterior pituitary is a false option, posterior pituitary is a circumventricular organ.

  • Subfornical organ
  • Area Postrema

questions.text: A female patient had contractions and started expelling the placenta following the delivery of the baby. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the peripheral placental separation shown in the image below?

choices.text: It is commonly known as Schultz method
It takes place during second stage of labour
The maternal surface of placenta appears first at vulva
This is an abnormal method of placental separation

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicates that the patient is in the third stage of labor and the above image shows the Mathews-Duncan method of placental separation which begins at the periphery. Here, the maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

The third stage of labor starts after fetal delivery and involves the detachment and expulsion of the placenta and membranes. There are two normal mechanisms by which placental separation occurs:

Mathews-Duncan method:

  • The separation of the placenta begins at the periphery of the placenta. The blood collects between the membranes and uterine wall and escapes out from the vagina. 
  • Here, as the placenta separation is sideways, the maternal surface appears first.

Schultze method:

  • The method of separation begins at the center of the placenta (fetal surface). Hence, this is the first part to descend and appear at the vulva.
  • The blood collects into a membranous sac behind the placenta, leading to the formation of retroplacental clots.

The below image shows:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as the Schultze method
B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoid syndrome excretes a large amount of a certain metabolite of serotonin in the urine. Which enzyme is involved in the production of this metabolite?
questions.solution:
In carcinoid syndrome, 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) is excreted in large amounts in the urine and the enzyme monoamine oxidase is responsible for its production.

A carcinoid tumor is a tumor of argentaffin cells that produces an excessive amount of serotonin and is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. Serotonin is a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism (as shown below).

Urinary metabolites of serotonin in patients with carcinoid syndrome include N-acetylserotonin glucuronide and 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid. 

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific for carcinoid tumors. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumors associated with carcinoid syndrome.

 Other options:

Option A: Aminotransferase is involved in the conversion of GABA to Succinate.

Option B: PLP-dependent amino acid decarboxylase is involved in the second step of the synthesis of serotonin, where 5-hydroxy tryptophan is decarboxylated to 5-hydroxy tryptamine/serotonin.

Option D: Tryptophan is first acted on by tryptophan hydroxylase in serotonin synthesis.

questions.text: A research assistant with chemical burns was rushed to the emergency. On examination, he has 2nd-degree burns involving 40% of his total body surface area. He is stabilized and fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction is by measuring urine output. 

The urine output should be maintained between 0.5 to 1mL/kg body weight/hour. If the urine output is low and the patient presents with signs of hypoperfusion (restlessness with tachycardia, cool peripheries, high hematocrit). A bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be administered.  Urine output in excess of 2 mL/kg body weight per hour indicates that the patient is being over-resuscitated and thus the infusion should be decreased.

Monitoring lactate levels is useful in larger burns. A persistent raised lactate/metabolic acidosis can indicate a missed systemic toxicity from cyanide or carbon monoxide.

Other options: 

Option A: The parkland formula is a tool to estimate fluid requirement, and not assess the adequacy of fluid correction.

Option B: Central venous pressure monitoring is required in patients with cardiac/renal dysfunction.

Option D: Hematocrit is not measured during resuscitation of burns.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient who is known to have chronic kidney disease is planned for dialysis treatment. Which of the following is not an indication for dialysis ?
questions.solution:
Severe coagulopathy is a relative contraindication for dialysis. 

Dialysis is a form of renal replacement therapy. Here the kidney's function of blood filtration is supplemented with artificial equipment to remove excess water, solutes, and toxins.

Dialysis broadly has 3 types that include hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis and continuous renal replacement therapy.

Indications for dialysis include: 

  • Refractory metabolic acidosis that has failed to respond to medical treatment
  • Refractory hyperkalemia 
  • Extracellular volume expansion despite diuretic therapy
  • Uremic symptoms
  • eGFR <10 mL/min per 1.73 m2 
  • Any toxic ingestions

Note: Non-refractory hyperkalemia can be managed by: Restricting the dietary potassium intake, insulin, calcium gluconate or calcium chloride, inhalational β-agonist therapy and potassium binding ion-exchange resin.

Contraindications for dialysis include inability to secure vascular access, difficult vascular access, needle phobia, cardiac failure and coagulopathy.

questions.text: A young male had a workout session following which he ate a bowl of rice with fish. Which of the following would not increase his glucagon levels?
questions.solution:
Among the following, increased blood glucose would not increase his plasma glucagon levels. 

Blood glucose concentration is an important factor that regulates the levels of glucagon. An increase in blood glucose decreases the plasma levels of glucagon.

Option A: Exercise increases glucagon secretion. During exercise, glucose is utilized increasingly. This leads to an increase in circulating levels of glucagon thereby increasing glucose production.

Option C: During starvation, there is an increase in the levels of glucagon. The peak reaches by the third day of fast and declines when the  fatty acids and ketones become the sources of energy.

Option D: Intake of protein-rich meals, especially arginine and alanine stimulates the secretion of glucagon. The mechanism is that the amino acids stimulate insulin secretion which promotes the storage of carbohydrates and lipids while the glucagon prevents the development of hypoglycemia. 

Other factors which stimulate glucagon secretion are :

  • CCK, gastrin
  • Cortisol, infection, and stress
  • Beta-adrenergic stimulators
  • Theophylline and acetylcholine.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is diagnosed with parathyroid adenoma. He complains of constipation, bone pain, lethargy, and low mood. Which of the following features can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of hypercalcemia due to hyperparathyroidism. Pathological fractures can be seen in this condition.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is one of the important causes of hypercalcemia and is characterized by an increase in the levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH). They mainly present with bone pain or pathological fractures. Other common complaints of hypercalcemia include difficulty in concentrating, depression, constipation, peptic ulcer, lethargy, and increased urinary output.

Hyperparathyroidism leads to increased excretion of phosphate in the urine, leading to decreased levels of serum phosphate.

ECG may show arrhythmias and short QT interval.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with fever, chills, and malaise. Her husband reports that she has refractive schizophrenia and is on clozapine for the same. Investigations revealed agranulocytosis. What would be the most likely cause for her agranulocytosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for the woman's agranulocytosis would be drug toxicity. In this given clinical scenario, the woman is on clozapine, which can cause agranulocytosis. Hence she requires hematological monitoring.

Agranulocytosis is a form of neutropenia characterized by a marked reduction of neutrophils resulting in an increased risk for infections. 

The most common cause of agranulocytosis is drug toxicity. Drugs such as alkylating agents, antimetabolites, anticonvulsants, antipsychotics, and anti-inflammatory agents can cause this condition. 

Other causes of neutropenia are: 

  • Inadequate or ineffective granulopoiesis
    • Suppression of hematopoietic stem cells - aplastic anemia, infiltrative marrow disorders
    • Suppression of committed granulocytic precursors due to certain drugs
    • Ineffective hematopoiesis - megaloblastic anemias and myelodysplastic syndromes
    • Congenital conditions (e.g., Kostmann syndrome)
  • Increased destruction or sequestration of neutrophils
    • Immunological injury to neutrophils: idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus, drug exposure
    • Splenomegaly due to increased sequestration and destruction of neutrophils
    • Increased peripheral utilization: bacterial, fungal, or rickettsial infections.

Clinically, there are symptoms related to infection and malaise, chills, and fever. Ulcerating and necrotizing lesions of the oral cavity are characteristic. Histopathologically, the bone marrow appears hypercellular. 

Related Pearl: Clozapine treatment guidelines

Clozapine treatment guidelines:

Indications:  Treatment resistant schizophrenia, schizophrenia associated with suicidality.

Adverse effects:

  • Seizures
  • Myocarditis
  • Metabolic syndrome

questions.text: A male patient presents with hearing loss and otorrhea for the last one week. He has a history of middle ear infections. The last episode resulted in the perforation of the tympanic membrane. His otoscopy findings are depicted below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and image above showing a perforated tympanic membrane and a large mass of white keratin debris suggest the likely diagnosis of secondary cholesteatoma. 

Cholesteatomas are keratinized squamous epithelium masses present in the middle ear cavity. They are described as skin in the wrong place. Although it is called cholesteatoma, this term is a misnomer as it is not composed of cholesterol crystals.

Cholesteatomas can be classified into the following types :

  • Primary acquired cholesteatomas occur in the absence of previous infection or perforation and patients present with hearing loss.
  • Secondary acquired cholesteatomas occur in those who have a preexisting perforation. 
  • Congenital cholesteatomas arise from the embryonic epidermal cells present in the middle ear cleft. It can be visualized as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. 

Clinical features of cholesteatomas include hearing loss (due to perforation of tympanic membrane and middle ear bone destruction) and otorrhea. Cholesteatomas have a high potential to destroy the bone due to invasion and enzymatic bone destruction. 

Diagnosis of cholesteatoma can be done by history, examination, and radiography. CT can demonstrate bony defects such as ossicular erosion, mastoid aditus widening, and bony ear canal erosion.

Surgery is the only treatment for cholesteatoma. The procedure of choice is modified radical mastoidectomy (MRM), a type of canal wall-down tympanomastoidectomy.

Other options: 

Option A - Acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) is more common in children. It would not have a pearly white mass on otoscopy. Clinical and otoscopy findings depend on the stage of ASOM. 

The following image shows mucopurulent discharge in the external auditory meatus seen in the stage of resolution of ASOM:

Option B - Glomus tumors are the most common benign tumors of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IXth cranial nerve. A rising sun sign is seen on otoscopy when a tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear

The following image shows a rising sun sign:

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

questions.text: A young woman presents with fever, severe myalgia and arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. NS-1 antigen has been detected in her blood sample. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this disease?

choices.text: The causative agent belongs to orthomyxoviridae
It is transmitted by Aedes aegypti

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of dengue and dengue viruses are members of the flaviviridae family, not orthomyxoviridae.

Dengue viruses are enveloped viruses that are transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti (tiger mosquitoes). 

Dengue is an acute febrile illness. The patient presents with sudden-onset fever, retro-orbital pain, muscle and joint pains, and a rash. Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain. The initial rash in dengue may appear as flushing erythema of the face in the first 2 days of symptoms. A second rash occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and appears maculopapular or morbilliform. Sometimes, lesions may coalesce and appear as white islands in a red sea due to generalized erythema with petechiae and islands of sparing. As the disease progress, it can be associated with leukopenia and thrombocytopenia.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS-1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

The condition is self-limiting and the treatment of dengue is supportive management, with hydration and paracetamol for fever. If there is severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000) then platelets should be transfused. 

The image below shows erythema with petechiae in a patient with dengue fever showing white islands in a red sea appearance.

questions.text: A newborn with persistent cyanosis was evaluated. He was found to have a congenital heart disease that is schematically represented below. What is the most likely embryological defect causing this?

choices.text: Failure in formation of conotruncal ridges

questions.solution:
The given image shows persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) and the embryological defect causing this is a failure in the formation of the conotruncal ridges.

This leads to the absence of a conotruncal or aorticopulmonary septum which normally divides the outflow tract into the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.

Deoxygenated blood goes into the right heart and back into systemic circulation via the aorta. Oxygenated blood goes into the left heart and then back into pulmonary circulation via the pulmonary artery. This parallel circulation gives rise to persistent cyanosis as seen in this patient. 

Since the conotruncal ridges also participate in the formation of the interventricular septum, an accompanying ventricular septal defect (VSD) may also be seen. The persistent truncus overrides both the ventricles and receives mixed blood from both sides. 

 

Other options -

Option A - Abnormal spiraling of the conotruncal septum leads to the transposition of the great arteries (TGA). This leads to the aorta originating from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

 

Option B - Anterior displacement of the conotruncal septum gives rise to the Tetralogy of Fallot. It is characterized by 4 cardinal features - pulmonary infundibular stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is represented by the schematic image given below. 

 

Option D - Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection causes the drainage of oxygenated blood (brought in by pulmonary veins) into the systemic venous circulation. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

questions.text: A 7-day-old neonate is brought with failure to pass meconium since birth. The baby's abdomen is markedly distended and she aspirates on feeding. Rectal suction biopsy shows a lot of hypertrophied nerve bundles with increased acetylcholinesterase staining and aganglionosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of failure to pass meconium and a markedly distended abdomen along with biopsy showing aganglionosis suggests a likely diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease/congenital aganglionic megacolon.

Hirschsprung disease is a developmental disorder of the enteric nervous system. Normally, the enteric neuronal plexus develops by neural crest cells migrating to the colon wall. When there is a mutation in tyrosine kinase receptor RET, it results in premature arrest of this regular migration from the cecum to the rectum. This results in the lack of Auerbach and Meissner submucosal plexus in the distal intestinal segment (aganglionosis) causing hypertonicity of the bowel wall. Thus, there is a functional obstruction in the distal segment that also results in massive dilatation of the proximal segment (megacolon). 

      Based on the segments affected, they are classified into -

  • Short-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease having proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

The onset of constipation can be seen at birth. Patients present with intermittent attacks of fever and pain due to intestinal obstruction from the retained feces. Complications include enterocolitis and bowel perforation. 

Rectal suction biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis and shows increased acetylcholinesterase staining and aganglionosis. Other investigations include anorectal manometry and barium contrast enema. 

Surgical intervention is the only definitive treatment available.

Other options:

Option B: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis generally presents as new-onset regurgitation and projectile non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A firm abdominal mass and abnormal left-to-right hyperperistalsis can be seen. Diagnosis is made by ultrasonography. 

Option C: Wilkie syndrome, otherwise known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome, occurs due to the compression of the third duodenal segment against the aorta by this artery. Diagnosis is by radiological demonstration of duodenal cutoff along with proximal duodenal dilatation. 

Option D: Functional constipation, otherwise known as fecal withholding, is the intentional or subconscious withholding of stool. It usually starts after the neonatal period. Here daytime encopresis (passage of stools at inappropriate places after 4 years of age) is common.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who has regular periods and is sexually active comes with a history of new onset post-coital bleeding. She mentions that her last period was much heavier than usual. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a pap smear in the OPD

questions.solution:
In this patient with a history of new-onset post-coital bleeding and menorrhagia, cervical cancer can be suspected in the patient, and a pap smear would be the next step in management to rule it out.

Papanicolaou test or pap test is a screening test routinely employed in gynaecological practice. 

 The screening guidelines include the following

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Cytology alone is done in women aged 21-29 years, every 3 years. 
  • In women who are aged 30-65 years, for every 5 years, FDA-approved primary hrHPV testing and co-testing (hrHPV testing and cytology) are done and cytology alone, is done every 3 years
  • Women can stop cervical cancer screening if previous negative results after the age of 65 years or hysterectomy along with cervix removal are done.

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol and stained with Pap stain.

The instruments used for pap smear are summarized in the image below.

Pap smear should be obtained prior to the vaginal examination (Option A), because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report, the lubricant may prevent detection of organisms, and any vaginal bleeding during the examination may preclude proper visualization of the cervix.

The laboratory investigations and transvaginal ultrasound can be ordered after taking a Pap smear and doing a per-vaginal examination. (Options C and D). A transvaginal ultrasound should be taken to assess the endometrial thickness and rule out any fibroids. Hemoglobin levels should be estimated to assess the need for iron supplementation since heavy blood loss can cause anemia.

questions.text: A female patient comes with complaints of a bilateral, non-pulsatile headache of tightening quality. She describes it as wearing a tight cap. She has no nausea, photophobia, or phonophobia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A bilateral, non-pulsatile headache of tightening quality without any nausea or photophobia suggests likely diagnosis to be tension-type headache (TTH).

TTH usually starts slowly and fluctuates in severity. It can be episodic or chronic (persist for >15 days).

Treatment of TTH includes simple analgesics such as NSAIDs and paracetamol. Amitriptyline has been found to be useful for chronic TTH. Triptans are not useful in the treatment of this condition. 

Other options:

Option A: Migraine headache typically starts with a prodrome consisting of mood changes, tiredness, discomfort, food cravings, and yawning. This is followed by the headache phase associated with nausea, photophobia, phonophobia, and allodynia. During the postdrome, there is poor ability to concentrate and neck discomfort. 

Management includes lifestyle changes including sleep, exercise, diet, and pharmacological management depends on the severity. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), triptans, and dopamine receptor antagonists are used in the treatment of migraine.

Option C: Medication overuse headache can occur with overuse of opioids or barbiturate containing analgesics. Patients with migraine with two or more headache episodes per week should be advised to use analgesics cautiously. 

Option D: Cluster headache is a rare form of primary headache. It is characterized by deep excruciating pain that is usually retroorbital, and unilateral. It usually lasts for short duration of 8-10 weeks a year followed by a pain-free interval. It is associated with lacrimation, rhinorrhoea, and ptosis. In acute cases, oxygen therapy is useful. Subcutaneous and nasal sumatriptan can be used.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of oligomenorrhoea, weight gain, and acne. USG shows multiple cysts in the ovary. Which of the following is not included in Rotterdam criteria?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) and acanthosis nigricans is not included in the Rotterdam criteria.

PCOS is the most common endocrine disorder in a reproductive-age woman but the cause is unknown.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE - 2018) is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). It is an algorithm and diagnosis is made only after excluding other causes. To diagnose both of the following criteria should be present:

1) Irregular menstrual cycles is defined as

  • normal cycles in the first year post menarche (due to pubertal transition).
  • < 21 or > 45 days in 1-3 years post menarche
  • < 21 or > 35 days or < 8 cycles per year > 3 years post menarche to perimenopause.
  •  > 90 days for any one cycle > 1-year post menarche
  • Primary amenorrhea by age 15 or > 3 years post thelarche (breast development).

2) Clinical/Biochemical hyperandrogenism characterised by alopecia, acne, hirsutism

If only one of the criteria can be established, then an endovaginal/transabdominal ultrasound to demonstrate polycystic ovaries should be done (confirmatory).

PCOS can increase the risk for:

  • Cardiovascular disease 
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Gestational and type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A statistician collects data regarding life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income of the population. Which among the following is most likely being calculated by the statistician?
questions.solution:
The index that is calculated using the given indicators such as life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income is the Human Developmental Index (HDI).

Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development. It assesses abilities 

  • To lead a healthy long life - measured by life expectancy at birth
  • To acquire knowledge- measured by mean years of schooling
  • To achieve a decent standard of living- measured by gross national income per capita

Hence the 3 dimension indices used to calculate the human development index are as follows life expectancy index, education index, and gross national index. 

Other options:

Option A- Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) uses three indicators which include infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy rate.

Option B- Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) is an international measure of acute multidimensional poverty by capturing the acute deprivations in health, education, and living standards that a person faces simultaneously. It is assessed using 3 dimensions and 10 indicators which are as follows:

  1. Health - Nutrition and child mortality
  2. Education- Years of schooling and school attendance
  3. Standard of living - 
    • Cooking fuel
    • Sanitation
    • Drinking water
    • Electricity
    • Housing
    • Assets

Option C- Disability-adjusted life years (DALY) is the amount of time lost due to ill health. It is expressed as the number of years lost due to ill health, disability, or early death. The components of DALY are:

  • Years of life lost due to premature death
  • Years lived with disability (YLD)
  • Years lived in a state of less than full health

questions.text: During an ophthalmological evaluation of a patient, the Schirmer's test at the end of 5 minutes revealed filter paper wetting of <10 mm. All of the following could have led to this finding, except:
questions.solution:
<10 mm of wetting at the end of 5 minutes on Schirmer's test is suggestive of dry eye disease. All of the above can lead to this finding, except dacryocystitis. 

Dry eye disease occurs as a result of inadequate tear volume and function which results In unstable tear film and ocular surface disease. The causes are: 

  • Sjögren syndrome
  • Ocular rosacea
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Follicular conjunctivitis
  • Age-related dry eye 
  • Wearing contact lenses 
  • Trachoma

Schirmer's test is used for the assessment of aqueous tear production by measuring the amount of wetting of a special filter paper(no. 41 Whatman). <10 mm of wetting after 5 minutes without anesthesia is considered abnormal. However, a single Schirmer test should not be used as the sole criterion for diagnosing dry eye. 

Dacryocystitis is the infection of the lacrimal sac caused secondary to nasolacrimal duct obstruction. The clinical features are excessive tearing (epiphora), recurrent conjunctivitis, pain, and swelling in the medial canthus. 

The image below is an illustration of a Shirmer's test being performed:


Other options: 

Option B: Vitamin A deficiency - Dry eye associated with vitamin A deficiency is called xerophthalmia. Night blindness, discomfort and loss of vision are the symptoms. Retinoic acid is the active form of vitamin A. Bitots spots which are triangular patches of foamy keratinized epithelium are seen in the conjunctiva.

The image below shows Bitots spots:


Option C: Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Option D: Ocular rosacea is a manifestation of acne rosacea which is a chronic idiopathic dermatosis. Symptoms are irritation, telegenctasia, blepharitis, etc. 

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: What is the period after fertilization during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins?
questions.solution:
The period after fertilization, during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins, is >13 days.

The proposed mechanisms are:

  • Incomplete splitting of one embryo into two 
  • Fusion of a portion of one embryo from a monozygotic pair onto the other.

questions.text: A young man came for an infertility workup. Semen analysis was done and the report was normal. Which of the following findings can be expected in his semen sample?

choices.text: Sperm concentration of 35 million per mL

questions.solution:
A sperm concentration of 35 million per mL can be expected in his semen sample.

Semen analysis is an important component in evaluating the cause of male infertility. According to WHO(2021), the lower limits of the values in a semen analysis are as follows:

  • Volume of semen- 1.4 mL
  • Sperm concentration- 16 million sperm per milliliter
  • Total sperm number per ejaculate- 39 million
  • Total motility- 42%
  • Progressive forward motility- 30%
  • Vitality- 54%
  • Normal morphology- 4%

Semen is collected in a sterile cup. The male is asked to refrain from ejaculating for 3-4 days prior and the sample is obtained. It has to be sent to the lab within an hour where it undergoes liquefaction. The process takes 15-20 minutes. If parameters are normal, a single sample is sufficient, if not, two samples at an interval of one month should be taken. 

Some of the disorders of sperm are:

  • Aspermia—means no semen.
  • Azoospermia—implies no sperm in semen.
  • Oligospermia—low sperm count. It is defined as a sperm count of less than 15 million sperm per milliliter
  • Asthenospermia— diminished sperm motility
  • Teratospermia—abnormal morphology of sperms.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with abdominal pain, bloody stools, and elevated blood pressure. He is a known case of chronic hepatitis B. The arterial biopsy finding of this patient is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chronic hepatitis B infection and arterial biopsy findings of fibrinoid necrosis suggests a likely diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). 

Polyarteritis nodosa is a vasculitis syndrome that causes segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation in small and medium-sized arteries. It is often superimposed with aneurysm or thrombosis. 

About one-third of the patients with PAN are noted to have chronic hepatitis B which causes the formation of HBsAg-HbsAb immune complexes being deposited in the vessel walls.

Histologically, during the acute phase, there is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall along with fibrinoid necrosis and luminal thrombosis. Fibrinoid necrosis is usually the result of the deposition of immune complexes and plasma proteins in the arterial wall. On biopsy, fibrinoid necrosis appears as bright pink and amorphous deposits in the vessel wall. 

Clinical features include rapidly accelerating hypertension caused by the involvement of renal arteries, abdominal pain, and bloody stools due to vascular gastrointestinal lesions. 

Other options:

Option A- Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. Arterial biopsy findings show an onion-skin appearance that consists of a concentric arrangement of smooth muscle cells with a thickened and re-duplicated basement membrane.

The image below shows the characteristic onion skin appearance of a renal arteriole.

Option C- Monckeberg medial sclerosis is a vascular pathology of aging characterized by calcifications accumulating in the medial layers of muscular arteries. Since there is no vascular compromise (no luminal narrowing), it is usually an accidental finding.

The image below shows calcific deposits (deep purple on H&E staining) in the arterial wall.

Option D- Giant cell arteritis/temporal arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting large- to small-sized arteries of the head and is commonly seen in the elderly. Patients usually present with constitutional symptoms and symptoms specific to the artery involved:

  • cerebral artery, temporal artery- facial pain, headache
  • ophthalmic artery- sudden onset visual loss, diplopia

Arterial biopsy findings consist of granulomatous inflammation with internal elastic lamina fragmentation and T-cell infiltration. The image below shows internal elastic lamina fragmentation (black arrow) and giant cells (yellow arrow) in a cerebral artery.

questions.text: A young man was brought to the casualty ward following a road traffic accident. He gives a history of having sustained a dashboard injury. On examination, his right lower limb is flexed, adducted, and slightly internally rotated. Which of the following is not a radiological finding seen in this condition?

choices.text: Femoral head appears smaller than normal
Femoral head is displaced above and behind the acetabulum
Prominent lesser trochanter on anteroposterior view

questions.solution:
The given history of dashboard injury and the examination finding of the right lower limb being in a flexed, adducted, and slightly internally rotated posture suggests posterior hip dislocation. Prominent lesser trochanter on anteroposterior view is not a radiological sign seen in this condition. 

Posterior dislocation of the hip occurs when the knee sustains a force injury. It occurs commonly after dashboard injuries.

Patients present with pain, swelling, history of severe trauma, and deformity. The deformity usually seen is flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. It is also associated with the shortening of the leg.

Radiological findings in posterior hip dislocation:

  • Femoral head is displaced above and behind the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualized
  • Femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen
  • Shenton's line will be broken 

Complications associated with posterior hip dislocation:

  • Injury to the sciatic nerve
  • Avascular necrosis of the femoral head
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Myositis ossificans

Treatment includes the reduction of dislocation as soon as possible. If not done within 6 hours, it could lead to osteonecrosis and osteoarthritis. Closed reduction of the dislocation should not be attempted if there is an associated femoral neck fracture.

questions.solution:
The given image shows a sheathed microfilaria with 2 nuclei at the tail which is characteristic of Brugia malayi.

Brugia malayi is endemic to Kerala (most common), Assam, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh and West Bengal.

Brugia malayi are smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti. It shows kinks and secondary curves. Cephalic space is longer and carries double stylets at the anterior end. The nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films. The tip of the tail carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal.

The below image shows the microfilaria of Brugia malayi.

Other options:

Option A: The microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti is sheathed with a pointed tail tip free of nuclei.

Option C: The microfilariae of Loa loa is sheathed with nuclei extending up to the pointed tail tip.

Option D: The microfilariae of Onchocerca volvulus is unsheathed with a blunt tail tip free of nuclei.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presented with a history of fever, sore throat, and enlarged lymph nodes. He was prescribed ampicillin after which he developed a maculopapular rash. Which of the following is the standard diagnostic test for this condition?
questions.solution:
A young adult with fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy and development of a maculopapular rash after administration of ampicillin likely has infectious mononucleosis. The standard diagnostic test for this condition is the Paul Bunnell test, which is a heterophile antibody reaction test.

Infectious mononucleosis (IM), or kissing disease or glandular fever, is caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Patients present with fever, pharyngitis, bilateral symmetrical lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. A drug-induced rash may develop on using beta-lactam antibiotics. Large, atypical lymphocytes are seen in the peripheral blood of affected patients.

Paul-Bunnell test is a heterophile agglutination test used for the diagnosis of IM. It identifies the heterophile antibodies produced in IM that agglutinate erythrocytes of different animal species. These antibodies can be demonstrated by the end of the first week of illness, but are occasionally delayed until the third or fourth week and may persist for months. In this test, the inactivated serum of a patient is mixed with 1% suspension of sheep erythrocytes in serial dilutions. After incubation at 37°C for four hours the tubes are examined for agglutination. An agglutination titre of 100 or above is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis.  

Other serological tests such as immunofluorescence and ELISA are employed to detect antibodies against EBV. The lgM antibody to VCA (virus capsid antigen) appears soon after primary infection and disappears in 1-2 weeks. It indicates primary infection. The IgG anti-VCA antibody persists throughout life and indicates past or recent infection. The new appearance of antibodies to the EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) is a marker for primary infection.

Other options:

Option A: Cold agglutination test is used to detect primary atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma.

Option B: Weil-felix test is used for rickettsial infections.

Option D: Microscopic agglutination test is used for diagnosing leptospirosis.
